DOC.HEAD: Revolution Brings High Hopes for Border Contacts
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nicolae Franghili has not seen his hometown just across the Prut River in 49 years, since the day his parents and their six sons fled Stalin's terror when the Soviet Union absorbed Moldavia. He said he will return once a week if Romania's revolution against another tyrant, Nicolae Ceausescu, opens one of the tightest borders in Eastern Europe. Opening the border is expected to be on the agenda Saturday when the Soviet foreign minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, meets with officials of the interim government that took over when Ceausescu was overthrown and executed last month. Romanians profess to have more serious problems than reunification with what is now Soviet Moldavia, taken by Stalin in 1940, but rising ethnic consciousness on the Soviet side has made Moldavia one of the Kremlin's many headaches. Much broader cultural and economic exchanges and a plan to open the border to free travel are among issues Soviet officials have discussed with the new Romanian government, Mikhail S. Platon, a deputy premier of Moldavia, said in an interview this week in Kishinev, the capital. Franghili, across the river, is eager. ``I'm just waiting,'' the gray-haired, 60-year-old construction engineer said in an interview Tuesday at the dining table of his small apartment in this Romanian border city of 300,000 people. ``I want a passport, so I can go every Sunday.'' His father, a teamster, received a grant of land from the Soviets after they arrived in 1940 in what had been northern Romania, and everything seemed fine at first. The Soviet government sent material for the residents to make clothing _ the same flowered cloth for men and women alike, Franghili recalled. He remembers how columns of Soviet soldiers with red banners unfurled led tanks into his town, how positive feelings began changing as Stalin deported ethnic Moldavians and replaced them with politically more reliable Slavs. The family fled to western Romania when Germany and its allies in Bucharest attacked the Soviet Union in 1941. In 1946, they hid again to avoid being sent back to the victorious Soviet side as Stalin demanded. Franghili has seen the Moldavian side of the border only once, on a tour in 1979. Romanian tour guides refused to allow deviations from tbe itinerary, even for the reunion of relatives who had not seen each other for decades. Franghili could not travel to the river town of Kagul, about 90 miles south on the Soviet side of the border. Such strictness has been standard on the border for 20 years. After Ceausescu refused to take part in the Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, the Soviet Union severely restricted border access. In recent years, Ceausescu's worry that his citizens would find life better on the other side prompted Romania to limit travel. Ethnic Moldavians, who make up 64 percent of that Soviet republic's 4.2 million people, began clamoring last year for more autonomy from Moscow, as have people in the Baltic republics and other regions. Like the Baltics, Moldavia was taken by Stalin under the secret protocol of the 1939 non-aggression agreement with Nazi Germany. Until now, Moldavian activists had no options because Ceausescu _ a ``Romanian Stalin'' in the eyes of Mikhai Ghimpuc, leader of the Moldavian People's Front _ was on the other side of the border. Soviet officials, who for decades tried to convince the world that Romanians and Moldavians were distinct nationalities, finally gave up. In September, the Cyrillic alphabet Stalin imposed on Moldavia was replaced by the Latin alphabet Romanians use. People on both sides of the border understand each other with little difficulty and both areas claim to be cradles of Romanian culture. For centuries, Iasi was a center of Romanian learning. Ethnic feelings and passion for reunification are much stronger on the Soviet side of the border than in Romania. Platon said that, when the uprising against Ceausescu began, many Moldavians told the Soviet government they were ready to fight for the revolution. Moscow refused to allow it, but offered humanitarian aid. The Soviet side is willing to open bridges closed for decades, exchange theater groups, writers and other artists, and begin closer economic cooperation, Platon said, but reunification is another question. ``This is not a situation of two Germany,'' he said, referring to calls to reunify East and West Germany since the Berlin Wall was opened in November. He said Soviet Moldavians, whose territory is rich agriculturally, know they live better than Romanians. Officially, the new Romanian government agrees reunification with Moldavia, or Bessarabia as it was known in the Russian Empire, is not on the table. ``There is no Bessarabian problem, and in any case, it is not Bessarabia, but Soviet Moldavia,'' said Silviu Brucan, who manages foreign policy for the National Salvation Front now running Romania. Franghili and other residents of Iasi see reunification as a distant goal, not to be pursued now when the country must be rebuilt.

DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Thursday that Pakistan won independence from India in 1947. The nation gained independence from Britain in that year.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Team Excavating Warplane Crash Sites In Laos
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military experts began excavating two airplane crash sites in Laos today to determine the fates of American servicemen missing from the Vietnam War, a U.S. Embassy spokesman said. The experts left Bangkok Friday for the seventh joint excavation with Laotian officials since 1985, said spokesman James Williams. They were from the U.S. Joint Casualty Resolution Center and the Army Central Identification Laboratory, both based in Hawaii and charged with accounting for America's wartime missing. Williams said the current sites in southern Laos were surveyed twice last year, but he had no further details. About 2,300 Americans are listed as missing in action from the Vietnam War, about 540 in Laos. The war ended in 1975 with communist victories in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. The United States has diplomatic relations only with Laos.

DOC.HEAD: 5 Workers Suspended Over Temple Elephant's Death
DOC.TEXT: Five workers at a Hindu temple in southern India were suspended pending an inquiry into the death of the temple's 47-year-old elephant, according to news reports. The elephant Venugopalan died Tuesday after gangrene set in on lesions on his legs caused by beatings, Press Trust of India said Friday. It quoted unidentified official sources as saying the elephant's handlers had hit him with heavy objects. Five temple workers, including the assistant administrator for livestock, were suspended after veterinarians at the Kerala Agriculture University at Trichur issued an autopsy report, the news agency said. Venugopalan, whose name is derived from one of the names used for the flute-playing Hindu warrior god Krishna, belonged to Trichur's Guruvayoor temple, a major pilgrimage site in the southern coastal state of Kerala.

DOC.HEAD: Light Tremors Shake Mount Etna, Volcano Spits Ash, Rocks
DOC.TEXT: Hot ash and rocks shot from Mount Etna and fell on nearby hamlets during a snowstorm, experts said. Seismologists at the International Volcanology Institute in Catania, the Sicilian city lying at the foot of Europe's most active volcano, also said a series of tremors rattled the top of Mount Etna over several hours early Friday. The southeastern crater of the volcano spit hot ash and lava rock, which fell on the villages of Maletto, Bronte and Randazzo during a snowstorm, the seismologists said. No one was injured and no damage was reported. Bad weather conditions did not allow volcanologists to observe the eruption at close range, but they said it did not appear lava had flowed down the side of the volcano.

DOC.HEAD: Marine to be New Editor of U.S. Military Paper
DOC.TEXT: The new chief editor of Pacific Stars and Stripes will be a uniformed officer despite recommendations by Congress that a civilian hold the post at the newspaper, which serves American troops. Today's edition said Marine Col. Walter S. de Forest will replace Air Force Col. Edwin J. Montgomery as commander and editor-in-chief when Montgomery retires in the spring. It said the appointment was reviewed by the Defense Department and the ombudsman appointed last June to look into complaints that military editors had censored news. Philip M. Foisie, the ombudsman, is a former executive editor of the International Herald Tribune and former foreign editor of the Washington Post. He visited Japan several times to look into the situation at Pacific Stars and Stripes and traveled to West Germany to assess its sister paper, European Stars and Stripes. His recommendations on management of the papers have not been made public. A report in 1988 by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said it found evidence of censorship and improper management at the papers and recommended the top editor at each be a civilian. Several members of Congress have said American troops should be assured of receiving uncensored news. The military editors of the papers denied censorship. In October, Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams said the Pentagon would install civilians as chief editors when the current editors retired. Later, he said no decision had been made. De Forest, the new editor of the Pacific edition, is deputy director of public affairs for the Marine Corps in Washington and has a masters degree in journalism from the University of Wisconsin. Pacific Stars and Stripes said he would serve an internship on commercial newspapers in the United States before taking his new job. Staffs of the service papers include military and civilian journalists. Some civilians have said military commanders stop publication of news that might embarrass the armed services or offend host countries.

DOC.HEAD: Editor of Respected French Daily Promoted
DOC.TEXT: Daniel Vernet, editor-in-chief of the daily Le Monde, was named director of editorial operations following a failed bid last month for the top post at France's most respected journal. Vernet, 44, was the sole candidate on a ballot to succeed Andre Fontaine as managing director of the independent afternoon newspaper. Fontaine announced the appointment Friday and named two editors-in-chief to assist Vernet in his new job. Bruno Frappat will take charge of daily coverage and Claude Sales will handle supplements, the debate page and long-range projects. An editorial staff panel of 250 chooses the paper's managing director by vote. Vernet failed to muster the 60 percent approval needed in the Dec. 18 vote. No other candidate has been put forward to succeed Fontaine, whose term expires in 1993. Fontaine said Vernet's appointment to the newly created post underscores his confidence in him. Vernet joined the newspaper in 1973 and served as a correspondent in Bonn, Moscow and London before becoming foreign editor in 1983 and editor-in-chief in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Beheaded For Killing Husband
DOC.TEXT: A woman was beheaded in the Gulf coast city of Dammam after an Islamic court found her guilty of murdering her husband, the Interior Ministry announced. A statement issued by the ministry Friday said Shafaa bint Nasser bin Ali al-Merri murdered her husband as he slept, confessing she carried out the crime because she was forced into marrying him and because he beat her savagely. Saudi Arabian uses Islamic Sharia, law which calls for beheading murderers with a sword, cutting off the hands of thieves and stoning adulterers. The law applies to nationals as well as to resident foreigners.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Blasts Regulators for Taking Away Thrift
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr., denying government charges he plundered his own thrift, is defiantly accusing the government of driving his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association into bankruptcy. Keating, who is asking a federal court to overturn the government's seizure of Lincoln, said the Irvine, Calif., thrift would be operating at a profit today if the government hadn't interfered in his business, eventually taking it away from him. ``They took away an association with $5.5 billion in assets and they were supposed to have some reason to do that,'' Keating told reporters Friday after completing nearly six hours of testimony before U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin. ``This company (Lincoln) made money. In my opinion it was well managed. In my opinion it would have survived. In my opinion there would have been, under the proper handling by the regulator, no losses,'' he said on the steps of the federal courthouse. Regulators seized Lincoln in April and estimated the cost of the failure to taxpayers at up to $2 billion, making it the largest S&L failure yet. The government later filed a $1.1 billion fraud and racketeering civil suit against Keating and his associates. The financier is also at the center of a political drama in which the Senate ethics committee is investigating the actions of five senators who accepted more than $1.3 million in contributions from Keating and later met with federal regulators on his behalf. Under questioning from government attorneys and the judge, Keating denied the contention of regulators that he used business deals and other devices to funnel money from Lincoln to American Continental Corp., Lincoln's parent company. The holding company paid Keating a total salary of $3.7 million in 1986 and 1987 and employed many of his relatives. Specifically, the government says American Continental used a tax-sharing agreement between Lincoln and American Continental to siphon $94 million from the thrift to the holding company from 1985 through 1988. However, Keating told Sporkin, ``With all my heart and soul, I want you to know that I categorically deny that I had any concept remotely related to that.'' Regulators say Keating used ``sham'' land transactions to generate false profits at Lincoln, which in turn created a tax liability that could be paid to the holding company. In one, Lincoln was able to make an $11 million profit and create a $4.4 million tax liability by selling 1,000 acres of land to WestContinental Mortgage Co., a straw buyer for Arizona developer Ernest C. Garcia. That same day, Garcia had received a $20 million loan from Lincoln which regulators contend enabled Garcia to pay for the land. Keating acknowledged Lincoln's bookkeeping cloaked Garcia's identity as the true buyer of the land, but he said that was common in land syndication deals. Sporkin, who served as enforcement chief at the Securities and Exchange Commission before becoming a judge, reacted skeptically. ``When you run a bank or a savings and loan, you have the highest responsibility of anyone because you're not dealing just with stockholders, you're dealing with people's savings,'' Sporkin said. ``... The only way regulators (can ensure that an institution is being run properly) is if the books and records accurately reflect transactions.'' Garcia, through his attorney, refused to testify Friday, invoking his constitutional protection against self-incrimination. Friday marked the seventh day of hearings in Keating's attempt to overturn the seizure of Lincoln and the end of the government's presentation. Keating's attorney said he would require nine days to present Keating's evidence against regulators. Sporkin said he hoped to begin those sessions as early as next week. ``The government's case has been presented and completed and to me it's obvious that they have not made a case. ... Our turn now starts,'' Keating said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Susan Eisenhower, granddaughter of President Dwight Eisenhower, will marry Roald Z. Sagdeev, an adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. They will tie the knot in a Feb. 9 civil ceremony in Moscow and then will be ``blessed'' at a religious ceremony at the U.S. Embassy there, Sagdeev said. The couple will maintain two homes, living in Washington with Miss Eisenhower's three school-age children during the fall and spring, and spending summers in Moscow, said Sagdeev, 57. He said he has two grown children. They met 2{ years ago, and the romance blossomed while they collaborated on a book about ``survival, how a very thin layer of intellectuals survived through difficult years, through purges,'' before Gorbachev rose to power in 1985, Sagdeev said. Miss Eisenhower, 38, was not immediately available for comment on the wedding, which she announced through the Eisenhower World Affairs Institute. The marriage will be Miss Eisenhower's third. Her consulting company, the Eisenhower Group Inc., handles commercial ventures for major U.S. companies dealing with the Soviet Union. Sagdeev, a rocket scientist, was elected to the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies last year, and was a political ally of the late Andrei D. Sakharov.

Actor James Drury says his only regret about his nine years of playing the mysterious cowboy on ``The Virginian'' television series was that his character never got the girl. ``She always died of a mysterious disease or she had to leave town in a hurry,'' he recalled in the Jan. 22 issue of US magazine. After acting in the series, Drury settled in Cypress, Texas, and had five children. He is now in his third marriage. The 55-year-old actor said he sees a chiropractor twice a week, due to crack ribs he suffered during the show. ``It was often necessary to hit the ground from horseback,'' Drury said.

Larry Hagman, star of the television show ``Dallas,'' has given $150,000 to the Dallas Symphony to support an annual concert honoring his mother, actress Mary Martin. Ms. Martin, a native of Weatherford, Texas, best known for her starring roles in the Broadway musicals ``Peter Pan'' and ``The Sound of Music.'' She is expected to attend the first Mary Martin Annual SuperPops Concert with her family on May 4 at the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center. Dallas-area disadvantaged youth will be given complimentary concert tickets as part of the endowment agreement.

Nicola Rescigno, the co-founder of the Dallas Opera who has had disagreements with its administration in recent years, has resigned as the opera's artistic director. The opera's board on Friday accepted Rescigno's resignation ``with deep regret.'' ``I am disappointed that Nicola is leaving in discontent,'' opera board President John Dayton said. ``He is critical of the administrative leadership of the company and contends that such leadership has thwarted his artistic efforts.'' In his letter of resignation, the 73-year-old Rescigno wrote: ``It is with great sadness and regret that I must leave a company I helped create and that had become the core of my artistic activity during the past 33 years.'' Rescigno, regarded as one of his generation's foremost interpreters of the operatic repertoire, said he plans to step up his worldwide guest conducting schedule.

Actor Mel Gibson is expanding his ranchland holdings in south-central Montana. Beartooth International Corp., of which Gibson is principal stockholder, plans to buy 5,000 acres adjacent to its 12,500-acre Beartooth Ranch, ranch manager George Ellis said. Gibson, whose ``Lethal Weapon'' movies have been box-office hits, lives in Australia and rarely visits Montana, Ellis said.

Milovan Djilas, communist Yugoslavia's leading dissident, will receive the Freedom medal from the Roosevelt Institute of New York. He will be awarded the medal May 19, in Middelburg, Holland, for his ``devotion to democracy and resistance to despotism.'' Djilas spent nine years in jail for his criticism. The Roosevelt Freedom medal was established to honor individuals and institutions which contributed to freedom. He said that when the medal was first given, he and other communists ``did not hold the theses contained in it in great esteem. But now the history shows what great thoughts these were. So I am all the more touched.'' The institute said his book ``The New Class'' _ published in the 1950s abroad, and due for publication for the first time in Yugoslavia this year _ contained ``brilliant insights.''

Actor Tom Cruise, who plays a paralyzed war veteran in ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' says those who can walk take too much for granted. He told US magazine for its Jan. 22 issue that for someone who is paralyzed, ``Just tying your shoes is like bench-pressing 250 pounds or like running a marathon.'' Cruise, 27, who plays Ron Kovic in the movie, says he interviewed paralyzed people at various rehabilitation centers to prepare himself for the part. ``We take a lot for granted: getting out of bed in the morning, putting our shoes on, running into the shower, washing our hair, running down the stairs,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gwyneth Jones Sings First Met Turandot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: Gwyneth Jones, who made her debut at the Metropolitan Opera in 1972, hadn't sung the title role in ``Turandot'' here until the Puccini opera's first performance this season. Her performance was a triumph. Her singing, including lots of difficult high notes, was strong and beautiful. Vocally and in acting, the Welsh soprano made Turandot more womanly and less a monster than usually is done. Since Calaf, the tenor, falls in love with the bloodthirsty Chinese princess, it's probably a good idea. At the Friday night performance, Nello Santi conducted with control and vigor and received enthusiastic applause. Vladimir Popov of Moscow has an unusual tenor voice. In the first act it was focused too narrowly and sounded strained. After he warmed up, it sounded like an Irish tenor, warm while keeping a crisp edge. His voice can ring, not just on final notes, but through entire phrases. The aria ``Nessun dorma'' is where most tenors display their vocal beauty. Popov's voice sounded more beautiful when he was answering Turandot's riddles _ if he missed she'd send him to death _ and later, when Turandot is feeling emotion for the first time. Aprile Millo sang the slave, Liu. We prefer a less rich soprano voice for Liu, as more of a contrast to Turandot's voice. But there's no denying that Miss Millo created some beautiful musical moments. Early in Act 1, however, when Liu, Calaf and his old father are on stage, John Macurdy as the old man sounded best. The other two were pushing too hard. The production, one of Franco Zeffirelli's elaborate, big ones, was new in March 1987. It wasn't presented last season and much of the audience hadn't seen it before, judging from the delighted gasps for the emperor's splendid golden throne room. A few changes have been made. Act 1 is gray people, sampans and shacks. The palace, once shimmering in the distance, seems to have been brought forward. And the banners furled for each riddle now are done by three men instead of the silliness of two men pulling them from a backpack worn by Turandot.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Fines Delta $70,000, Cites Pilot and Dispatcher For Diverted Flight
DOC.TEXT: When Flight 1575 took off from Fresno, Calif., the passengers thought they were flying to Reno, Nev., but the Federal Aviation Administration says the pilot and his dispatcher had other plans. The FAA, which for a time thought the June 17 flight had been hijacked, proposed Friday to suspend the licenses of the Delta Air Lines pilot and dispatcher and fine the airline $70,000 for flying an ``unairworthy'' plane to an unscheduled destination. FAA spokesman Fred Farrar said that when the airline found it could not make needed repairs to its rudder control system in Fresno or Reno, it allowed the plane to take off with passengers and then immediately diverted it to Los Angeles where repair facilities were available. Neither the FAA nor Delta identified the pilot or dispatcher or said how many passengers were aboard the flight. Farrar said letters were sent Dec. 15 to the airline and the two employees, informing them of the proposed fine and suspension and giving them a chance to respond before it becomes final. Airline spokeswoman Jackie Pate in Atlanta said Delta would investigate the incident and discuss the proposed action with the FAA. ``It's premature to say anything about what happened,'' she said. The FAA said the pilot was in contact with maintenance facilities in Atlanta, Ga., where the dispatcher was located. Before takeoff, the pilot spent 20 or 30 minutes on the ground performing various tests in an unsuccessful effort to fix the problem, the FAA said. According to the agency's letter, the captain and dispatcher then ``devised a course of action to takeoff the aircraft from Fresno with a flight plan ... to Reno with no intent to fly to Reno but instead on takeoff to immediately divert to Los Angeles because of the mechanical discrepancy.'' During the time on the ground, the pilot did not communicate with the FAA control tower. ``This, together with the unexplained diversion of the flight after takeoff, prompted the FAA to treat the flight as a possible hijacking and give it special handling,'' Farrar said. The 727 has three rudder control units, including a standby, but the FAA said the aircraft's minimum equipment list requires that all three be operating prior to takeoff. An inoperative system could cause control problems under some circumstances, such as landing in a crosswind or if there were an engine failure during takeoff, Farrar said.

DOC.SECOND: Panamanians, in Poll, Resoundingly Favor U.S. Invasion,0644
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Panamanians almost unanimously support the U.S. invasion that toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, despite casualties that personally touched nearly a quarter of the population, a poll there has found. More than six in 10 of the 794 Panamanians polled expect the invading U.S. troops to remain there for six months or longer, and nearly eight in 10 said they want the soldiers to stay that long or ``as long as necessary.'' The survey, consisting mostly of in-person interviews, was done Tuesday through Thursday by CBS News and Belden & Russonello, a research firm based in Washington. Remote areas were excluded, but results can be projected to about 75 percent of the population. The poll has a four-point error margin. Interviewing was under way when Noriega surrendered to U.S. forces Wednesday night to face charges in Miami of supporting international drug trafficking. Eight in 10 favored his trial in the United States. CBS pollster Kathleen A. Frankovic noted that the findings could reflect a ``post Noriega-out-of-there euphoria'' among Panamanians. Follow-up surveys could find whether the support for the invasion is lasting or short-lived. As things are, 92 percent said Noriega's reign was mostly bad for Panama, and even more said the Panamanian people couldn't have ousted him alone. With Noriega out, 90 percent expect the situation in Panama to improve. The U.S. invasion Dec. 20 won equally resounding support: Ninety-two percent were in favor, with most of them approving strongly. Eight in 10, moreover, believed the United States ``sincerely cared about helping Panamanian democracy.'' Nearly as many said they would have supported a U.S. invasion during a coup attempt by Panamanian officers in October. Roughly three-quarters said U.S. troops used appropriate force in the fighting, which lasted four days, leaving an estimated 600 people dead and thousands wounded. Surprisingly, 19 percent said the invaders used too little force. The invasion's cost was high in any case. Fifteen percent said they suffered some personal loss, loss of property or vandalism to their home or business. Ten percent said the main wage-earner in their home had lost his or her job since the invasion. Ten percent said they had a good friend or relative killed, and 13 percent said they had a friend or relative wounded. Despite the casualties, 87 percent said Noriega's ouster was ``worth the price.'' Respondents gave strong favorable ratings to their new leaders, and about three-quarters expected Panama to be truly ruled by the civil government, rather than by the Panamanian military or the United States. Still, 57 percent opposed allowing members of the military under Noriega to join the new military. On the Panama Canal, 53 percent expected the United States to want to renegotiate the treaty turning the canal over to the Panamanian government in 1999. Most found that acceptable: Seventy percent preferred having the canal run jointly by the United States and Panama, instead of either one alone. As to Noriega, 71 percent called it ``completely unlikely'' that he may return to power, and 16 percent called that ``not very likely.'' The pollsters sought to avoid bias by having interviews conducted in Spanish by Panamanian interviewers who said they were doing independent research for television news, without identifying the network. About 70 interviews were conducted by telephone with residents of the wealthier sections of Panama City; respondents elsewhere were interviewed in person. Interviews were conducted in 158 randomly selected neighborhoods, excluding more rural communities, the remote Bocas del Toro and Darien provinces and the Indian reservation of San Blas. CBS News noted that its efforts were complicated by the conditions under which the survey was conducted, with neighborhoods under curfew and a strong military presence in the streets.

DOC.HEAD: Paroled Killer Charged in Rochester Serial Slayings
DOC.TEXT: After almost two years of legwork, police got their lucky break in a serial-murder investigation when a helicopter pilot circled once more around a park and found a suspect and one of his alleged victims. The pilot followed Arthur Shawcross, a 44-year-old paroled killer, to a nursing home where police questioned him Wednesday. A day later, Shawcross was in jail, charged with killing eight women and under investigation in the deaths of three others. ``We were just on a search, just going over an area that we had covered previously,'' said state police Sgt. Ken R. Hundt, one of two pilots of the helicopter. ``It was kind of like (we saw) the vehicle first, and then the second time around we both saw the body. ``As far as I'm concerned, it was just a matter of luck.'' Rochester Police Chief Gordon F. Urlacher said Shawcross made statements to authorities about the murders and told police where to find three bodies, but he refused to say whether Shawcross admitted to the crimes. A state police source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Shawcross admitted to 11 of the murders. Shawcross pleaded innocent Friday to eight counts of second-degree murder at his arraignment in Rochester City Court. Judge John Manning Regan ordered him held without bail until a preliminary hearing Wednesday. Each count carries a possible penalty of 25 years to life in prison. A profile of the suspect began to emerge Friday from state prison and parole officials, relatives and police who investigated the 1972 slaying of 8-year-old Karen Hill. The Rochester girl was strangled and sexually molested while visiting Watertown, 150 miles to the northeast. Shawcross was convicted of first-degree manslaughter for that slaying and served 15 years in prison. ``I thought he was a very dangerous person,'' said Charles S. Kubinski, a retired Watertown police detective who investigated that slaying. ``He was not mentally disturbed. He knew what he was doing.'' After his parole in 1987, Shawcross was moved by parole officials from three communities because of opposition by local residents. One of the communities was Delhi, a town of 3,500 people about 120 miles northwest of New York City. ``I feel that if the people hadn't stood up and showed their displeasure with the system, then we'd have had the problem Rochester did,'' Delhi Police Chief Frank Harmer said. ``We dodged a bullet.'' Shawcross eventually settled in Rochester, finding a job making salads in a restaurant. He appeared to be adapting well to life outside prison, said Edward Elwin, executive director of the state Division of Parole. ``Superficially, he was making a good adjustment,'' Elwin said. But his mother, Mrs. Arthur Shawcross of Brownville, said her son remained ``a sick person'' who never got over his experiences in the Vietnam war. ``He never should have been let out,'' Mrs. Shawcross told the Syracuse Herald-Journal. She said her son, whom she hadn't spoken to in 17 years, was shot in action and ``saw things he shouldn't have seen over there.'' Police refused to discuss a motive for the slayings, but said all of the victims were involved with drugs or prostitution. Evidence linking Shawcross to three more slayings will be presented to grand juries, said Monroe County District Attorney Howard R. Relin. The 11 deaths are among 16 unsolved slayings of Rochester area women in the last two years. Relin and Urlacher said they don't believe the remaining five killings are related to the 11 in the present case. Even as Shawcross was being arraigned, more bodies were being found. Police following directions they said Shawcross had given them found a body in a densely overgrown area in the suburb of Greece early Friday. They said they believed the body was that of Maria Welch, 22, a Rochester woman missing since Nov. 6.

Fifteen percent said they suffered some personal loss, loss of property or vandalism to their home or business. Ten percent said the main wage-earner in their home had lost his or her job since the invasion. Ten percent said they had a good friend or relative killed, and 13 percent said they had a friend or relative wounded. Despite the casualties, 87 percent said Noriega's ouster was ``worth the price.'' Respondents gave strong favorable ratings to their new leaders, and about three-quarters expected Panama to be truly ruled by the civil government, rather than by the Panamanian military or the United States. Still, 57 percent opposed allowing members of the military under Noriega to join the new military. On the Panama Canal, 53 percent expected the United States to want to renegotiate the treaty turning the canal over to the Panamanian government in 1999. Most found that acceptable: Seventy percent preferred having the canal run jointly by the United States and Panama, instead of either one alone. As to Noriega, 71 percent called it ``completely unlikely'' that he may return to power, and 16 percent called that ``not very likely.'' The pollsters sought to avoid bias by having interviews conducted in Spanish by Panamanian interviewers who said they were doing independent research for television news, without identifying the network. About 70 interviews were conducted by telephone with residents of the wealthier sections of Panama City; respondents elsewhere were interviewed in person. Interviews were conducted in 158 randomly selected neighborhoods, excluding more rural communities, the remote Bocas del Toro and Darien provinces and the Indian reservation of San Blas. CBS News noted that its efforts were complicated by the conditions under which the survey was conducted, with neighborhoods under curfew and a strong military presence in the streets.
