DOC.HEAD: US Inter-Agency Group Looks At Captured Documents in Panama
DOC.TEXT: U.S. intelligence and law enforcement officials hope tons of documents captured by the military in Panama will yield information on possible double agents and on arms and drug trafficking, an intelligence community source says. Eight people in Panama are working on what has been dubbed the Document Control Branch, a special inter-agency group set up for the task, said the source, who has first-hand information about the group and spoke on the condition of anonymity. It could take representatives from the military, the CIA, the U.S. Customs Service, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the State Department some six months sift through the material, according to the source. Asked about the group, a State Department official said: ``We have nothing for you on that.'' The U.S. military took the documents from Panamanian government offices in the days following the Dec. 20 invasion. The source indicated the law enforcement and intelligence workers were based at a U.S. military installation in Panama. A Pentagon spokesman said the Defense Department did ``not have any information on that.'' According to the source, some of the papers examined by the group document arms trafficking by the former regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, including the channeling of weapons to guerrillas fighting the government in Colombia. U.S. officials have long contended that Cuba exports Soviet-supplied materiel to undermine democratic countries in the region. The State Department says Cuba ships arms to El Salvador's rebels. Havana provides the Sandinista government in Nicaragua with most of its weaponry, and Nicaragua, in turn, has supplied Panama with arms, American officials contend. In 1987, Noriega's former deputy, Roberto Diaz Herrera, told reporters the Panamanian general shipped weapons to the Colombian guerrillas. Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. officials Wednesday, faces drug trafficking charges in Miami. And the source said the Drug Enforcement Administration is seeking additional information on drug trafficking in the papers. In other areas of inquiry, the source said: _Customs is looking into possible illegal transfers of technology and smuggling. American officials have contended that goods otherwise unavailable to Cuba because of trade sanctions have arrived on the island through Panama. _The CIA will be looking for lists of spies, attempting to find out who may have worked as double agents. Noriega has been widely reported to have established close ties with the CIA when he served in the 1970s as head of intelligence for the Panamanian Defense Forces. As his internal problems heated up and the Americans pressed for his ouster, Noriega sought closer ties with Cuba. Several U.S. sources believe the general often worked as a double agent, providing information to the intelligence agencies in both the United States and Cuba. A former Noriega aide, Jose I. Blandon, testified before a Senate hearing in 1988 that the general began building up a criminal organization in the early 1970s which involved money laundering, drug smuggling and arms dealing.

DOC.HEAD: North's Lawyers Says Reagan Should Have Been Questioned
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for former White House aide Oliver North say his Iran-Contra case convictions should be thrown out because former President Reagan did not testify at North's trial. ``Mr. Reagan was in a position to testify, as no other witness available to North could,'' about whether the president authorized a cover-up of a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran, North said in papers filed Friday urging a federal appeals court to overturn his convictions. North testified at his trial last year that then-national security adviser John Poindexter told North that Reagan in a Nov. 12, 1986 meeting had not disclosed to congressional leaders his 1985 authorization for the Hawk shipment. ``That statement by Poindexter certainly provided a reasonable basis for concluding that Mr. Reagan had made clear that U.S. involvement in the Hawk shipment should not be disclosed to Congress,'' North's papers said. ``Mr. Reagan's expected testimony also would have corroborated'' North's statements that he was ordered to cover up evidence of his assistance to the Contras by altering classified National Security Council documents, the filing said. U.S. District Court Judge Gerhard Gesell quashed North's subpoena for Reagan's testimony, saying the court record contained no proof the president authorized North to break the law. Court arguments in North's appeal are scheduled for Feb. 6. He was convicted in May of aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress in connection with the Hawk shipment, altering and destroying National Security Council documents that detailed his assistance to the Contras, and illegally accepting a home security system from Richard Secord. Secord, enlisted by North to run arms to the Contras during a congressional ban on military aid to the rebel force, will be sentenced Jan. 24, it was disclosed Friday. Secord pleaded guilty to making a false statement when he told congressional investigators that he was unaware of any money from the Iran-Contra operation that had benefited North. Secord could face up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. North was sentenced to 1,200 hours of community service and fined $150,000. He is appealing the fine and convictions while serving the community service in an anti-drug program.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman Pleads Guilty in Export Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A businessman faces up to 15 years in prison and $500,000 in fines for attempting to illegally export military gyroscopes to South Africa for use in anti-tank missiles. Frank Randazzo, 32, pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court on Friday to conspiracy and violating the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act of 1986. The plea came two days after a South African admitted he participated in the same plot to export sensitive military equipment without a State Department license. Symone Morris Behrmann, a South African who had been living in Toronto, Canada, pleaded guilty Wednesday in federal court to conspiracy and violating the Arms Export Control Act. U.S. District Judge Joyce Green will sentence both men on April 20. Randazzo and Behrmann were accused with three others of conspiring to ship $50 million worth of gyroscopes manufactured by the Northrop Corp. to South Africa through Israel. Randazzo, Behrmann and the three others were indicted as part of an ongoing U.S. Customs Service undercover operation designed to stem the illegal export of sensitive U.S. technology. Also arrested and charged was Maryanne E. Callaghan, 39, of Warwick, R.I. The other two who were charged, Perfezou and Lester George Buckingham Talbot, are South African residents and have not been arrested. The United States has no extradition treaty with South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Identify Gene Possibly Linked to Colon Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Researchers at Johns Hopkins University say their discovery of a gene that may play a role in forming colon cancers could move science closer to a basic understanding of how colon malignancies form. Dr. Bert Vogelstein, head of a research team at the Hopkins oncology center, said his laboratory found that a gene on chromosome 18 is ``an excellent candidate'' for one of four or five genes that experts believe may be linked to colon cancer formation. The gene is called DCC, for ``deleted in colon cancer,'' because the Hopkins research found it is altered in more than 70 percent of the colorectal cancers studied. A report on the DCC gene was published Friday in the journal Science. Vogelstein said the discovery had no immediate clinical or preventative application for colon cancer, the nation's second most lethal form of cancer. However, he said it could contribute to developing methods to detect the disease at an earlier, more treatable stage. The Hopkins team examined 41 colorectal cancers, finding that in more than 70 percent of them the cells had only one copy of a part of chromosome 18. The missing part contained what they called the DCC gene. Normal cells have two copies of this portion of chromosome 18. Normal cells contain 23 different and whole chromosomes, which form the package for all human genes. The genes in a cell direct the production of proteins that carry out biological functions, including the creation of new cells. When these genes are altered, normal protein production is affected. That can lead to abnormal cell formation and, perhaps, disease. Though discovery of the DCC gene has no immediate application, Vogelstein said it theoretically could lead to a method of early detection of colon cancer. He said the mutated gene could produce an altered protein that might be detected in blood or stool. That, in turn, could lead to a direct molecular test for the early stages of cancer formation. It is believed, he said, that colon cancer forms through the mutation of four or five genes. Earlier studies at Hopkins identified two other genes, called RAS and p53, that seem to mutate, or alter, during the formation of colon cancer. RAS is an oncogene, a gene whose presence contributes to cancer formation; p53 is a tumor suppressor whose absence seems to enhance cancer formation. Vogelstein said the DCC gene ``is an excellent candidate'' for a suppressor gene, but that the finding needs to be verified by other labs. About 147,000 Americans were diagnosed with colon cancer in 1988, and about 61,000 die of the disease annually, second only to lung cancer. Members of Vogelstein's research team included Eric Fearon, Dr. Kathleen Cho, Janice Nigro, Dr. Jonathan Simons, Dr. J. Michael Ruppert, Dr. Stan Hamilton, Antonette Preisigner and Kenneth Kinzler. Science is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Fabricated Shooting Story, Authorities Say
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor accused of inventing a story about two men trying to assassinate him was dejected because he feared he wouldn't be reappointed, a top aide said. Camden County Prosecutor Samuel Asbell, now in a psychiatric hospital, hadn't gotten any indication on his future from the state's governor-elect, the prosecutor's first assistant, Dennis G. Wixted, said Friday. ``He was extremely disappointed at the prospect of not being reappointed and was sometimes very sad, quiet and seemingly depressed about it,'' Wixted said. The gun-toting prosecutor, known for accompanying detectives on drug busts, resigned and checked into a psychiatric hospital after he was caught fabricating the story, state Attorney General Peter N. Perretti said Friday. Asbell, 46, had claimed that two gunmen opened fire on him during a car chase through the streets of Camden on New Year's Day. He said he was showered with glass from his shattered car windows but wasn't badly injured in an attack he attributed to his tough stance on illegal drugs. Asbell said he fired back with a 12-gauge shotgun and pistol he kept in the car, and that he hit one of the assailants. ``I saw his head explode,'' Asbell said at a news conference Tuesday. State police had found Asbell shot out his own windows, Perretti said. ``The event was staged by Prosecutor Asbell, apparently acting alone,'' Perretti said. He said Asbell could face criminal charges depending on his psychiatric evaluation. Perretti refused to say why Asbell might have staged the shooting. Wixted said Friday that his boss, whom Republican Gov. Thomas H. Kean appointed in 1984, had despaired because he had no indication he would be reappointed by Gov.-elect James Florio, a Democrat who takes office Jan. 16. Asbell's term expired Dec. 17 and he had been a holdover since. ``What developed was that his love for the job ... basically forced him into a situation very difficult to describe,'' Wixted said. Attempts to reach Asbell were unsuccessful Friday. Perretti said Asbell entered the Carrier Foundation in Somerset County for psychiatric evaluation; a spokeswoman there said privacy laws barred her from confirming or denying his admission there. Perretti said if Asbell decided to check out of the hospital, authorities could move to have him held involuntarily. The attorney general added that he hadn't found any evidence Asbell's ``sudden and aberrational behavior'' affected his work as prosecutor. Asbell stuck to his story as late as Thursday. ``I have met with the attorney general, and he made it explicitly clear to me that I am a victim ... of a violent crime. He very kindly said I have to get (in) my mind the fact that I am not a prosecutor in this matter, but I am a victim,'' Asbell said at a news conference. While in private practice in 1970, Asbell was shot in the chest while representing a client whose property was put up for sheriff's sale. The bullet remains lodged in his chest. ``I'm a hands-on prosecutor,'' Asbell said Wednesday. ``The public knows me. If they know me, the drug dealers know me.'' Kean said that if Asbell is found mentally incompetent, ``prosecution would not serve any purpose.'' ``The whole situation is very sad,'' Kean said. ``He was a good, hard-working prosecutor in every way.'' Gloucester County Prosecutor Richard Hickey III said he considered Asbell a close friend. ``He loved what he was doing. I really feel for his family right now,'' Hickey said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Fears Use of Split Screen Made Him Appear Callous
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has expressed concern that networks' use of a split screen to show coffins of GIs being taken off a transport plane just as the president was making lighthearted comments at the White House made him appear callous. Bush, at the end of a news conference Friday, asked the television networks to warn him in the future when use of the split-screen technique is anticipated. The president was referring to the live telecasts of his previous news conference, held Dec. 21, just one day after the Panama operation began. Toward the end of that session, Bush engaged in some holiday banter, unaware that most of the TV control rooms also were splicing in a live shot of the solemn arrival ceremony at Dover AFB, Del., for the bodies of the first U.S. combat victims in Panama. All the networks except NBC employed the technique. ``I got a lot of mail. ... I had some calls,'' said Bush, ``because when I was speaking here in this room, juxtaposed against my frivolous comments at the time were some split screen techniques that showed American lives, the bodies of dead soldiers in their caskets, dead soldiers coming home. ``And all I respectfully request is that if the urgency of the moment is such that that technique is going to be used, if I could be told about it, then we'll stop the proceedings. Or (not), if it's something less traumatic. ``But that one _ I could understand why the viewers were concerned about this. They thought their president at a solemn moment like that didn't give a damn.'' ``And I do,'' bush added, his voice catching. ``I do. I feel it so strongly. So please help me with that if you would.'' ABC News spokesman Scott Richardson said ABC News President Roone Arledge ``in essence agrees with what the president said.'' ``He (Arledge) called the control room when it came up split screen and asked them to go back to full frame,'' Richardson said. ``Peter Jennings was quite upset and explained at the end of the news conference that the president had not known you were seeing the bodies arrive.'' CBS News President David Burke said in a statement that he understood the president's ``sensitivity'' about the incident, but that the network had planned live coverage of the arrival long before Bush announced his news conference. ``It was our judgment that we had the responsibility to broadcast live a brief portion of the arrival ceremony which occurred simultaneous with the president's briefing,'' Burke said. NBC, which did not use the split screen, said in a statement that it was not likely to develop a policy to alert the White House of such plans. ``As a practical matter, it's not likely to happen in most cases since these decisions are often made in a matter of minutes,'' the network said.

DOC.HEAD: President Releases Disaster Aid Funds for Earthquake, Hugo Recovery
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has authorized the release of $184.6 million in disaster aid to help with recovery from Hurricane Hugo in September and the California earthquake in October. The White House said in a statement Friday that the money would be used for school reconstruction, debris removal, transfer of patients to Veterans Administration hospitals from damaged facilities and repairing federal parks, forests, wildlife refuges and medical facilities. It also will be used for forest fire prevention and stabilization of historic properties. The Education Department will distribute $62.8 million for school reconstruction and related costs in the Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, South Carolina and North Carolina, the White House said. It said the Veterans Affairs Department will distribute $56.8 million for construction and repair of its facilities and transfer of patients. The money comes from a congressionally approved package that Bush signed Oct. 26, allocating a total of $2.85 billion in disaster relief for regions that suffered from Hurricane Hugo and the Northern California quake. Of that money, Bush was left $250 million to spend as he saw fit on unanticipated needs from both disasters.
DOC.HEAD: Noriega Bounty May Go Unclaimed.
DOC.TEXT: Administration officials say the $1 million reward offered by President Bush for information leading to the capture of deposed dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega apparently will go unclaimed, although a congressman believes the money should go to the papal nuncio in Panama. The administration had offered the bounty on Dec. 21, a day after the U.S. invasion of Panama and while Noriega was still at large. ``We don't have any claimants for it at this time,'' said Justice Department spokesman David Runkel on Friday. ``Nobody's stepped forward and asked for it. And I don't anticipate anyone will, in view of the circumstances'' of Noriega's surrender and arrest. He said that under terms of the $1 million offer Bush put on Noriega's head, ``if there were claimants, the attorney general and the secretary of state would determine who would receive it and how much.'' Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., said Friday in a letter to Bush that the papal nuncio in Panama, Monsignor Jose Sebastian Laboa, deserved the reward because he persuaded Noriega to surrender. But administration officials, who asked not to be identified, said the Vatican probably wouldn't qualify for the reward because its role in Noriega's surrender was an indirect one. Noriega was holed up in the Vatican embassy from Christmas Eve until this past Wednesday when he surrendered to U.S. forces.
DOC.HEAD: Justice Spent $224,000 in Futile Effort to Find Leak
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department says it spent $224,000 on a futile attempt to identify the source of an unauthorized disclosure of a preliminary criminal investigation involving Rep. William H. Gray III. The department conducted a five-month investigation to determine who leaked information that the FBI was investigating alleged financial irregularities in Gray's congressional office. An initial CBS-TV story that Gray was the subject of the preliminary investigation prompted a storm of accusations from Democrats on Capitol Hill that the Republican-run Justice Department was trying to smear the Pennsylvania Democrat with news leaks. The department quickly took the unusual step of issuing a statement that Gray was not a target and was cooperating with FBI agents. The CBS story was particularly embarrassing for Attorney General Dick Thornburgh because it was aired as Gray was seeking election as House majority whip, a job he later won. Thornburgh ordered an investigation of the unauthorized leak. The $224,000 included the salaries and travel expenses of 11 FBI agents, as well as prosecutors and support personnel, said Justice Department spokesman David Runkel on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Orders New Trial in Cigarette-Safety Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court threw out the nation's first damage award in a smoker-death case and ordered a new trial, leaving lawyers for both sides haggling over who emerged the winner. The ruling by the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on Friday set the stage for new and expanded litigation against cigarette manufacturers, anti-smoking forces claimed. The appeals court overturned a lower court's damage judgment, which would have made Liggett Group Inc. pay the family of smoker who died of cancer $400,000. The lower court found that Liggett _ which makes Chesterfield and L&M cigarettes _ had advertised its cigarettes as safe. Attorneys for three cigarette manufacturers claimed victory, citing the reversal of the award, which restored their 35-year no-loss record in such cases. But their opponents stressed a part of the ruling in which the court reinstated broader claims that weren't fully considered in the first trial. Rose Cipollone of Little Ferry, N.J., a smoker for 42 years, originally filed the case against Liggett and two other cigarette manufacturers, Lorillard Inc. and Philip Morris Inc. Mrs. Cipollone died of lung cancer at age 58 in 1984, but her husband, Antonio, has carried on the case. ``Plaintiff's attorneys are back to square one after having spent nearly six years and nearly $3 million in lawyer and legal fees,'' said Josiah Murray, Liggett's general counsel. He said he was ``extremely gratified'' with the reversal, but declined to comment further on the decision. Charles Wall, an attorney representing Philip Morris and Lorillard, also was pleased with the court ruling. Cipollone was out of town and unavailable to comment, according to his current wife, Dorothy. His lawyers said they had been unable to reach him. Marc Edell, Cipollone's attorney, said the decision ``is a big win for us'' because he can now seek damages from all three companies. ``I'm looking forward to retrying the case,'' he said. The ruling said Cipollone has ``live claims'' against the three companies on grounds they marketed the product knowing the risks of cigarette smoking. The district court had barred Cipollone from making such a claim. One law professor with ties to anti-smoking forces said the court's ruling on that issue strengthens a plaintiff's ability to seek judgment against the tobacco companies. Richard Daynard, a Northeastern University law professor who heads a center supporting lawyers suing the tobacco industry, said the opinion ``really put tobacco litigation back on the track, where it was a couple of years ago.'' ``That is far more important than getting the $400,000 reversed. This makes the cases actually very easy to win,'' Daynard said. Cipollone's lower court victory was on his contention that the tobacco companies promised through advertising that their products were safe. The appeals court said District Court Judge H. Lee Sarokin erred on that point, by preventing Liggett from trying to prove that Mrs. Cipollone didn't believe the companies' advertisements in the first place. The court said Cipollone could pursue other points denied in District Court such as a general failure-to-warn claim. But the court said Cipollone could pursue the failure-to-warn claim against Liggett because his wife smoked its cigarettes before 1965, when a federal law took effect requiring cigarette makers to put health warnings on packages.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Call it the luck of the Irish, but a wine bottle tossed into waters off Cuba by an Irishman washed up in the land of his ancestors. Michael McNamee and his wife, Judy, were on a ship celebrating their 25th anniversary in August 1988 when they sealed a note in a wine bottle and threw the bottle overboard. ``It was just a whim that we threw that dumb bottle overboard,'' Michael McNamee said Friday. The McNamees of Grand Forks said they received a letter in October from an Irish man, Billy McCarthy, saying he had found the bottle off the west coast of Ireland. They have written to McCarthy but haven't heard back. Michael McNamee, a department store merchandising manager, found it ironic that their note would navigate thousands of miles of ocean and wind up on Irish shore. ``I thought the bottle might get to Cuba or Florida or somewhere along the eastern seaboard. But Ireland? No chance,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New Government Strips Noriega of Rank
DOC.TEXT: The new civilian government sealed the ouster of strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega by stripping him of his rank as general and firing him as chief of the Defense Forces. The papal nuncio, Monsignor Jose Sebastian Laboa, disputed statements by an aide and denied Friday that he gave Noriega an ultimatum to leave the Vatican mission, where the strongman had been in refuge before he surrendered to U.S. troops Wednesday. The Cabinet issued a decree firing 39 military officers, including Noriega's chiefs of staff at the time of the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion that deposed him and defeated his army. The government also promoted three former Defense Forces officers President Guillermo Endara named to head Panama's new public security force. Two of the officers had been jailed after participating in a failed March 16, 1988, coup against Noriega and were freed by the U.S. invasion. The third, Eduardo Herrera, was ambassador to Israel when he took part in the coup and has been in exile in the United States. U.S. officials have said all 16,000 members of the Defense Forces are accounted for, but the commander of U.S. invasion forces said Friday that about 200 die-hard Noriega loyalists remain at large and are ``capable of disrupting activities.'' ``Our first priority is to capture their leadership,'' Lt. Gen. Carl Stiner told reporters at Howard Air Force Base. He indicated they include members of the paramilitary Dignity Battalions Noriega created and other holdouts. Stiner accompanied Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who left for Washington after a one-day visit. He said troops had captured six of the 18 commanders of the Dignity Battalions, which took to the streets in defense of Noriega when the invasion began. ``The last four we captured were turned in by the people,'' he said. ``Otherwise, it is like a rabbit hunt. We go and flush them out.'' Laboa, who sheltered Noriega for 10 days before he surrendered to U.S. troops and was taken to Florida to face drug charges, denied he gave the strongman an ultimatum to force him to leave the mission. ``He left of his own accord. The nuncio never told him to leave,'' Laboa said in a telephone interview. ``There was no threat. There is not a single basis for thinking that.'' Letters Noriega wrote to Pope John Paul II, the nuncio and others before he left show that ``he left of his own free will,'' Laboa said. During the days after Noriega took refuge in the mission Dec. 24, the Vatican said it would not force him out but was urging him to leave on his own. Thursday night, the Rev. Javier Villanueva, who was assisting Laboa during Noriega's stay, said: ``If he would not have given himself up, the Panamanian government, not the U.S. government, would have been invited to send in forces to take him out. We would have lifted the diplomatic immunity.'' Asked about the statement, Laboa said, ``I don't know how such craziness could have come out.'' Villanueva could not be reached for comment Friday night. The Chamber of Commerce, a staunch opponent of Noriega, reopened its doors after being closed for a year and nearly destroyed in the invasion fighting. Chamber of Commerce head Alfredo Maduro called for U.S. aid. ``For the real recovery of the country to take place, we will need the help of our friends,'' he said. Damage from looting following the invasion is estimated at more than $2 billion. There is no estimate of damage from bombing and combat in the invasion and U.S. economic sanctions against the Noriega regime. The White House said the 1991 U.S. budget had no aid money to repair invasion-related damage to Panama. ``Undoubtedly there will be some international funds, some bank loans and that sort of thing that would be involved, and at this point we just can't say how any aid might be financed,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Powell said the number of U.S. troops in Panama will be reduced to close to the pre-invasion level of 12,000 ``over the next few weeks.'' About 14,000 troops participated in the assault. A U.S. survey said Panamanians overwhelmingly approve of the U.S. invasion, even though nearly one in four had a relative or good friend killed or wounded in the fighting. CBS News and Belden & Russonello, a research firm based in Washington, interviewed 794 Panamanian adults, most in person, Tuesday through Thursday. Remote areas were excluded, but results can be projected to about 75 percent of the population. The poll has a 4-point error margin. Noriega was arraigned on drug charges Thursday in Miami and a judge entered a plea of innocent on his behalf after he refused to recognize the court's jurisdiction on grounds he is a political prisoner.

DOC.HEAD: Gadhafi Says Democracy Could Devastate East Bloc, Invites Jews To Libya
DOC.TEXT: Moammar Gadhafi said capitalism and Western-style democracy could ravage reformist Eastern Europe, and he invited Jews to leave Israel and settle in Libya. ``There is no place for capitalism, which is dictatorship based on exploitation of basic human rights that are completely crushed in Western Europe and the United States,'' Gadhafi said Friday, referring to the democratic reforms that have swept the East bloc. He told a news conference that said if Eastern Europe adopts a ``Western European system with its multiparties and capitalism, I warn you of unemployment and beggars, of inflation, crises and, in the end, war.'' Wearing a dark suit under a flowing brown cape, Gadhafi sat at a chair with a low table in front of him and a globe of the world at his side. There were none of his usual female bodyguards, only a few men watching the news conference. At one point he waved a green handerkchief he had been holding to call for order from the estimated 100 Arab and foreign journalists invited to his headquarters at Bab Aziziya, just outside the capital Tripoli. ``Eastern Europe must adopt the new socialism calling for `partners not wage-earners' _ parties destroy the causes of democracy and revolution, the future reality will be the Jamahiriya,'' he said, expounding from his third series of ``universal'' writings, known as his green book. Written and published in the mid-70s, the green book calls for a new economic and political system to replace capitalism and communism in a Jamahiriya, or masses, that has people representing themselves without parties or parliaments. ``The other thing is the question of Jews. Despite the fact that I am an Arab, and I know Arabs are targets of Zionism, I admit the Jews are oppressed in the world,'' Gadhafi said. ``This is a crime committed by Europe and the rest of the world, with the exception of the Arabs, at least of Libya, which would welcome them back.'' Speaking calmly, Gadhafi accused Europe and the United States of plotting to rid the world of Jews by placing them in ``Palestine, the tomb of Jews, the mass oven for Jews. They (Jews) must leave the oven before it gets too hot.'' There had been no hint of the content of his news conference, which some believed would address the revolution in Romania and allegations of Libyans fighting alongside security forces loyal to ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. However, Gadhafi made no reference to the allegations. Asked about Western economic sanctions against Libya, Gadhafi said: ``We are not interested in the European siege. The companies working here need Libyan money, they need Libyan oil. ``We put our conditions, not they; if they don't like them, they can go to hell.'' He said no progress has been made toward a settlement with American oil companies that suspended operations Libya. ``There is no progress. We are ready to talk but there is nothing new,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Residents of Noriega Streets Won't Surrender Name
DOC.TEXT: Residents of Noriega Drive and Noriega Lane say they like the names of their streets just fine and don't plan to surrender them. But they have been targets of some kidding since deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega was brought to the United States to stand trial on drug trafficking charges. The streets in this Florida Panhandle city were named for a family of Noriegas that arrived here more than 200 years ago, but many residents don't realize that. ``The other night I called Domino's Pizza and the girl taking my order asked my address,'' said Reyn Voeltz, a 10-year resident on Noriega Drive. ``When I told her, she yelled, `Noriega!' and asked, `Are you in Panama?' I said, `No, that's the name of my street,' '' Voeltz said. ``I then heard a guy in the background yell, `Don't deliver! Don't deliver!' Then the girl said, `Don't worry about paying for the pizza. If you are who I think you are, there is a $1 million reward for you.' '' Glenn Griffith, another Noriega Drive resident, said he gets the same kind of kidding. ``Whenever someone asks my address, and I tell them Noriega Drive, their first reaction is laughter,'' Griffith said. ``And then they say, `Oh, Manuel.' '' The streets really take their names from a pair of Josephs, a father and son. The first Joseph Noriega arrived in 1781 when the Spanish won the city back from the British in the Battle of Pensacola, said Sandra Johnson, curator of the Pensacola Historical Museum. His son was born in 1788 and was one of the early brickmakers in the area between 1810 and 1830, she said. The Noriegas received tracts of land from the Spanish crown near Escambia Bay where Noriega Drive is situated.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Attorney Deny Plans For Pre-Trial Agreement
LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for ousted Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega say they aren't seeking a plea bargain and will move ahead with plans to bombard a federal court with motions to dismiss drug-trafficking charges. Meanwhile, Noriega remains hidden from the public eye, reportedly in a subterranean room at the federal courthouse where he has met several times with defense attorneys. ``A man who is innocent is not receptive to any plea bargain,'' defense laywer Steven Kollin said Friday after a two-hour conference with Noriega. ``General Noriega is not guilty of these charges and if we can find a jury of 12 people who will have an open mind ... General Noriega will be acquitted.'' Kollin said he has ``absolutely'' ruled out a plea bargain with the government. Justice Department officials have been quoted in published reports as saying they might be interested in striking a deal in exchange for information about Latin American drug networks. Federal prosecutors also said they were gearing up for a trial. ``We are not seeking any kind of agreement of any sort,'' Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said. ``We are preparing for trial.'' President Bush, who announced Friday that he is sending Vice President Dan Quayle on a Latin American diplomatic mission in hopes of repairing relations with those nations after the Panama invasion, also denied that the administration was seeking a deal with Noriega. Bush refused to rule out a plea bargain, however. He said Noriega has the same right as any federal prisoner to seek a deal. Speculation on a plea bargain is linked to the possibility Noriega's trial might expose embarrassing details of his longtime connections with the CIA. Kollin promised to seek Noriega's CIA files. ``We're looking for the truth and the only way to get to the truth is to get to those documents,'' he said. Frank Rubino, another of Noriega's attorneys, said a number of motions are planned to challenge the U.S. District Court's jurisdiction over the 51-year-old Noriega, who could be sentenced to 145 years in prison and fined $1.1 million. Among the planned motions will be claims the case is politically motivated and Noriega is a head of state subject to diplomatic immunity, Rubino said. Other charges will be that the U.S. invasion of Panama Dec. 20 violated international treaties, he said. Rubino said it could take nine months to prepare for trial. Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. troops in Panama City Wednesday night, is charged with taking $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn his nation into a way station for the cocaine trade. Noriega was among 16 people indicted by a federal grand jury in Miami in February 1988. Noriega and five others named in the indictment have been arraigned. Federal officials refuse to divulge Noriega's whereabouts. But U.S. marshals have assured the Miami-based defense team that Noriega can be made available within an hour. ``His demeanor is fine,'' Rubino said. ``He's cheerful and very relaxed.'' During arraignment Thursday before U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler, the judge entered a plea of innocent after Noriega refused to answer to charges. Noriega was ordered held without bond. Noriega was spirited into the downtown Miami courthouse early Thursday after arriving at Homestead Air Force Base aboard a C-130 plane. He surrendered to U.S. troops after 10 days inside the Vatican Embassy in Panama City. The capture of Noriega has led to an exodus of Panamanian exiles returning to their homeland from South Florida. Also, FBI agents have reportedly been sent to Panama to review bank records of suspected American drug dealers, according to newspaper reports. Cuban activists in Miami, meanwhile, have begun distributing 3,000 postcards addressed to Noriega with the message, ``Fidel Abandoned You,'' referring to Noriega's alleged close ties with Cuban leader Fidel Castro.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega's Wife Vows To Fight For His Defense
DOC.TEXT: The wife of ousted Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega says he is a model family man who has been wrongly charged with drug trafficking and unfairly portrayed by the U.S. media. Felicidad Fiero Noriega said she would raise money for her husband's legal defense ``cent by cent,'' according to the interview in today's editions of El Diario-La Prensa, a Spanish-language daily newspaper in New York City. Mrs. Noriega has taken refuge in the Cuban Embassy in Panama City along with her three daughters and a 4-month-old granddaughter, the newspaper said. She told the newspaper she didn't trust the U.S. legal system and feared for ``the destiny of my husband,'' who was brought to the state of Florida to face U.S. drug-trafficking charges. The wife of the ousted military ruler made the comments in a telephone interview from Panama, a transcript of which was made available to and translated by The Associated Press on Friday night. ``I hope that good will triumph over evil,'' Mrs. Noriega said, referring to her husband's legal fight against the drug trafficking charges. Mrs. Noriega said the new Panamenian government hasn't contacted her and is unaware of her situation. She said she plans to stay in Panama, where ``everyone knows I have done social work for the needy.'' She said her husband also worked to help Panama's poor. ``If the TV cameras had been more objective they would have filmed the many toys and bags of food we kept in the garage that were going to the needy,'' she told the newspaper. Of the voodoo altars and cocaine U.S. officials said were found by American troops in her husband's residence, Mrs. Noriega said, ``It was all made up.'' She said she kept in touch constantly with her husband after he took refuge in the Vatican Embassy on Christmas Eve. Noriega eluded U.S. troops after they invaded the country on Dec. 20, and took refuge in the embassy. He surrendered Wednesday night and was flown to the United States. ``Everyone here knows Manuel Antonio to be a model husband who raised his children with love and respect,'' Mrs. Noriega said. Asked if she knew about reports that a mistress had talked Noriega into giving himself up, Mrs. Noriega responded: ``I was not aware of her, because he loves me so much.'' According to the paper, Mrs. Noriega denied any knowledge of her husband's relationship with the CIA and said the accusations that her husband engaged in drug dealing are false. Mrs. Noriega told El Diario-La Prensa that she had talked with her husband before he decided to leave the embassy and give himself up. But she said she ``never asked him why he was giving up or what his plans were.'' According to the paper, Mrs. Noriega said she ``got used to not asking questions, even in difficult times like these.'' Asked about her husband's properties in Panama, Mrs. Noriega said they owned three houses, two in the country and one in the capital, ``just like the majority of the upper middle class in Panama.''

DOC.HEAD: 2 Killed, 14 Towns Under Curfew
DOC.TEXT: Paramilitary troops fired at Moslem separatists violating a curfew in the northern state of Jammu-Kashmir, killing at least two people, police said today. The two men, both Moslems, were killed when they defied a curfew Friday in Srinagar, summer capital of the state along the Pakistani frontier, a senior police officer in Jammu said. Srinagar is one of 14 Kashmiri towns under round-the-clock curfews because of the continuing violence by Moslems who seek independence from predominantly Hindu India or union with overwhelmingly Moslem Pakistan. The latest town to be placed under curfew was Badgam, just outside Srinagar. Curfew was imposed there on Friday night after Moslem demonstrators stoned a police patrol, the Jammu police officer said on condition of anonymity. Residents are under orders not to leave their homes during the curfews, which authorities started imposing Thursday to prevent celebrations of Kashmir Day on Friday. Kashmir Day marks the anniversary of a Jan. 5, 1949, resolution passed by the United Nations that said residents of Kashmir should determine their own future. All government offices and educational institutions were closed Friday in the curfew areas, said the police officer in Jammu, the state's winter capital. Kashmir, the western part of the state, is mostly Moslem, while the eastern Jammu area is mostly Hindu. Moslems comprise 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 5 million people, making it the only state in India with a Moslem majority. Nationwide, Moslems account for about 12 percent of India's 880 million people, while Hindus make up about 80 percent. Kashmir is claimed by India and Pakistan, and the two countries have fought three wars over the territory since gaining independence from Britain in 1947. A cease-fire line monitored by the United Nations divides the old state of Kashmir into Indian and Pakistani sectors. At least 10 people were killed in Indian-governed Kashmir last month during violence sparked by demonstrations celebrating the release of five jailed Moslem extremists in exchange for a kidnapped Cabinet minister's daughter on Dec. 13.

DOC.HEAD: New Year's Gunfire Spurs Plan to Outlaw Year-End Ammo Sales
DOC.TEXT: Ammunition sales would be banned for a week before New Year's Day and the Fourth of July under proposals aimed at stopping revelers from firing guns into the air to celebrate those holidays. Plans offered Friday by Mayor Tom Bradley and Councilmen Joel Wachs and Richard Alatorre also would provide rewards of up to $500 for tips leading to conviction of people illegally firing guns in the city. ``We have a reign of terror when it comes to New Year's Eve,'' Wachs said. Six people were wounded by falling bullets in the city on New Year's Eve and two men were wounded by police when confronted while allegedly shooting. Police made 75 arrests and seized 134 weapons citywide. Bradley said he was ``disgusted'' to discover some gun stores stayed open late in order to supply last-minute bullet buyers. The mayor commended the Police Department for an aggressive education campaign that appeared to reduce the amount of shooting over New Year's but observed that many stores had long lines of bullet buyers over the weekend. Police received 706 complaints about New Year's gunfire, a decrease from the 1,249 incidents a year earlier. A falling bullet killed a 13-year-old boy during New Year's gunfire three years ago. No one was killed this year. Wachs said there may be some discussion on the length of the bans but predicted differences will be ironed out and a law enacted by the 15-member council. At Western Surplus, a southside general store that sells weapons and ammunition, operator Al Campbell wondered whether the ordinance would be effective. ``The ban may cause people to buy ammunition one week earlier,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Kentucky Church Leaders Call for Investigation of Nun's Kidnapping
DOC.TEXT: The case of a nun kidnapped and tortured in Guatemala has been ignored by investigators in that country and the United States, Roman Catholic church leaders say. A group of Kentucky church officials called Friday for investigations by both Guatemala and the U.S. State Department into the Nov. 2 kidnapping of Sister Diana Ortiz. Ortiz has said in a sworn statement that three men kidnapped her from a religious retreat, beat her and burned her with cigarettes during a 30-hour ordeal. Ortiz, a native of Grants, N.M., is a member of the Ursuline Sisters of Mount St. Joseph, a religious community based near Owensboro. She has made no public appearances and granted no interviews since she returned. ``Religious leaders from across Kentucky are calling on the president of Guatemala to begin a formal investigation,'' said Sister Mary Matthias, major superior of the Ursuline order in Owensboro. Sen. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., and Rep. Carroll Hubbard, D-Ky., have requested an investigation by the State Department into the torture and abduction. The State Department said Wednesday in a letter to Hubbard that the investigation is up to Guatemala. ``We hope that she will be able to assist in the investigation, once she has recovered from her ordeal,'' wrote Janet G. Mullins, assistant secretary for legislative affairs in the State Department. As in other cases of human rights abuses in Guatemala, the U.S. Embassy lacks the authority to investigate, Mullins wrote. A spokesman for Hubbard said the congressman was unhappy with the response and planned to talk with Secretary of State James Baker.

DOC.HEAD: Firestorm Over Order To Execute `Traitors' If U.S. Invades
DOC.TEXT: A Defense Ministry communique ordering the execution of ``traitors'' in the event of a U.S. invasion has sparked a war of words between supporters and opponents of the leftist government. The six-page ``Special Communique'' issued following the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion of Panama announced actions to be taken by the armed forces in case of a similar American military attack in Nicaragua. Point No. 3 says: ``At the start of the Yankee intervention, all permanent military units, reserves, people's militias and counterintelligence, in close cooperation with state security, apply the plans of neutralizing, cutting off and executing all recalcitrant traitors who openly or covertly have been encouraging the Yankee intervention.'' Luis Sanchez Sancho, spokesman for the 14-party National Opposition Union running against the government in next month's election, said the communique ``effectively calls for committing murders against the Nicaraguan opposition, who are invariably accused of being `traitors,' by the Sandinistas' ideological criteria.'' Danilo Lacayo, another Union spokesman, accused the Sandinistas of ``encouraging aggression against political leaders and justifying such an aggression by saying it is done to protect the national sovereignty.'' In an open letter published by La Prensa, the country's only opposition newspaper, Nicaraguan Bar Association secretary Orlando Castillo Sobalvarro said called the Dec. 27 communique an ``instigation to the crime of genocide.'' On Friday, Adrian Meza Castellanos, a leading attorney responded with a letter to the pro-government newspaper El Nuevo Diario, calling bar members ``traitors.'' The letter also accused the bar of ``asking the U.S. government to intervene in our country.'' Mariano Fiallos, president of the Supreme Electoral Council supervising the campaign for the Feb. 25 general elections, asked the government for an explanation. Defense Minister Humberto Ortega's reply, in a letter published by the Sandinista newspaper Barricada on Friday, said the communique stated that it had ``absolutely nothing to do with the electoral process.'' It ``has to do exclusively with the legitimate, extraordinary and exceptional measures that an eventual armed intervention would force the Nicaraguan government to impose for the defense of the motherland,'' the letter said. The defense minister's brother, President Daniel Ortega, is seeking re-election; his main opponent is Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, candidate of the National Opposition Union and publisher of La Prensa. Although Fiallos himself is a Sandinista party member, his council's impartiality has met with the approval of a United Nations and other foreign observer missions here to monitor the electoral process. Iqbal Riza of Pakistan, head of the U.N. observer mission, also expressed concern to Fiallos about the communique. ``He went to the council to raise the issue,'' said his spokesman, Angelica Hunt. Nicaragua and the Sandinista government have been on edge since the Panama invasion, with the military on ``maximum alert'' and tanks rolling through Managua's streets amid gun emplacements. Then last week troops surrounded the U.S. Embassy in Managua with tanks and armored cars in retaliation for U.S. troops encircling the Nicaraguan and Cuban embassies in Panama City. U.S. military officials said they took the action to prevent deposed dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega and his henchmen from seeking asylum. The military cordon around the embassy in Managua was withdrawn, but last weekend the Sandinistas expelled 20 American diplomats in retaliation for an American military search of the Nicaraguan ambassador's residence in the Panamanian capital. President Bush called the search a ``screw-up,'' and the State Department said the Sandinistas were trying to shrink the U.S. mission to prevent it from monitoring the electoral process. Ortega promised the elections in return for the demobilization of the U.S.-backed Contras fighting the Sandinista government. On Thursday, President Ortega called for the ``immediate'' withdrawal of U.S. troops from Panama, saying their goal of capturing Noriega had been achieved.

DOC.HEAD: Mourners Told to Find Strength in Loss
DOC.TEXT: Two nuns slain in Nicaragua should be viewed as modern-day martyrs whose example can spur efforts for peace, a Roman Catholic leader said at the funeral for one of the victims. ``We feel a right to be angry at this senseless death, this loss of innocent human life,'' Milwaukee Archbishop Rembert Weakland told nearly 700 people attending Friday night's funeral for Sister Maureen Courtney, 45. But the deaths also provide ``the rare privilege of being witnesses to martyrs in our day, no less glorious than in the past. We can associate ourselves with those who gave totally of themselves for others,'' he said. ``If we are encouraged by their example ... to make this world a place of peace and love through the mutual service we give to one another, then senselessness will be turned into fullness of life,'' Weakland said. Sister Courtney, a Milwaukee native, and Sister Teresa Rosales, 24, of Nicaragua, both members of the Fond du Lac-based Sisters of St. Agnes, were killed Monday when their vehicle was attacked by assailants in northeastern Nicaragua. Auxiliary Bishop Pablo Schmitz of Bluefields, Nicaragua, a native of Fond du Lac, and Sister Francisca Colomer, 24, of Nicaragua were wounded in the attack. Sister Colomer, transported to Fond du Lac, was reported in fair condition at St. Agnes Hospital Friday night, being treated for multiple head wounds. Members of the Sisters of St. Agnes in Nicaragua said evidence at the scene indicates the ambush was carried out by U.S.-backed Contra rebels. The Marxist Nicaraguan government has blamed the ambush on the Contras, although a spokesman for the rebels Wednesday denied any involvement in the killings. Sister Courtney worked as a teacher in the United States before becoming a missionary in Nicaragua in 1978, where she helped establish clothing co-operatives and a medical center. About 20 Nicaraguan natives who have worked with the Sisters of St. Agnes sang a Spanish hymn, ``Pescador de Hombres,'' or ``Fisher of Men,'' and several prayers were said in Spanish. Burial was scheduled for today. Earlier Friday, nearly 300 friends and relatives attended a memorial service at Sister Courtney's home church in Milwaukee. They wept as a coffin draped in red roses was borne between two rows of women parishoners. The Rev. Tom Wittliff said Sister Courtney was a victim whose sacrifice would bring life to others. ``On that road in Nicaragua, whatever traps were set, whatever shots were shot, the spirit of Christ was being continued,'' he said. ``The world has enough of the military, it has enough clowns. What the world needs now is people who will give.''

DOC.HEAD: Shoes on Skeleton in Spring Back Town Legend
DOC.TEXT: Old Jess may just be more than legend. A skeleton wearing old shoes discovered in an underwater cave is believed by many to be the remains of Jess Preston, the subject of 50-year-old lore in this north Florida town. While investigators have yet to confirm an identity, they believe a tale of a man drowning in the spring may prove true, Sheriff Tom Tramel said Thursday. Two divers in ``Old Jess Hole'' near the Sante Fe River found the skeleton. Shoes found on the skeleton are about 50 years old, said Columbia County sheirff's Lt. Jim Wells. Some residents say the man disappeared near the spot where the skeleton was found. His coat was found nearby, and relatives and friends held a funeral service by the deep spring. Investigators are awaiting a report from forensic anthropologist William Maples. A preliminary report indicated the skeleton was that of a white male 5-foot-7 to 5-foot-8 who may have suffered from Down's snydrome or a related disease.

DOC.HEAD: 13 Charged In Death of Family
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor investigating the deaths of a five members of a family found buried under a muddy barn floor says the killings may have been human sacrifices. A grand jury indicted 13 people in the slayings. The grand jury, returning the indictments late Friday in Painesville, charged reputed religious cult leader Jeffrey Lundgren, his wife, son and 10 members of his group in the deaths of the family. Lake County Prosecutor Steven C. LaTourette said those indicted ``are not crazy. They are the coolest, most inhuman people this county has ever seen. They're going to die in the electric chair for these crimes.'' The five dead are believed to be Dennis Avery, 49; his wife, Cheryl, 42; and their three daughters, Trina, 15; Rebecca, 13; and Karen, 7. The Averys, found Wednesday and Thursday at Lundgren's Kirtland farm, apparently were killed because of Lundgren's religious concept and a prophecy, LaTourette said. ``Originally, this prophecy was that 10 of them had to die,'' said Latourette, who said members regarded killing as ``a cleansing execution.'' Seven of those charged were arrested in the Kansas City area by Friday afternoon, said George Rodriguez of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. Six others were being sought. ``We now have four people who have given us a full confession of their involvement,'' said Dave True, an ATF spokesman in Kansas City. The Averys apparently were targeted as victims because they were less active in the group than others, LaTourette said. ``The Averys were ... falling out of grace,'' he said. He said the Averys apparently never attempted to flee the communal farm, about 20 miles east of Cleveland. LaTourette said the Averys may have been killed over a ``relatively short period of time,'' April 16-18, but not ``en masse.'' While the bodies have yet to be positively identified, LaTourette said an informant confirmed the identities of the victims, and Kirtland Fire Chief Richard A. Martincic said a picture of the Avery family was found in the barn. Each of the victims was shot at least twice, according to an autopsy by Elizabeth Balraj, the coroner in neighboring Cuyahoga County. No federal charges were filed in the case, and Rodriguez said the defendants will be extradited to Ohio. Five of those in custody waived their right to fight extradition. Two other suspects face extradition hearings Monday. Rodriguez said the Averys were members of a splinter religious group led by Lundgren, a former lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints. Lundgren, 39, his wife, Alice, 38, and son, Damon, 19, were at large early today. Lundgren and Damon were charged with five counts of aggravated murder, and Mrs. Lundgren was charged with five counts of conspiracy to commit aggravated murder. Dave True, a spokesman for the ATF in Kansas City, said Lundgren was thought to be somewhere in Missouri. Lundgren left the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in 1988 after his ministry credentials were revoked and formed his own religious group, said Dale Luffman, president of the northeast Ohio chapter of the RLDS. The RLDS is separate from the Salt Lake City-based Mormon Church, or Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, though they share some beliefs. ``He was silenced for ethical reasons,'' Luffman said. ``He would have been expelled from the church on the basis of un-Christian conduct had he not withdrawn his membership.'' Also indicted on five counts of aggravated murder were Richard Eugene Brand, 26, of Independence, Mo.; Daniel David Kraft, no age given, of Navoo, Ill.; and Ronald Boyd Luff, 29, of Independence. The others indicted on charges of conspiracy and complicity to commit murder and kidnapping were Deborah Sue Oliverez, 47, of Independence; Dennis Simms Patrick, 35, of Independence; Sharon Jean Bluntschly, 31, of Independence; Gregory Scott Winship, 29, of Euclid, Ohio; Tonya J. Patrick, 33, of Independence; Susie Luff, 31, of Springfield, Mo., and Kathryn Johnson, 36 of Holden, Mo.

DOC.HEAD: After 68 Years, Ella Hoffman Can Hear
LaserPhoto BI1
DOC.TEXT: Ella Hoffmann danced for the first time at age 68 _ because she finally could hear the music. A cheerful woman who lives in a retirement home in this small central North Dakota community, Hoffman had been considered deaf since birth. But when she was being checked for a growth in her ear in early December, a specialist discovered she actually could hear with the help of a hearing aid. It was a magical moment. ``She looked at me and kind of smiled and giggled,'' audiologist Jon Richins recalled. Hoffmann, who has lived at the Pioneer Park Retirement Home since 1981, danced for the first time a week later, when a polka band came to entertain residents of the home. ``She kept time, and she danced. She could hear,'' said Helen Iverson, director of the home. ``It's unbelievable.'' Sitting in an armchair in her room at Pioneer Park, Hoffmann laughs a wheezy laugh and sways from side-to-side in a dancing motion when she's asked about that dance. Her speech unclear and she doesn't know sign language. But her smile says it all. Iverson calls her story a miracle. ``When she came to the home in 1981, I was told she was deaf,'' Iverson said. ``But at the same time, I understood she was sent to school in Minnesota somewhere where she was taught to read and write.'' Last fall, Hoffmann complained of a throbbing pain in her right ear by holding a clenched fist to her head and making a pounding motion, Iverson said. Unable to relieve the persistent pain, her doctor recommended she see a specialist in Bismarck, about 70 miles southeast of Hazen, a community of 3,300 people. At the Bismarck clinic, Richins asked Iverson if Hoffmann's hearing had ever been tested. Not to her knowledge, she said. ``He took her into a booth, put some headphones on her, and she raised her hand when she heard a sound,'' Iverson remembered. Richins then fitted Hoffmann with a hearing aid, ``and she was all smiles when the doctor turned up the sound,'' Iverson added. Richins was all smiles, too. ``When someone says they're deaf, I need to have proof,'' he said. ``There's more stories like this than I would care to admit _ people who have been diagnosed as autistic or placed in homes for the handicapped,'' Richins said. If children aren't developing appropriate speech and language skills at a young age, their hearing should be checked, he said. ``That's what should have happened with Ella years and years ago,'' Richins said. ``She was probably just lumped in with other people and assumed to be deaf.'' ``It's too bad it had to come so late in life,'' Walter Morast, a cousin and Ella's and Elsa's guardian, said of Ella's hearing aid. ``But why this was never done before, I don't really know,'' said Morast, who lives about three miles away from the farm where the Hoffmanns spent most of their lives. Nonetheless, Ella Hoffmann has a new life as she prepares to turn 69 later this month. ``She never came out (of her room) before for activities because she couldn't hear,'' Iverson said. ``Now she comes out all the time.'' Asked in a scrawled note whether she was angry at the thought of what she might have missed, Hoffmann shook her head ``No.''

DOC.HEAD: Long Battle Claims Woman Who Set Jarvik Record
DOC.TEXT: A woman who set a record for living the longest on an artificial heart before receiving a heart transplant has died of a heart attack brought on by her battle against infection. Carolyn Stadler, 57, of St. Charles died Friday at St. Louis University Hospital, where she had received two transplants, officials said. Stadler, the mother of four, lived 440 days on a Jarvik-7 artificial heart before receiving a heart transplant last fall. Hospital officials said Mrs. Stadler was kept alive by the Jarvik-7 after her body rejected a first donor heart given her June 30, 1988. She had been diagnosed as having idiopathic cardiomyopathy, a degenerative heart condition. She spent the last 1{ years at the hospital, where she showed ``an inner grace and faith'' that strengthened her family, her husband, Roger, said. Dr. Leslie Miller of the hospital's cardiology staff said Mrs. Stadler's case provided much-needed information about reaction to transplants. Women are more likely to reject heart transplants than men, Miller said. The Jarvik-7 artificial heart was developed by Robert Jarvik at the University of Utah School of Medicine in Salt Lake City. It is capable of replacing the function of both of the heart's pumping chambers, the right and the left ventricles, and is intended to keep a patient alive while awaiting a donor heart. William DeVries first implanted the Jarvik-7 in 1982 in Barney Clark, who survived for 112 days. Miller said at a Friday news conference that the federal government is examining artificial hearts as permanent devices. Approval for some hospitals to begin testing them as permanent heart replacements is expected within the next year, Miller said.

Nonetheless, Ella Hoffmann has a new life as she prepares to turn 69 later this month. ``She never came out (of her room) before for activities because she couldn't hear,'' Iverson said. ``Now she comes out all the time.'' Asked in a scrawled note whether she was angry at the thought of what she might have missed, Hoffmann shook her head ``No.''

DOC.HEAD: 25 Dairy Calves Bludgeoned to Death
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-five calves were bludgeoned to death at a dairy farm and the owners are at a loss about the motive. The killers apparently used heavy clubs or metal pipes to beat the 3-month-old calves to death and seriously injure several others in a corral at the Henry Pylman Dairy, authorities said Friday. ``It's got to be some kind of weirdo that would do something like this,'' said farmer Mike Pylman. ``Why would anyone want to kill these animals?'' The animals had an estimated value of $10,000. Authorities believe the slaughter took place late Wednesday night or early Thursday morning. ``I can tell you this about them,'' said the farm's veterinarian, Alyn McClure. ``There had to be more than one. They had to be very strong, and they were in some kind of killing frenzy.''

DOC.HEAD: Communist Rebels Say Killed Mayor, U.S. Servicemen Next Targets
DOC.TEXT: Communist guerrillas near a U.S. base today claimed responsibility for killing a mayor and said the next targets will be American servicemen and five more town officials fighting the insurgency. ``This is just the beginning,'' said Joema Garcia, who claims to be the communist New People's Army area chieftain. ``More liquidations will follow.'' Garcia said Mayor Javier Hizon of the town of Mexico, a few miles southeast of Angeles, was assassinated for leading the creation of anti-communist militia groups in his area. Hizon and a police escort were gunned down Friday outside the mayor's home as he departed for work. Angeles, in Pampanga province, is home of the U.S.-run Clark Air Base, about 50 miles north of Manila. Garcia said five other Pampanga mayors and American servicemen believed to be ``collaborating'' with the Philippine military would be killed. He said the killings would be in retaliation for setbacks suffered by Communist insurgents in the area last year. He declined to give the names of any targets. Military sources said government troops have killed 38 of the estimated 73 Communist guerrillas operating in the province during the last two years. Communist rebels are believed to have killed two American civilian employees of a U.S. installation near the Clark base last September and three other Americans in Angeles in October 1987. In Maguindanao province, government troops Friday killed six Moslem rebels belonging to a band of separatist insurgents who faked a surrender before ambushing two vehicles sent to pick them up, the military reported. Brig. Gen. Orlando Soriano, regional army commander, said the three-hour clash occurred in the town of Barira, 480 miles southeast of Manila. Soldiers recovered 15 firearms from the site, Soriano said. He said the slain guerrillas belonged to a band of 130 Moro National Liberation Front members who were allegedly surrendering to the government Wednesday but ambushed the trucks in the nearby village of Buldon. Three government representatives were killed but a fourth, a soldier, escaped unhurt to a nearby forest and managed to return to military headquarters to report the incident, the military said. Soriano said the attack was ``treachery of the highest degree.''

DOC.HEAD: Nine Chinese U.N. Staff Protesting Orders To Return Home, Claim Politics
DOC.TEXT: Nine Chinese U.N. employees are protesting orders to return home when their contracts expire and say their pro-democracy activities are being held against them, U.N. staff officials said. But U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliania said Friday the cases were examined and that the ``contracts cannot be renewed unless their government asks us to do so.'' The U.N. employees union has protested to Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar on their behalf and its officials have said they will support the Chinese if they seek political asylum. Some of the Chinese also protested the requirement that they turn over their paychecks to the Chinese Mission and receive a small monthly stipend _ a common practice among many communist countries at the United Nations. The complaint to the secretary-general was lodged by the U.N. Staff Committee President Lowell L. Flanders. Of the 12,338 U.N. staff employes in New York, Geneva and Vienna, about 275 are from China, Flanders said. The complaint concerns five employees in New York, two in Geneva and two in Vienna. They include typists, translators and Chinese language reporters. Yuan Shibing, counselor at the Chinese U.N. Mission, said Friday: ``Their contracts have expired and it is normal practice that they should go home because normally our people work in rotation.'' Although some of the Chinese employees took part in demonstrations against the crackdown on the pro-democracy movement last spring, Yuan said: ``It has nothing to do with that.'' Chinese troops killed hundreds, perhaps thousands, of people when soldiers marched on Beijing June 3-4 and crushed the student-led pro-democracy movement. Since then, there have been sympathy demonstrations, petitions and vigils by Chinese government employees overseas, including some at the United Nations.

DOC.HEAD: Wind, Snow in Northwest; Fog in Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Southerly winds with gusts to 60 mph moved on to the mountains of Idaho and Montana today after lashing the coasts of Oregon and Washington. Up to 8 inches of snow was expected in the Oregon Cascades before the winds continued across the northern states. Damp, cloudy weather was predicted today from the western Gulf states into the Southeast. Heavy fog was forecast for parts of the Florida Panhandle and southern Alabama today. Local advisories for fog also were posted along the central Gulf Coast and the Texas Gulf coast. The Midwest's partly cloudy skies and above-normal temperatures were expected to continue through the weekend. The New England forecast called for snow in the mountains and colder weather today, with temperatures below zero expected in northern Maine. Cloudy, wet weather was predicted to make its way into the Northeast from the Gulf Coast later in the weekend, bringing the threat of rain or snow late Sunday and early Monday. Snow continued to fall along the shore of Lake Superior. There were some warm and sunny spots Friday. Record high temperatures for Jan. 5 were set in Miami, at 83, and in Seattle-Tacoma, Wash., 54.
