DOC.HEAD: Judge: Former Beatle Owes Musician Recording Costs
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled that Ringo Starr must pay a musician more than $74,000 to cover recording costs for a record album the former Beatle wanted to silence. Superior Court Judge Clarence Cooper, who issued a permanent injunction in November preventing produer Chips Moman's company from releasing the 1987 album, ruled that Starr must pay Moman $74,354 to cover costs of the recording sessions, and 7 percent interest. Starr contended he was under the influence of alcohol at the time the album was recorded and said he wasn't satisfied with the results after listening to the tapes. He sued Moman and his CRS Records of College Park, Ga., to block the album's release. The album included some new material along with some older songs, such as ``I Can Help'' and ``Ain't That a Shame.'' At the non-jury trial in November, Moman testified that Bob Dylan made a guest appearance on one song. An attorney for Starr, Robert Fleming Jr., said Friday he yet to see the ruling but indicated he was satisfied with it as he understood it. Moman had contended that Starr owed him $146,239. Tom Washburn III, Moman's attorney, said he hadn't seen the new ruling, but added, ``If it is as I understand it to be, then what the court has done for some unknown reason is partially enforce the agreement.'' If so, Washburn said, he plans to appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I hope that good will triumph over evil.'' _ Felicidad Fiero Noriega defending her husband, Manuel, the ousted Panamanian dictator, saying he has been wrongly charged with drug trafficking and unfairly portrayed by the U.S. media.
``Go shopping, rake leaves ... ignore it.'' _ Atlanta Mayor Maynard Jackson's advice to civil-rights activists on how to handle a Ku Klux Klan rally planned at the state Capitol.

``I feel that if the people hadn't stood up and showed their displeasure with the system, then we'd have had the problem Rochester did. We dodged a bullet.'' _ Frank Harmer, police chief of Delhi, N.Y., one of three towns who objected to the relocation of Arthur Shawcross, a child killer who was paroled in 1987 and who is now charged with killing eight women in the Rochester area, where he eventually settled.

DOC.HEAD: KKK Can't Protest King Birthday in its Birthplace
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled that the small town where the Ku Klux Klan was born enacted a mostly unconstitutional set of ordinances aimed at blocking KKK marches, but he upheld one part that spoils a planned protest. U.S. District Judge John T. Nixon on Friday said most of Pulaski's parade ordinances were an unconstitutional abridgement of free speech. But he said the limit of one parade per day in the town of 8,000 was reasonable. On Jan. 13, when the KKK wanted to march in Pulaski to protest the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, another group beat the Klan in signing up first to march. The KKK will instead demonstrate on the date in Lawrenceburg. The towns are 25 miles apart and south of Nashville, near the Alabama line. The holiday honoring the civil rights leader, slain in Memphis in 1968, will be observed Jan. 15. ``He struck practically all parts of the ordinance except the one that we were interested in,'' Thom Robb, national director of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, told a news conference after the hearing. The judge struck down provisions of the Pulaski ordinance that barred parade permits to those advocating violence to people based on race, national origin or religion and to those wearing masks or disguises. Pulaski is the birthplace of the original KKK in the late 19th century. Residents say they are tired of the distinction. The parade-limiting ordinance was passed following an October march by members of a white supremacy group, The Aryan Nations. The KKK has marched in Pulaski to protest the King holiday for the past three years and Robb said up to 400 people might take part in this year's march. Robb said the Klan would parade in Pulaski in February, possibly on other dates in January and throughout the year. George Barrett, a Nashville lawyer arguing on behalf of the American Civil Liberties Union, reminded Nixon that the ordinance restricting parades was similar to laws enacted 25 years ago to try to thwart civil rights marches, including those led by King. ``The best way to honor Dr. King is to vindicate the First Amendment,'' Barrett said. ``Vindication of the First Amendment is the legacy of Dr. King.'' Of the judge's ruling from the bench, Barrett said, ``I'm very pleased. I think the basic thrust of the lawsuit was the unconstitutionality of the ordinance. I don't think it was a victory for the Klan or a defeat for the good people of Giles County.''

DOC.HEAD: More Former Re-Education Camp Inmates Leave Vietnam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with more arrivals. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `The Vietnamese will...'
DOC.TEXT: More former re-education camp inmates and relatives arrived here today from Vietnam en route to new lives in the United States, whose forces they fought alongside during the Vietnam War. It was the second day of the first major resettlement of people who were imprisoned because they served the U.S.-backed South Vietnam government that communist forces toppled in April 1975. A total of 151 former inmates and their families arrived in Bangkok this n morning and afternoon charter flights from Ho Chi Minh City, said Komol Srinakul of the International Organization for Migration. The agency handles medical processing and transportation of the refugees. On Friday, 156 arrived. The Vietnamese will join relatives in California and other states after a few days at a Thai immigration center. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Friday the administration hopes at least 7,000 former detainees and their relatives will be resettled by Sept. 30. Those who arrived in Bangkok Friday expressed joy at finally reaching ``the free world'' after many years of internment and waiting. Some described conditions in the Vietnamese camps as very bad, and one claimed he saw guards shoot dead 25 prisoners who tried to flee. They said Vietnamese citizens were watching closely the pro-democracy movements in Eastern Europe and hoped the revolution would come to their country. The agreement on resettling former inmates was reached between Hanoi and Washington in July. The U.S. negotiator, senior State Department official Robert L. Funseth, said at the time it would help heal ``the last big wound remaining from the war.'' Hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese were subjected for years to a spartan regimen of manual labor and political study after the fall of the South Vietnamese government. One of the thousands headed for the United States is P. Nguyen's brother-in-law, who was interned for 12 years. ``He's coming next month,'' Nguyen, of Los Angeles, said Friday. ``We prayed for him every year. This is a dream come true. My sister who is here is very happy. He's coming home to his children. ``Tomorrow is my nephew's birthday and his birthday gift will be his father coming home.'' Nguyen said he and some of his relatives were ``lucky enough to escape from Vietnam in 1975.'' According to a U.S. source in Bangkok, Washington believes about 100,000 former camp inmates are among the 600,000 Vietnamese who have applied to emigrate to the United States. He said Hanoi estimates former inmates and their families total 550,000 people. Vietnam has freed hundreds of the prisoners in recent years, and in June, Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach said only about 120 people remained interned. Hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese have been resettled in the United States since the war, but political bickering had hindered progress on emigration of the former inmates. The two countries still do not have diplomatic relations, mainly because the United States has opposed Vietnam's 1978 invasion of Cambodia.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Escapes Injury After Plane Crashes During Takeoff
DOC.TEXT: Actor James Brolin narrowly escaped unhurt when the single-engine airplane he was piloting crashed during takeoff and burst into flames, a sheriff's spokesman said. A strong gust of wind on Friday afternoon blew the plane off the runway and down an embankment, said Sgt. Ernie Roop of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department. Brolin, 49, escaped ``moments before the plane burst into flames,'' Roop said. He was alone on the four-seat Cessna 182 when the accident occurred at Agua Dulce Airport in Saugus, 33 miles northwest of Los Angeles. The plane was destroyed by fire. The National Transportation Safety Board will investigate the accident, according to a Federal Aviation Administration regional duty officer who declined to give his name. Brolin is best known for his role as the apprentice to Robert Young in the prime-time television series, ``Marcus Welby M.D.'' He won an Emmy Award in 1970 for the role. He also has starred in the television drama ``Hotel'' and has appeared in several films, including ``Pee Wee's Big Adventure'' and ``The Amityville Horror.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Says Rebels Killed More Than 200
DOC.NOTE: Eds: FIXES garble in byline and SUBS last graf to CORRECT to 1847 sted 1947; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Liberian army commander said ``armed dissidents'' who entered northeastern Liberia nearly two weeks ago killed more than 200 civilians, including seven people praying at a mosque, radio reported. Brig. Gen. Edward Smith, army commander in embattled Nimba county, reported the civilian casualties Friday when he briefed President Samuel K. Doe on the situation, according to the independent evangelical station Radio Elwa, based in Monrovia. The radio quoted Smith as saying that in one border town seven people had been shot and killed as they were praying in a mosque. He apparently did not give details of the other civilian deaths, but said only one Liberian soldier was killed in the fighting. Smith said a few of the dissidents remained on the run ``sporadically attacking civilians in the forest areas of Nimba,'' but that Liberia's forces were bringing the situation under control and had driven the rebels from Butuo, a border town. The radio broadcast, monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp., did not say whether Smith and Doe discussed the number of Liberians who reportedly have fled into neighboring Ivory Coast to escape the violence. Diplomats have said it is difficult to determine the number of Liberians fleeing because the border area is heavily forested and communications are poor. However, some reports have put the figure as high as 10,000. Smith also displayed identity cards he said were taken from the dissidents in the fight, three of which he claimed showed that some of the rebels were Ivorian nationals, the radio said. Liberia repeatedly has accused Ivory Coast of harboring Doe's opponents, a charge the Ivorians deny. Justice Minister Jenkin Scott said Tuesday the invaders, whose numbers he put at 96, had been trained in Burkina Faso and Libya. Burkina Faso has denied the claim. The fighting erupted Dec. 24 when, Liberia says, two groups of rebels entered the country from Ivory Coast intent on overthrowing Doe. Doe said it was the fifth time in his 10-year rule that dissidents have tried to infiltrate from Ivory Coast. The dissidents, led by Charles Taylor, a former civil servant in Doe's government, call themselves the National Patriotic Front and appear to have no connection with Liberia's opposition parties, according to diplomats. Officials of the United People's Party, the largest opposition group in Liberia, have condemned the invaders for using unconstitutional methods against the government. Doe is a pro-Western former military officer who runs Liberia on a free-market economy. The former sergeant major seized power in a bloody April 1980 coup in which President William Tolbert, a descendant of freed American slaves, and most of his political allies were killed. Liberia was founded by freed American slaves in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Twins Who Posed for Playboy Plead Innocent to Tax Evation Charges
DOC.TEXT: Twins who were Playboy magazine models pleaded innocent to charges that they evaded taxes on about $1 million they allegedly received from an elderly businessman. The government claims that Leigh Ann Conley and Lynette Harris, 35, failed to pay taxes on money they received from Shorewood businessman David Kritzik, who died in June at the age of 89. The twins entered innocent pleas Friday. Harris claims she was the elderly millionaire's mistress and that the money she received was a gift and thus not reportable as income. She has said her sister received cash gifts from Kritzik to compensate her for lost income. The twins appeared together in two films and in Playboy in 1978 and 1981. Harris says their joint movie careers were sidelined by her seven-year, full-time relationship with Kritzik. The government charges that the money, which ranged from $60,000 to $257,000 per year from 1984 to 1987, represented direct payments for services and could not be construed as gifts. Harris, formerly of Arlington, Texas, and now of Mukwonago, is charged with two counts of tax evasion and two counts of failure to file federal income tax returns. If convicted, she could face a maximum prison sentence of 12 years and fines totaling $625,000. Conley, of the Milwaukee suburb of Glendale, is charged with four counts of failure to file income taxes. She could be sentenced to as many as four years and fined as much as $325,000 if convicted on the charges. Harris, who was not named in Kritzik's will, has filed a $5 million claim in Probate Court against his estate. David Kritzik was a mail-order merchandiser who founded General Merchandising Co. It was sold in 1962 to the JC Penney Co. for $11 million. U.S. Magistrate Aaron E. Goodstein allowed the pair to remain free on $20,000 recognizance bonds. He ordered them to report to the federal probation and parole office here biweekly. A jury trial was set for March 5 before Federal Judge Thomas J. Curran.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Arrives for Talks, Moldavia and Aid High on Agenda
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with talks under way, tight security. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `In an...'
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze today held his country's first talks with the interim government that ousted and executed Nicolae Ceausescu, and the agenda was expected to include stronger economic ties. The common border that divides Romanians from their ethnic brethren in Soviet Moldavia also was expected to be a topic. Shevardnadze was welcomed at Otopeni airport by Foreign Minister Sergiu Celac and other Romanian officials, the state-run Rompres news agency reported. Shevardnadze met soon after with Ion Iliescu, president of the ruling National Salvation Front Council, Rompres said. The talks were held behind closed doors and no details were disclosed. Security was tightened in Bucharest to protect the prominent Soviet visitor. Soldiers lined the streets from the Soviet Embassy to the airport, a 20-minute ride, and tanks and armored personnel carriers were positioned at the airport as Shevardnadze arrived. Unlike other East European movements toward democracy, Romania's revolution last month strengthened rather than weakened ties with Moscow, strained for decades by Ceausescu's maverick foreign and trade policies and further hurt by his resistance to the reforms of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Shevardnadze's trip will be a brief, one-day affair. But Silviu Brucan, a foreign policy expert in the leadership of the National Salvation Front running Romania, has said Bucharest's new government has high hopes for the trip. Moscow already has pledged aid, including natural gas and oil supplies to ensure that Romania's 23 million citizens get adequate heat and light, both strictly rationed during the past eight winters by Ceausescu. In an interview with Bucharest radio broadcast Friday, Shevardnadze said the Romanian revolution ``has enormous significance for the interests of Europe and has an echo which can justifiably be considered as universal, important for the entire world.'' One touchy issue likely to be on the agenda is relations with Soviet Moldavia, which consists largely of territory annexed from Romania by Josef Stalin in 1940 under a secret protocol to the Hitler-Stalin pact. Many Moldavians pushing for more autonomy from Moscow hope Romania's revolution will open one of Eastern Europe's most tightly closed borders and boost cultural and other exchanges severely restricted in the past. On economic matters, Lt. Gen. Victor Stanculescu, who is in charge of the economy for the Front, said in an interview published Friday that some trading partners agreed to accept exports of industrial products instead of food. He did not name the countries, but food has been one of Romania's exports to the Soviet Union. Ceausescu, the hard-line Communist dictator ousted Dec. 22 and executed with his wife Elena on Christmas Day, exported vast quantities of food, especially meat, to the Soviet Union to ensure energy supplies from Moscow. But he used most of them for his pet industrial projects, imposing strict rationing that forced Romanians to wear thick coats in their homes and offices in winter, and had opera orchestras playing in gloves and fur hats. The new government has overturned the energy restrictions and many of Ceausescu's most unpopular decrees, abolishing the death penalty, promising free travel and releasing political prisoners and others under a general amnesty for those jailed for less than five years. The National Salvation Front also has promised to unveil a new election law by the end of January and hold free elections by April. But there is mounting concern that the Front, which reversed an earlier decision not to contest the elections, will have an unfair advantage at the polls because of its control of the media and high profile as the interim government. Western politicians visiting Bucharest Friday called for international monitoring to ensure that any elections staged would be fair. U.S. Rep. Frank Wolf, R-Va., said other fledgling parties hoping to contest the elections lacked the ``tools of democracy'' and called for a national referendum in April on when to hold general elections. Otto Lambsdorff, the former West German Economics Minister who came to Bucharest Thursday to discuss economic aid, also said the Front could be privileged in elections. ``It would perhaps be necessary to assure international supervision for the results of the elections to be completely fair,'' Lambsdorff told a news conference. The half-dozen political parties in the two weeks since Ceausescu was ousted have argued that they lack even such basic resources as typewriters, which under Ceausescu had to be registered so the government could trace dissident documents. They want the elections postponed until the second half of 1990, when Romania will be one of five Warsaw Pact countries holding the first free elections since Stalin decreed in the late 1940s that Communist parties should take over in all the East European countries liberated by the Soviets at the end of World War II.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Calls For Protests At Hungarian Properties Abroad
DOC.TEXT: The guerrilla-backed African National Congress today called on supporters to demonstrate outside Hungarian embassies in protest of contacts between South Africa's white-led government and Hungary's new rulers. ANC Secretary General Alfred Nzo said international pressure also was needed to halt South African efforts to recruit skilled immigrants from Hungary and other East European nations. The recruitment drive was intended to give ``a longer lease of life'' to the apartheid system of racial segregation, Nzo told the semi-official Zimbabwe Inter African News Agency. ``The action must be stopped in its tracks,'' he said. Demonstrators ``must show the new rulers in Hungary that what they have done in a counter-revolution,'' the exiled black South African guerrilla leader added. Nzo was in transit in Harare on his way from Mozambique to the ANC external headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia. On Thursday, South African Foreign Minister Roelof ``Pik'' Botha ended a two-day visit to Budapest, during which he held talks with his Hungarian counterpart, Gyula Horn. The first known visit by a senior South African official to a Warsaw Pact country drew sharp criticism from Hungarian democratic opposition groups, the ANC and anti-apartheid activists in South Africa. Nzo told Ziana today the ANC will soon send officials to unspecified East European capitals to assess political changes there. The ANC, the main guerrilla organization fighting in South Africa, traditionally has received the bulk of its diplomatic and material aid from the Soviet Union and Warsaw Pact governments. On Friday Botha said upon his return from Hungary that his country hopes to establish diplomatic ties with the Budapest government. He told reporters at Johannesburg's airport that the two countries will investigate possible cooperation in trade, industrial development and tourism. He said South Africans could now travel to Hungary ``without any problem.'' Botha also said his government wanted Eastern Europeans to come to South Africa to ease a labor shortage in skilled jobs. Anti-apartheid groups say South Africa should be training blacks for the jobs, not wooing white immigrants.

DOC.HEAD: Angry Crowd At Beach Frees Two Suspects, Stones Police
DOC.TEXT: Two men arrested for fighting in a beachfront children's wading pool were freed by hundreds of angry blacks who pelted police with stones and bottles, a police spokesman said today. The incident occurred Friday in the resort city of Durban and was one of the worst confrontations since President F.W. de Klerk's proclamation late last month that formerly segregated beaches would be open to all races. Lt. Bala Naidoo, a police spokesman in Durban, said a unit of seven white and Indian policemen was charged by 1,000 blacks after officers arrested two black men who had been fighting in a wading pool intended for use by children. One officer was injured on the hand by a thrown bottle, Naidoo said. According to Naidoo, the officers decided not to fire their guns for fear of inciting a full-scale riot. Prior to the incident, authorities had reported few racial confrontations during the Christmas and New Year's holidays despite huge crowds at beaches around Durban and Cape Town. In both areas, there had been some whites-only beaches until de Klerk's proclamation. A white Durban businessman, Norman Loubscher, said Friday he had collected 3,000 signatures on a petition calling for re-segregation of some local beaches. Loubscher contended that the large influx of blacks has led to a ``dirty, crowded mess'' along the shore. Police headquarters, in its daily report today on unrest during the last 24 hours, said a black man was shot and killed by police in the eastern Cape Province town of Molteno when he charged at officers with a hatchet during a confrontation. In Shongweni, a black township near the Natal Province city of Pietermaritzburg, a woman was burned to death by a mob, police said. Rival black political factions in the area have been feuding violently for three years.

DOC.HEAD: Switchman Arrested In Connection With Pakistani Rail Disaster
DOC.TEXT: Police have arrested a switchman in connection with Pakistan's worst rail disaster in which 307 people were killed and 700 injured when two trains collided in a station, officials said today. Army and civilian medical spokesmen said about 345 people remained hospitalized, 98 in critical or serious condition, following the collision between a passenger train and a freight train. They said there were no foreigners among the victims. Railway spokesmen said an improperly-set switch apparently sent an express train loaded with sleeping passengers crashing into a standing freight train early Thursday at the rural Sangi station. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said immediately after the crash: ``The possibility of sabotage cannot be ruled out.'' Two investigations were opened. The switchman, who worked at the station where the crash occurred, was arrested Friday and was being questioned, authorities said. Another switchman and the station master, both of whom fled after the crash, were still at large. Authorities issued warrants for their arrest.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Proposes 50 Percent Troop Cuts; Honecker Too Ill for Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 19 grafs to UPDATE with Communists urging troop cuts, foreign troop withdrawal. Pickup 11th graf, `Gerda Hasselfeldt...' TRIMS to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Communist Party today proposed that both German states cut their armies in half this year and undertake other drastic measures to demilitarize Central Europe. Party leader Gregor Gysi also proposed that all foreign troops be phased out of the two Germanys by 1999, according to the official ADN news agency, which reported on a special meeting of the Communist Party leadership. Communists retain control of the interim East German government pending free elections in May, and the call for sweeping disarmament measures is probably aimed at strengthening the party's image as the political force most capable of reshaping the nation. Cutting defense expenditures would free up state funds for restructuring industry, pulling East Germany out of its economic morass. Gysi urged cutting the West German and East German armies by 50 percent by next year and said both nations should agree not to modernize or expand their weapons arsenals. West Germany's army stands at 480,000, and there are 250,000 American soldiers on its soil; East Germany has an army of 170,000, backed by 400,000 Soviet troops. West Germany's readiness to go along with such measures probably would be restricted by its commitments to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which depends on West Germany as its defensive front line against the Warsaw Pact. But as East Germany and West Germany have closed the gap in their relations in recent months, the role of the two military alliances has come into question, and experts have predicted they could eventually be dissolved as Europe's post-war divides are healed. The military policy expert in West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's political party has proposed establishment of a ``European Security Union'' to protect the peace in a united Europe. In an article to appear Sunday in the Hamburg-based Bild am Sonntag, Otto Hauser proposes a military force independent of Washington and Moscow, which he told the newspaper would serve as ``guarantor powers'' for a new peace order on the continent. On Friday, East German media indicated that former leader Erich Honecker, ousted from power, expelled from the Communist Party and bedridden with illness, may be spared imprisonment. An independent medical team determined Friday that Honecker is in too poor condition to sustain the rigors of prison life and may need additional surgery to remove a malignant kidney tumor. The official ADN news agency said Honecker was checked by doctors sent by a special parliamentary committee investigating alleged widespread corruption during Honecker's rule. Seven former Communist Party Politburo members have been jailed pending investigation of charges they abused their power and bilked the nation of billions in hard currency. The 77-year-old Honecker, ousted on Oct. 18, is reported to be seriously ailing and confined to bed at the Wandlitz estate where he and other party elite indulged daily in luxuries while the rest of the nation endured spartan living conditions. He underwent surgery in August to remove gallstones and never fully recovered, East German media have said. Honecker was placed under house arrest more than a month ago after corruption charges were filed against him. ADN said Thursday the house arrest was lifted several weeks earlier. Honecker must be moved from Wandlitz by the end of the month because the estate is being converted to a facility for the handicapped. Meanwhile, West Germany's construction minister announced Friday that Bonn will provide aid of $4 billion to renovate crumbling cities and rebuild housing in East Germany to ease the acute shortage of living space in both nations. Gerda Hasselfeldt and her East German counterpart, Minister for Construction and Housing Gerhard Baumgaertel, told a news conference that four seriously deteriorated East German cities will be rebuilt as a pilot project for cooperation. The first beneficiaries will be Meissen _ the Elbe River city near Dresden famed for its hand-made porcelain, the former political and cultural center of Weimar, Brandenburg and Stralsund. Those cities, and many other urban areas of East Germany, require major restoration following damage to buildings during World War II, general neglect under a communist system that gave priority to industry over living conditions and the devastating effects of the brown-coal haze choking major cities. ``It is my hope that by pursuing all means of improving housing and construction in this country, that our housing market can be eased as well,'' Ms. Hasselfeldt said. East Germany suffers a serious housing shortage because many residential buildings are unfit for habitation. West Germany's housing problem is due more to a lack of space and the prohibitively high costs of construction against uncertain returns in a nation where rent control often limits a landlord's profit-making ability.

DOC.HEAD: Ian Horvath, Co-Founder of the Cleveland Ballet, Dead at 46
DOC.TEXT: Ian ``Ernie'' Horvath, co-founder of the Cleveland Ballet and once a soloist with the Joffrey Ballet and the American Ballet Theater, has died of complications from AIDS. He was 46. Horvath, a native of Cleveland, died Friday of pneumonia at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. Horvath's career spanned nearly three decades and encompassed a broad spectrum of artistic activities. He was an artistic consultant, administrator and fund-raiser for several dance companies and foundations, including the National Endowment for the Arts. He also was a dancer, choreographer and teacher who formed Cleveland's ballet company and its school with fellow dancer Dennis Nahat. Horvath spent much of his last years reviving interest in the repertory of choreographer Jose Limon. ``He knew so much about the field,'' said Rick Reynolds, managing director of the Jose Limon Dance Foundation. Reynolds said Horvath, the foundation's producing director since 1987, ``was able to communicate artistic ideas and necessities to people who didn't know (much) about the arts. In that way, he was unique.'' Horvath left the Cleveland Ballet in 1984 and did free-lance choreography and consulted for dance companies. He became a soloist with the Joffrey in 1964. Horvath left the Joffrey in 1967 for the American Ballet Theater, where he danced principal roles in a variety of classical and contemporary ballets choreographed by George Balanchine, Jerome Robbins and Agnes de Mille. He also appeared on Broadway in ``Funny Girl'' and ``Sweet Charity'' in the mid-1960s. While dancing with the ABT, he worked as assistant choreographer for the Royal Swedish Ballet and London Ballet, for which he prepared performances of several Nahat ballets. Horvath returned to Cleveland in 1972, establishing the Cleveland Dance Center ballet school with Nahat and Charles Hicoll, his former teacher. Horvath and Nahat started the Cleveland Ballet as a professional company in 1976. Horvath served as artistic director until 1984. Horvath began choreographing in 1974, and based his last piece, ``No Dominion,'' on his illness. Horvath sometimes served as a spokesman for people with AIDS. He helped organize ``Dancing For Life,'' an AIDS fund raiser at the New York State Theater in September 1987 and appeared in a television program on AIDS made in October 1988. During his month-long hospitalization before his death, Horvath was ``concerned about other people more than himself,'' said his brother, Jim Horvath. ``He fought all the way to the end.'' In addition to his brother, he is survived by his parents, Ernest and Helen, a sister, Debbie Zimmer, all of Tucson, Ariz., and his long-time companion, Rodger Barrow of New York City.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed in Beirut Shelling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf pvs, `Both sides...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with fighting resuming, Green Line crossing closed. Pickup 6th, `A police...'
DOC.TEXT: Christian army units and Syrian-backed Moslem militiamen exchanged artillery and tank fire across Beirut's dividing Green Line today, the first serious fighting in the civil war in three months. Police said two civilians were killed when an artillery shell crashed into the Sinn el-Fil residential area, on the Christian side of the three-mile sectarian line. Two other people were wounded in the exchanges that engulfed the neraby Sodeco and Ras el-Nabaa districts. The morning clash followed the arrival of President Elias Hrawi in Syrian-policed west Beirut. He moved into an apartment building where he will live and have an office. He did so to avoid having to commute to work in an area where his predecessor was killed by a car bomb in November. Thunderous shell blasts and staccato bursts of gunfire echoed across the Moslem and Christian sectors of the divided capital. Both sides accused each other of shooting first. The fighting eased at noon, then resumed in the afternoon, forcing police and army units to close the Green Line's mid-city Museum Crossing, the only gateway linking the two halves of the divided capital. A police spokesman said the fighting was ``the gravest violation'' of a cease-fire called by the Arab League on Sept. 22 to halt six months of savage artillery duels between the Syrian army and troops loyal to the Christian leader, Gen. Michel Aoun. At least 929 people were killed and 2,744 wounded during that six-month confrontation. Fighting also raged into a third week in south Lebanon between militiamen of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the pro-Syrian mainstream Amal. But police said no new casualties were reported in the inter-Shiite battles today. At least 77 people have been killed and 275 wounded since fighting flared between the two factions on Dec. 23. Amal and Hezbollah have been vying for two years for mastery of the 1.2 million Shiites who make up the country's largest sect. After moving into the apartment building in Ramlet al-Baida, Hrawi received the credentials of papal nuncio Pablo Puente. That reflected the Vatican's recognition of his government as the legitmate adminstration. The move totally isolates Aoun, who has rejected both Hrawi's election and the peace plan Parliament approved in October. All other foreign countries with diplomatic missions in Lebanon have already recognized the ``national reconciliation'' government formed in November to oversee implementation of a Christian-Moslem peace plan to end 14 years of civil war. Aoun, a Maronite Catholic, called on supporters to stage a ``human chain of demonstrations'' today along the 25-mile route from the presidential palace in Baabda to Puente's residence in Harissa to protest the Vatican's decision. Aoun commands 20,000 mainly Christian troops who control the Christian enclave in east Beirut and the hinterland to the north and northeast. Hrawi, also a Maronite, fired Aoun as army commander and caretaker prime minister in November. But the general remained entrenched in the presidential palace, refusing to turn over the traditional seat of heads of state to Hrawi. Aoun had issued a decree on Nov. 4 dissolving the 99-seat Parliament which approved the Lebanon peace accord despite his opposition. He called for elections on Jan. 7, an issue which would cement the paritition of the country. But the three-man Cabinet he heads decided Friday to postpone the elections for a month and send an envoy in the meantime to New York to request that the United Nations send observers to supervise elections on Feb. 7. With 40,000 Syrian troops controlling 70 percent of the country, and Israel occupying a 328-square-mile enclave in the south, the chances of holding general elections remain remote. The United Nations, which has voiced support for Hrawi, also is unlikely to endorse a request for observers from Aoun.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader's Meeting Plans Reported after Cancellations Cause Market Woes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 11-12, `KGB troops ...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with details on border clash. Pickup 13th graf, `A new ...'
DOC.TEXT: Radio Moscow said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has not canceled all January meetings with foreigners to deal with domestic problems, contrary to earlier reports that upset world financial markets. The radio report said Gorbachev still planned to meet with U.N. chief Javier Perez de Cuellar during the week of Jan. 15. In Tokyo, an official of the governing Liberal Democratic Party said today that former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe received an invitation to meet with Gorbachev on Jan. 15. Tokyo and Hong Kong markets declined and New York trading was upset Friday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 22.83 points, after a British Labor Party spokesman said Gorbachev canceled his meeting with opposition leader Neil Kinnock set for Jan. 16. The message to Kinnock explaining the cancellation said the Soviet leader was ``postponing contact with foreign politicians scheduled for January'' to deal with domestic problems. A top Communist Party official in Moscow confirmed that Gorbachev had canceled appointments with Kinnock and other foreigners. Abe, an influential member of Japan's Liberal Democratic Party, originally hoped to meet with Gorbachev in December, said party spokesman Iwao Kon. He said Abe received word of the January meeting from the Central Committee of the Communist Party through Japan's Embassy in Moscow on Friday night. Gorbachev is reportedly planning to spend three days next week in Lithuania, where the local Communist Party has split from the Soviet party and adopted a program favoring independence for the Baltic republic. Gorbachev also is concerned with violence in the south. KGB troops were rushed to the Soviet-Iranian frontier this week after Soviet Azerbaijanis tried to force open the frontier and reunite with their ethnic brethren in Iran. Fences remain flattened and other barriers out of commission along the border, Soviet TV reported Friday night. Protesters reportedly caused $4.9 million in damage. Interfax, a news service of Radio Moscow, said today the violence was caused by Azerbaijanis unhappy with delays in plans to expand border trade, cultural exchanges and meetings of relatives divided by the border. By the time an ultimatum expired on New Year's Eve, the border zone was occupied by protesters living in tents, and authorities found 300 Molotov cocktails and hunting guns, the newspaper Arguments and Facts said today. When negotiations collapsed on New Year's Day, 9,000 people rioted along an 85-mile stretch of the border from the Soviet side, and 800 people from the Iranian side joined them, the newspaper said. A new Communist Party chief was named for the area, the republic's official news agency, Azerinform, said today. Afedin Dzhalilov was named party first secretary of Nakhichevan to replace Gaidar Isayev, who retired because of a lengthy illness, the agency said. Meanwhile, officials in Agdam near the long-troubled district of Nagorno-Karabakh played down a report from the People's Front of Azerbaijan that Armenian extremists were responsible for the explosion of the Agdam bus station early this morning that left two people missing. A deputy police chief in Agdam said a preliminary investigation indicated the blast was caused by a nearby gas pipeline. Nagorno-Karabakh has been torn by ethnic violence between Armenians and Azerbaijanis for two years. Armenians, who make up most of the population, want the area transferred from the jurisdiction of Azerbaijan to Armenia.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeking to Mend Panama's Economy, US Relations with Latin America
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.NOTE: EDs: To update with Cheney remarks on CNN program, INSERTS three grafs after 5th graf bgng ``Recommendations have ... ''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is sending Vice President Dan Quayle on a mission of ``very, very important diplomacy'' to repair relations with Latin nations, as he vows he is ``not seeking a deal'' with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Bush said he will dispatch Quayle to reverse the negative reaction to the military invasion of Panama, which was roundly deplored in Central and South America. The president, during a White House news conference Friday, also said the reconstruction of Panama's economy will be a ``major priority'' for his administration. It was learned Friday that the administration is considering a range of possibilities to help the ravaged country, including: new housing for people left homeless; helping Panama pay its $543 million in foreign debt; getting other nations involved in the recovery effort; and facilitating loans for businesses. Recommendations have yet to be drawn up and presented to Bush, but one administration source said, ``There's a sense of urgency and we want to move quickly and respond quickly.''
DOC.HEAD: Following for release at 12:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: In another development, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the Panama invasion should not be viewed as heralding a new ``Bush doctrine'' under which the United States would be inclined to intervene militarily in other countries where democratic elections are subverted. Appearing on Cable News Network's ``Evans and Novak'' program, Cheney was asked specifically about what the United States would do if elections scheduled for February in Nicaragua are ``stolen'' by the ruling Sandinista regime. Cheney responded that the Panama action ``is not the beginning of the new Bush doctrine, where under every circumstance we would always use military force to intervene in order to enforce, if you will, the outcome of a free electoral process.''
DOC.HEAD: End embargoed material
DOC.TEXT: At Friday's news conference, the president did not rule out a plea bargain with Noriega in exchange for intelligence information the deposed dictator might offer on drug trafficking. ``Our government is not seeking a deal with Noriega,'' Bush told reporters following his meeting with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to discuss the drug-trafficking indictment against Noriega. However, when asked if he was ruling out the possibility of a plea bargain, he replied only, ``I`m not ruling it in.'' ``I'm just saying he's got his rights and .. we ought not to stand up here and try to define narrowly what they are,'' he added, leaving open the possibility that Noriega might seek the plea bargain. In Miami, Noriega attorney Steven Kollin said Noriega wasn't interested in a plea bargain because he considers himself innocent. Bush said he would ``bend over backwards'' not to make any comments that would prejudice the case against Noriega. With Noriega finally in U.S. custody, the president is turning his attention to shoring up relations in the Latin world. Quayle's itinerary is not yet determined, nor is the timetable for his trip, but he will visit countries in both Central and South America, said his press secretary, David Beckwith. Acknowledging the negative reaction by the Latins to his Dec. 20 invasion of Panama, Bush said: ``I am concerned, because I am well aware of how our friends south of our border ... look at the use of American force anywhere.'' He said that damage is ``correctable.'' An administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Bush is considering a trip to Panama. But the president said he had ``no plans'' for such a trip. Panama could be a stop on Quayle's trip. Bush did not say how much he might spend to help Panama recover but some estimates of invasion-related damage have been up to $2 billion. One administration official said is it likely the March date for certification on whether Panama's government is cooperating with U.S. anti-drug efforts will be moved up. If the administration, as expected, reverses Panama's current situation of non-compliance _ stemming from the Noriega regime _ its new government could partake in various trade and economic benefits. Bush said some 12,000 troops stationed at U.S. bases in Panama before the invasion would be left there, but would not serve a police role. Some 2,900 of the 14,000 additional combat troops that conducted the invasion were brought home this week, the Pentagon said. Bush also said: _He envisions no change in U.S. policy against intentionally sending military women into combat, although he would weigh such a recommendation if presented to him by the Pentagon. _He deplores the death of an American nun in Nicaragua, but noted the U.S.-backed Contra rebels denied responsibility. He called the matter of blame ``extraordinarily murky.''

DOC.HEAD: Monkey's Execution Stayed; Banishment Considered
DOC.TEXT: A judge stayed the execution of a ``naughty monkey'' and will consider a request from animal lovers to banish it to a wildlife sanctury, a newspaper reported Saturday. The monkey, which is in police custody in the port city of Trivandrum, was to have been killed Friday on an order issued by a local magistrate, The Hindu newspaper said. But after receiving a petition pleading for mercy on the monkey's behalf, the Trivandrum Sessions Court issued a stay of execution until Jan. 11 when a hearing will be conducted, The Hindu said. The newspaper did not say why or when the monkey was captured, referring to it only as a ``naughty monkey'' who ``fell into a police trap.'' Indian newspapers frequently report monkeys terrorizing school children, snatching their lunch boxes and even raiding homes in search for food. Monkeys are a common sight in India. Many Hindus do not hurt them because they evoke images of the monkey-god Hanuman and his band of monkey warriors who defeated a demon king in Hindu mythology. Trivandrum, in Kerala state, is 1,364 miles south of New Delhi.

DOC.HEAD: Waterway a Death Trap for Thousands of Wild Animals
DOC.TEXT: More than 8,000 wild animals, including endangered species, have been dying each year in a 125-mile-long irrigation canal in northern Namibia, a newspaper reported Saturday. The Star of Johannesburg said the canal had won two awards from an engineering institute but was considered ``an ecological deathtrap'' by conservationists. The canal, designed in 1980 and built over the next several years, is part of a network of reservoirs and pipelines that enables water to be carried from the Kavango River in northern Namibia to arid regions. The canal rarely carries enough water to drown large animals, but about half the animals that enter the 12-foot-wide waterway die because they are unable to climb back out the smooth, curved concrete sides, The Star said. The estimated annual death toll includes 4,700 warthogs, 1,500 hares, 300 baboons, and scores of antelopes, cheetahs, wildcats, foxes and jackals, The Star said. Namibia's Department of Water Affairs has expressed concern about the deaths but says it lacks the funds to cover the canal, The Star said. The department reportedly plans to erect a 20-inch-high wire fence along the waterway which it says will reduce the death rate by 90 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Two Die in Air Force Helicopter Crash
DOC.TEXT: An air force helicopter crashed into an electricity pole while flying in dense fog, killing two crewmen and injuring five, Press Trust of India said Saturday. The helicopter caught fire after Friday night's crash at Gorakhpur, 390 miles southeast of New Delhi, the news agency said. It had no other details.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Reached to Pull Indian Troops From Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: India and Sri Lanka reached an agreement Saturday on withdrawing Indian troops from the island nation, the major irritant in relations between the two countries. A joint press statement, issued at the end of Sri Lankan Foreign Minister Ranjan Wijeratne's visit to New Delhi, said the Indian peacekeeping force would be completely withdrawn by March 31, and possibly earlier. The two countries will also sign a treaty of friendship, the statement said. The Sri Lankans have been pressing India to speed up the withdrawal, but they appear to have accepted that it would not be logistically feasible to withdraw the 25,000 Indians soldiers before the end of March. ``What else can we do? We can't push them into the ocean,'' Wijeratne said in an interview after meeting with Prime Minister V.P. Singh. ``The Sri Lankans were very understanding,'' an Indian Foreign Ministry official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``They understood the logistical problem, they understood that we had no desire to stay longer than necessary.'' The official said the Indian government would examine the possibility of completing the withdrawal earlier. India's military deployment in Sri Lanka began in July 1987 and was intended to supervise the disarming of Tamil militants fighting for an independent nation in that country. But the biggest Tamil guerrilla group refused to honor an agreement to surrender and turned their guns on the Indians. At the peak of the fighting, the Indian force numbered about 100,000 men. At least 1,100 Indian soldiers were killed. The Sri Lankan government began pressing for a pullout of the troops last summer after peace talks with the Tamil guerrillas. But India refused to hastily withdraw its soldiers, saying it could lead to more violence. Sri Lanka's president issued a July 29 deadline for the Indian withdrawal, and relations between the countries deteriorated quickly after India said it would not adhere to the deadline. The two countries then decided to complete the withdrawal by Dec. 31, but Singh, who took office Dec. 2, said logistical problems precluded meeting that date. About 25,000 Indian soldiers are in Sri Lanka now. The Tamil separatist revolt began in 1983 and has left at least 11,000 people dead. Tamils account for about 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. They allege the Sinhalese majority discriminates against them in jobs, education and use of the Sinhalese language. Sinhalese comprise 75 percent of the population. India, Sri Lanka's northern neighbor, became involved in the peace efforts because it is the regional power and because of its own large Tamil population.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Struck By Lightning
DOC.TEXT: A construction worker died after being struck by lightning while on her way home, police said Saturday. The victim, 24-year-old Saropah Mohamad Salleh, was struck in Shah Alam, 18 miles west of the capital of Kuala Lumpur, the police spokesman said. She was killed Friday evening as she walked home from work.

DOC.HEAD: `Chester the Molester' Cartoonist Convicted of Child Molestation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: The cartoonist who created Hustler magazine's ``Chester the Molester'' has been convicted of molesting a teen-age girl. Dwaine Tinsley, 44, was found guilty of five child molestation counts by a Superior Court jury on Friday. Jurors agreed Tinsley had substantial sexual contact with the girl but also acquitted him of six charges and deadlocked on another five. The cartoon created by Tinsley depicts a lecherous character and his attraction to young girls. He refused to talk with reporters after the verdict. Defense lawyer George C. Eskin promised to appeal the guilty verdicts, arguing as he did during trial that the young woman accused Tinsley in retaliation for his efforts to halt her drug use. Tinsley faces a maximum prison term of 16 years and a $50,000 fine when he is sentenced March 1, said Deputy District Attorney Matthew J. Hardy. The molestations started in 1984, when the girl was 13 and continued until age 17, he said. Evidence presented at the trial said Tinsley told co-workers, ``You can't write this stuff all the time if you don't experience it.'' But Tinsley's ``Chester the Molester'' eliminated its focus on pedophilia several years ago, Hardy said. The prosecutor said the verdicts vindicated the victim, whose longtime efforts to report the attacks were discredited by adults. Tinsley, who now lives in Los Angeles, testified during the seven-day trial that the woman made up the story because he disapproved of her cocaine habit.

DOC.HEAD: Panama: A Long Hard Road to Economic, Political Recovery
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: With Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega safely in U.S. custody, President Guillermo Endara's new government can start to tackle political and economic problems that will make recovery difficult. ``We have to start from point zero,'' said Endara last week as he tried to grab the reins of government. ``This is the first time in Panamanian history that a new government had to start the way we did.'' Expectations in the small country of 2 million run high since the Dec. 20 invasion toppled Noriega. He surrendered to U.S. troops to face drug trafficking charges in Florida. From the businessmen making deals in the city's commercial hub to the people selling cool coconut water under the hot sun, Panamanians think dollars will flow ``now that the Americans are coming back,'' as they like to say. ``We are living a difficult moment ... for the worker, for the businessman,'' said Alfredo Maduro, president of the Chamber of Commerce in Panama City. ``For the real recovery of the country to take place, we will need the help of our friends.'' After two years of U.S. sanctions targeted at undermining Noriega, and with the devastation that followed the invasion, Panamanians want the United States to come through with financial aid now that Noriega is gone. They may get at least part of their wish. ``The revitalization of the Panamanian economy is a major priority in the months ahead,'' President Bush told a White House news conference Friday, ``as are our efforts for humanitarian assistance.'' In Washington, administration sources said U.S. officials are looking into building houses for people left homeless; helping Panama pay its $543 million foreign debt; and providing loans to help businesses recover. One administration official said, ``There's a sense of urgency, and we want to move quickly and respond quickly.'' But that will not be the end of Endara's problems. For starters, he will have to deal with the old conservative oligarchy, stifled under Noriega, who feel their time has come again. He also has to try to check some of his own followers' desire for revenge and spoils. At the moment, the government has support because everyone wants the economy, the country, to get moving. To list a few of his other problems: _Endara does not have a political party of his own. He led a coalition ticket in May 7 elections because he had fewer enemies than his running mates. _The Christian Democrat Party of Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon is best organized to get key government jobs in bitter political infighting. Arias is also justice minister, the most powerful Cabinet post. _The country's economy is a shambles. The construction industry was down to less than 20 percent of its normal level, unemployment is at more than 20 percent, and government income is less than 50 percent of what it was a year ago. _The invasion itself caused damages estimated at at least $2 billion, including the savage three-day looting of Panama City in the chaos following the invasion. Government economists estimate an additional $2 billion will be needed to pump up the economy in the next four years. _The United States, whose hand is guiding the actions of the new and inexperienced government, wants to mold it ``in its image,'' as a local politico put it, and is pressing for the formation of a professional military. Most politicians want to do away with the military that has ruled this country directly or indirectly since the beginning of the century and form a police force along the Costa Rican model. _There is fear of politically motivated witchhunts by rightist groups who feel secure with the U.S. Army here. ``You are going to have three governments here,'' said an Endara associate, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The weak Endara government, the stronger government of the Christian Democrats, and the overall government of the United States.'' Already, there are reports of dismissals based on political allegiances. One of the toughest jobs is the reorganization of a corrupt judiciary and the the entire legal structure controlled by the military. The question of what to do with the military is a controversial subject and a source of friction between members of the old Defense Forces and politicians. Both Endara and Arias, apparently under U.S. pressure, have backed down from statements about eliminating the military. Among those who wanted the military abolished were economic groups opposed to Noriega. A U.S. military source said a professional military would provide some of the security the U.S. government requires for the Panama Canal, while at the same time check the ambitions of competing economic groups. With Noriega gone, the U.S. military feel they can work with most of the members of his old forces. The United States maintains 12,000 troops in 10 installations here. The U.S. military has trained the Panamanian forces for years and knows them well. It was Noriega and his associates that were considered a problem. Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said Friday the number of U.S. troops here would be reduced to close to the pre-invasion level of 12,000 ``over the next few weeks.'' But Panamanian officials privately say the U.S. presence could be needed much longer, until it is certain Panama's government can survive on its own.

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Arrested for Selling Eggs on Sunday _ with Beer Free
DOC.TEXT: Eggs Benedict may be outrageously high in fancy, big city hotels, but when police heard a Sunday brunch of one egg was going for $15.50 at a rural mobile home they figured someone was being stung. It turned out it wasn't the customers. They were getting beer with their eggs, police said, which is OK in Georgia, except on Sunday. Sheriff's deputies arrested a father and son team for violating the state ban on Sunday alcoholic beverage sales, even though the men said they were giving the beer away and just charging for the eggs. The deputies then decided to turn the sting around operating out of the mobile home themselves and arrested 22 people who tried to buy eggs, with a beer chaser, said Capt. Arney Herrin of the Ware County sheriff's department. Devoy Martin Sr. and Devoy Martin Jr. were arrested Dec. 10. With the purchase of a $6 egg, the Martins were throwing in a six-pack of beer, while a $15.50 egg would bring the buyer two six-packs of 16-ounce beers, Herrin said. Both men are in the Ware County jail awaiting hearings on probation violations. The elder Martin has two years remaining on a five-year sentence for selling alcohol on Sunday, and his son is on probation for habitual violation of the state's drunken-driving law.

DOC.HEAD: Slain Drug Agent's Family Relives Horror Through TV Miniseries
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of slain Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena say they plan to watch a TV miniseries on his torture-murder at the hands of Mexican drug traffickers, but they know it will mean reliving the pain. Camarena's 65-year-old mother, Dora, said from her home in Calexico, Calif., that she has seen parts of the miniseries, scheduled to air Sunday, Monday and Tuesday on NBC-TV, and it was ``very difficult to watch.'' She plans to see the full program, but wants to get a videotape copy in case she becomes too emotional to watch the TV. ``I want a copy of the movie because I'm not sure I can take it,'' she said in a telephone interview last week. Her words were translated from Spanish to English by her daughter, Myrna, who works for the DEA in San Diego. Dora Camarena, who lost one son in the Vietnam War and another in the drug war, said she is grateful to the DEA, to the media and to Hollywood for keeping her son's story alive. Her daughter said she would watch the full show, even though she's seen most of it in advance and ``I cried a lot that night because it brought back memories.'' Camarena's wife, Mika, has not made any public statements about the show. Myrna Camarena, 35, said she joined the DEA in March 1974 and her brother followed in June of that year, although, ``He was the one who talked me into joining DEA'' when he was working as a narcotics officer for the Calexico police. He was kidnapped Feb. 7, 1985, in Guadalajara. A few days later, a Mexican pilot who had worked with DEA agents there, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, also was kidnapped. Their bullet-riddled bodies, showing signs of torture, were found March 5, 1985, wrapped in plastic bags and dumped on a ranch 60 miles southeast of Guadalajara. The miniseries, ``Drug Wars: The Camarena Story,'' recounts Camarena's efforts to combat drug trafficking in Mexico, his kidnapping, torture and murder and DEA efforts to pressure recalcitrant and sometimes corrupt Mexican officials into finding the agent and prosecuting those who killed him. Camarena's mother and sister said they were angered that a Mexican official referred to the miniseries as an ``amusement'' during an interview with The Associated Press following a screening of the movie in Washington. The Mexican Embassy minister for narcotics affairs, Gustavo Gonzalez Baez _ appointed by the new administration of Carlos Salinas de Gortari that has cracked down on drug traffickers and corrupt officials _ said Americans ``are accustomed to seeing this kind of series and they realize this is not reality, this is just amusement.'' Noting that the year-old Salinas administration has convicted major drug traffickers and some public officials in connection with the murders and has sentenced them to long prison terms, Gonzalez Baez said the movie suggests ``that all the Mexican authorities were involved in protecting drug traffickers, and that is absolutely inaccurate.'' ``It hurts for them to say it's an amusement because when I saw the movie, my heart felt the same thing that I felt when it actually happened,'' Dora Camarena said. ``It shouldn't be taken as an amusement.'' She said she was ``very pleased that the new president, Salinas, is cooperating to end corruption,'' but her daughter said, ``This is based on a true story. That is reality. We all know there is corruption in Mexico.'' DEA and State Department officials have praised the Salinas administration's efforts, but the miniseries doesn't include that recent history. DEA Administrator John C. Lawn said in an interview that he considered the miniseries ``about 80 percent accurate,'' while David Westrate, DEA's director of operations, said, ``There's a lot of pretend in there.'' Except for Lawn and Camarena, virtually all the DEA personnel depicted in the miniseries are composites based on several real-life people. For Camarena's mother, the show brings her son's work back to life. ``He gave his full strength and everything he could to combat the drug trafficking in a foreign country. He left an example. ... I have a lot of faith, and that keeps me going.''

DOC.HEAD: New Battles Erupt Between Christians and Moslems; Two Killed
DOC.TEXT: Christian and Moslem fighters battled in fiery duels across Beirut on Saturday, killing two civilians and forcing police to close the only gateway linking the divided city. It was the first serious flare-up in three months. The clashes coincided with the arrival of President Elias Hrawi in west Beirut, where he set up his office and residence and received credentials of the Vatican representative, Pablo Puente. That marked the Vatican's recognition of Hrawi's government and further isolated the Christian army leader, Gen. Michel Aoun, in his rejection of the government. Aoun's supporters, at his request, staged a ``human chain of demonstrations'' along the 25-mile route from Aoun's residence to Puente's home to protest the Vatican's move. Other protesters went to Puente's home to deliver a message of protest from Aoun. Thunderous shell blasts and bursts of gunfire echoed across the Moslem and Christian sectors as soldiers of Aoun's army battled with Syrian-backed Moslem militiamen. Both sides accused the other of shooting first. A police spokesman said the clash was ``the gravest violation'' of a cease-fire called by the Arab League on Sept. 22 to halt six months of fighting between Aoun's troops and Syrian forces. Until Saturday, there had been only minor clashes. An artillery shell crashed into the Sinn el-Fil residential area, on the Christian side of Beirut, and killed two civilian men, police said. Two other people were wounded in exchanges that engulfed the nearby Sodeco and Ras el-Nabaa districts. The fighting broke out in the morning, eased at noon and picked up again in the afternoon, forcing police and army units to close the mid-city Museum Crossing, the only gateway linking Moslem west Beirut and Christian east Beirut. The latest deaths brought to 931 the number of people killed in Christian-Moslem duels since Aoun in March declared his intention to drive Syria's 40,000 troops out of Lebanon. Aoun rejects Hrawi's presidency became it came about as a result of an Arab League plan aimed at ending the 14-year-old civil war but not setting a deadline for the withdrawal of the Syrians. All foreign countries with diplomatic missions in Lebanon have recognized Hrawi's ``national reconciliation'' government, which was formed in November to oversee implementation of the plan. Puente said during the Vatican credentials ceremony that the Holy See favored dialogue to resolve the crisis between Hrawi and Aoun. But a stung Aoun later emerged from his residence outside Beirut and told cheering demonstrators ``there is no room for dialogue.'' He drew wild applause when he vowed to bring to justice Hrawi and all Parliament members who approved the peace accord. Aoun commands 20,000 mainly Christian troops who control a 310-square-mile enclave comprising east Beirut and the region to the north and northeast. He claims the Syrian troops, deployed in 1976 to quell civil war fighting, violated their mandate by siding with the Moslems, and he declared a ``war of liberation'' in March to drive them out. Hrawi, who like Aoun is a Maronite Catholic, fired Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister in November. Hrawi and his wife, Mona, arrived in a 10-car convoy escorted by Lebanese army and police units in west Beirut's seaside Ramlet al-Baida district. He set up both his residence and office in the same building to avoid commuting in the city. His predecessor, Rene Mouawad, was killed by a bomb Nov. 22 as he drove from his office to his home, which was in the same building Hrawi is using. Meanwhile, fighting raged in south Lebanon between militiamen of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah and the Syrian-backed Amal. No new casualties were reported. At least 77 people have been killed and 275 wounded since the latest battles flared between the Shiite Moslem militias on Dec. 23. Amal and Hezbollah have been vying for two years for mastery of the 1.2 million Shiites, Lebanon's largest sect.

DOC.HEAD: 1890 Schools Prepare for Centennial
DOC.TEXT: Seventeen historically black universities across the South are getting ready to mark the 100th anniversary of their admission into the nation's land-grant college system. Officials at the ``1890 schools'' are hoping a lot of people will hear about the party. ``It gives us an opportunity to show the country the value of these institutions to society,'' said William Hytche, president of the University of Maryland-Eastern Shore and chairman of the Council of Presidents-Chancellors of the 1890 schools. In 1862, Congress passed the National Land-Grant Act, introduced by Rep. Justin Smith Morrill of Vermont, giving the states millions of acres of public land to establish state schools. Twenty-eight years later, Morrill, then a senator, pushed the Second National Land-Grant Act, also known as the Second Morrill Act, mandating that opportunities for higher education be extended to blacks. Twelve schools already established, including Florida A&M University in Tallahassee, were chosen for inclusion in the system. The other five schools were founded over the next 22 years. Since then, some 600,000 students have graduated from the so-called 1890 schools. Centennial celebrations will be organized on each of the campuses throughout next year as well as in Washington in April 1990. The Aug. 30, 1890, signing of the Second Morrill Act will be commemorated at Lincoln University in Missouri, founded in 1866 as the nation's first college for black students. The centennial must be celebrated ``within the context of the struggle'' said Joyce Payne, director of the office of Advancement of Public Black Colleges in Washington. Kept alive by the inequities of segregation, the schools have had to struggle for resources. ``They've done more with less than other ... institutions,'' agreed Sharon Worthy, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Department of Agriculture. ``That's a given.'' The schools, which are either in or near rural, often poverty-striken areas, have maintained a special interest in agriculture and engineering even as they developed their liberal arts programs. ``Everybody knows about George Washington Carver and peanuts,'' Ms. Worthy said, referring to the work done at Tuskegee University in Alabama. ``FAMU is committed to the land-grant notion,'' said Frederick Humphries, president of Florida A&M, the only historically black school in the state's university system. ``We fill a very special role of working with the limited resource farmer.'' The 1890 schools try to help small farmers find a way of making ends meet, Humphries said. In North Florida, that means experimenting with crops such as blueberries, grapes and Christmas trees. Elsewhere, current projects range from joint-research with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration into alternative foods for outer space to working with farmers in Third World countries in Africa and the Caribbean. Ms. Payne praises the 1890 schools also for their social accomplishments, saying that they generally have high levels of integration and large numbers of foreign students. White enrollment at the 17 schools is probably in the 10-15 percent range, said Eddie Jackson, spokesman for Florida A&M. ``We see the rich legacy of the land-grant tradition remaining preeminent on the campuses of these 17 campuses,'' Ms. Payne said, listing teaching, research and public service as the missions of land-grant schools. Hytche, who expresses high hopes for the next 100 years, said establishment of ``rural economic incubators'' was one priority. Such centers would increase efforts already being made at the universities to promote small and rural businesses and would help them for three or four years as well as train displaced workers.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Intervention Destroys Bush's `Wimp' Image
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, who a few months back was fending off charges of timidity, is reaping foreign policy and political gains from the success of a daring military operation in Panama. ``Bush just knocked one out of the park,'' one political analyst said. ``The `W' (wimp) word will not be heard again,'' said another. The U.S. intervention in Panama and subsequent surrender of dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega to U.S. forces is allowing Bush to bask in praise from leaders of both parties _ something rare for a president a full year into his term. Bush's gamble may have left him in the strongest position yet since he took office as he awaits the return of Congress on Jan. 23 with his popularity soaring in public opinion polls. And, while analysts and political leaders differed on the long-range payoff, few disputed the short-term value to Bush and his party _ particularly in this congressional election year. ``The president goes into this session of Congress with enormous credibility, whether on defense spending or domestic policy,'' said Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas. And no harsher a critic than Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., proclaimed the surrender of Noriega ``a triumph for diplomacy and a triumph for justice.'' At a news conference on Friday, Bush dismissed an assertion by Lee Atwater, chairman of the Republican National Committee, that the Panamanian venture was a ``political jackpot.'' ``A president's called on to take certain actions. We're not going in to try to furbish a political image; that's ridiculous,'' Bush said. But Leslie Goodman, a spokeswoman for the RNC, said Atwater's ``basic point was that anytime an American president does what he says he's going to do, the public approves wildly. That's what happened with Panama. And that's the political jackpot.'' Most analysts seemed to agree. ``Bush just knocked one out of the park,'' said Stephen Hess, a political analyst who specializes in the presidency at the Brookings Institution, a generally liberal research organization. ``And in international terms, he reminded the rest of the world that they can't take him for granted.'' ``This was a high-wire act, this was a big risk,'' Hess added. ``Think of all the ways he could have fallen off the wire, and yet he got from one side to the other.'' Mitch Daniels, political director in the Reagan White House and now a scholar at the conservative Hudson Institute in Indianapolis, said Bush's success in bringing Noriega to justice ``can't be overstated.'' ``There are defining events that tend to be remembered after the event itself has been forgotten. This was clearly a complex operation and the president clearly was personally directing events. And it worked,'' Daniels said. ``The `W' word will not be heard again,'' he added. Although Bush has not been called a ``wimp'' since early on in his presidential campaign, Democratic critics, including Senate Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, were accusing him of timidity in foreign policy as recently as a few months ago. Bush was attacked for failing to stand up to the Chinese government in the aftermath of the bloody Tiananmen Square crackdown; for reacting too slowly in promising aid for Poland and other emerging new democracies of Eastern Europe; and for failing to seize the moment during an abortive coup attempt against Noriega last October. ``Over the long run, in retrospect, it would have been much better to have intervened in that indigenous coup, rather than to handle it this way,'' said Norman Ornstein of the conservative American Enterprise Institute. ``We would have been abetting rather than initiating and carrying out,'' Ornstein said. ``And we would have been less responsible for Panama. Now, Panamanians are going to look with some justification to us to bail them out.'' Even so, Ornstein said, ``Bush's popularity has gone up, praise for him is across the spectrum. No one will be able to take away from him the victory that comes when you say, `I'm going to do this. And it's done.' And when he is called weak, wimpish and indecisive again, as he will be, it will have less sting.'' The president often has referred to himself as a cautious man. Against the backdrop of this caution, therefore, the bold Panama strike stands out in even greater relief, political analysts said. But Bush himself, while clearly savoring the praise and happy with the success of the operation, offers a more cynical assessment of how Democrats in Congress will react once the initial glow has faded. At Friday's news conference, he was asked: ``Is this the last time George Mitchell can ever accuse you of having a timid foreign policy?'' Bush: ``Knowing George, he'll find a reason, he'll find a way. And that's his job. Look, we're going into an election year.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Communists Change Stand and Denounce 1968 Czechoslovak Invasion
DOC.TEXT: The Greek Communist Party, in a policy reversal, has denounced the Warsaw Pact invasion that crushed Czechoslovakia's reform movement in 1968, the party's newspaper said Saturday. The policy reversal comes at a time when communism has been discredited by popular uprisings throughout Eastern Europe. Hard-line Communist regimes have fallen in Czechoslovakia, Poland, East Germany, Hungary, Bulgaria, and Romania. The Greek party's Central Committee also supported political reforms initiated by Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has given the countries in the Soviet bloc new freedom to determine their own political destinies. The party's initial decision to support the Warsaw Pact invasion caused some members to leave the organization and to form the Greek Left Party. The policy reversal could heal that rift and lead the two parties to merge. Last year, they cooperated in Greece's general elections under the banner of the Coalition of the Left and Progress. The coalition emerged as the power broker when the vote ended inconclusively. An all-party government was eventually formed to govern until new elections later this year. The party said it reversed its decision because it decided that while many East bloc nations deviated from orthodox socialism during the Cold War, that ``can be justified by the diverse styles of regimes that governed'' those countries, according to the party newspaper, Rizospastis.

DOC.HEAD: Smoking Ban in Tobacco Town Gives Some a Slow Burn
LaserPhoto CH2 of Jan. 5
DOC.TEXT: Cindy Barton lighted her second cigarette of the lunch hour and sneered at the ``Non-Smoking Section'' sign just across the room at Donnie's, a downtown restaurant. ``I think it's stupid. It's a joke,'' she said about the city's new smoking regulations, the toughest in the nation's No. 1 tobacco state. ``It was passed by a lot of hypocritical goody-goody two shoes who are no better than anybody else.'' Her co-worker, Sheila Atkins, agreed. ``The government cracks down on little bitty things that don't amount to a hill of beans,'' said Ms. Atkins, who said she smokes five cigarettes during lunch. ``It just irks me.'' Two tables away, Joseph Bernstein was enjoying a cigarette with his coffee and newspaper. Unlike his fellow diners, the restrictions didn't seem to bother him. ``I think it's a give-and-take thing,'' he said. ``I think it will work out.'' The smoking rules went into effect on New Year's Day in this city of nearly 200,000 people located in the heart of North Carolina tobacco country. Despite vocal opposition from the tobacco industry, the controversial measure passed by a slim 173-vote margin out of nearly 30,000 cast in a November referendum. Meetings have since been held between city officials and business owners so there would be no surprises. Many restaurants and retail stores already were complying with the restrictions, said city spokesman Jack Gardner. ``A lot of them were glad they didn't have to alienate their customers _ we were,'' he said. While Greensboro doesn't rank up there with tobacco towns such as Winston-Salem or Durham, it is the home of Lorillard Inc., which makes Newport, Kent and True cigarettes and employs 2,300 people. North Carolina produces about two-thirds of the nation's flue-cured tobacco, which is used to make cigarettes. With 14,000 tobacco farmers, the state's annual crop is valued at $900 million.
