North Carolina's cigarette manufacturers produce about 56 percent of all domestic brands. ``If this was Indiana or some other state where tobacco isn't grown there would be far less criticism,'' said Gardner. The ordinance bans smoking in elevators and grocery and department stores and requires restaurants seating 50 or more to set aside at least 25 percent for non-smokers. Customers who ignore the warnings can be fined $25, after a one-year grace period. The grace period doesn't apply to businesses, which can be fined immediately for failing to post the no-smoking signs or asking a customer to extinguish a lighted cigarette. ``We have a whole year to figure out how to enforce it,'' said Gardner. ``We won't be going into restaurants and shops looking for violators.'' Mary Lacklen, president of the 75-member Guilford County Restaurant Association, said most restaurant owners prefer a voluntary program. ``Since it's not (voluntary) we've taken it upon ourselves to educate our members so the transition can be smooth,'' she said. Mrs. Lacklen owns Bert's Seafood Grill, which seats 52. ``Before this ordinance we had already set aside 70 percent of our seats for non-smokers because of customer demand,'' she said. At Woolworth's, shoppers were greeted by large ``No Smoking'' signs at the door. Outside, the sidewalk was littered with dozens of crushed cigarette butts. Inside, part of the lunch counter that was desegregated by blacks during the 1961 civil rights ``sit-ins'' was set aside for non-smokers. Robert T. Taylor, who ate a sandwich while sitting at one of the four non-smoking tables at Donnie's, likes the new restrictions. ``After a while it will become second nature, just like integration,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Panama Action Doesn't Portend New Big Stick Policy
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Saturday the U.S. invasion of Panama should not be viewed as heralding a new ``Bush doctrine'' under which the United States would be inclined to intervene militarily in other countries where democratic elections are subverted. Interviewed on Cable News Network's ``Evans and Novak'' program, Cheney was asked specifically about what the United States would do if elections scheduled for February in Nicaragua are ``stolen'' by the ruling Sandinista regime. Cheney responded that the Panama action ``is not the beginning of the new Bush doctrine, where under every circumstance we would always use military force to intervene in order to enforce, if you will, the outcome of a free electoral process.'' Under further questioning about Nicaragua, the Pentagon chief said ``I think as a general proposition we always reserve all of our options when we look down the road. But at this point, I would not want to indicate that we plan to use force there.'' ``Our hope is that there will, in fact, be a fair election and that the outcome of the election will be honored by the current government of Nicaragua,'' he said. Cheney said there were ``different circumstances'' in Panama _ including the U.S. right to be in Panama under the canal treaties, the killing of an American Marine and harassment of other servicemen by the Panama Defense Forces, and President Bush's obligation to protect the lives of thousands of Americans living in Panama. He said the United States used military force in Panama ``very reluctantly. We exhausted all other options ... to try to deal with that situation and finally moved only when it was clear that American lives, American interests were, in fact, in jeopardy.'' Cheney said that judging by the ``huge quantity'' of weapons found in caches in Panama, it was ``reasonable speculation'' that former strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was involved in the international arms trade. ``When I was there right after the operation, I visited several of the sites that, at that time, we thought had maybe 30,000 or 40,000 weapons. Now it looks like 75,000. We have one report that may take it as high as 100,000,'' he said. Cheney noted that ``for a military force of some 4,500 people it doesn't make any sense at all to have weapons of that magnitude.''

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu's Last Days: Fallen Dictator Lies In Armored Car
LaserPhoto NY10
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: This account is based on reports from leaders of Romania's revolution, the Romanian media and information gathered by Associated Press reporters in Bucharest and elsewhere.

Nicolae Ceausescu ruled Romania with an iron hand for 24 years, scorning the changes swirling around him in Eastern Europe. But in four, swift December days he was brought down by a revolution, hunted, captured, imprisoned in an armored car, tried and executed by a firing squad. He liked to cast himself as the hero of a Romanian epic, and at the end he defiantly told the prosecutor at his summary trial: ``I am the president of Romania and the commander in chief of the armed forces.'' His power crumbled so quickly he couldn't even flee the country. And the soldiers he once commanded drew lots for the honor of shooting him. Of Ceausescu's heroic plans for himself and Romania, only one wish came true: he was granted a request to die together with his wife. Ceausescu had a huge security apparatus, with legions of specially trained, fiercely loyal troops, a secret tunnel network under his capital of Bucharest, and seemingly endless resources for his own protection. But unrest that started Dec. 15 in the western city of Timisoara sparked a national revolt against the hardship and terror of his reign. Hundreds were reported massacred in Timisoara Dec. 17 by the security police. Ceausescu, apparently confident he could ride out this protest, left for a three-day state visit to Iran. He returned on afternoon of Dec. 20, greeted as usual at the airport by chanting crowds and children with bouquets. Then Ceausescu began to blunder. He went on television and denounced the Timisoara protesters as ``hooligans.'' By Dec. 21, disorder began to move to Bucharest, largely as a result of a miscalculation by the 71-year-old Ceausescu, who had shrewdly survived other popular protests and even an attempted 1984 coup. He held two rallies in Bucharest and faced shouts of protest at both _ stunning occurrences for his tightly controlled state. At the second rally, on Dec. 22, the leader was shouted down with chants of ``Death! Death!'' Abandoning his palace, security forces, secret tunnels and his own dignity, he fled Bucharest in presidential helicopter No. 1, a sleek white craft with a range of 600 miles. No one can be certain what Ceausescu's precise plans were. Apparently, he and Elena were bent on fleeing the country, but it is not clear where he might have expected asylum. Silviu Brucan, a senior member of the National Salvation Front now running Romania, told the French newspaper Le Monde that Ceausescu was headed for ``a North African country,'' possibly Libya. Other reports mentioned China. From accounts of his flight from Bucharest, the escape was frantic and confused. The helicopter's pilot, Vasile Malutan, told the newspaper Romania Libera he desperately radioed for instructions while one of Ceausescu's bodyguards pointed a gun at his head throughout the flight. Ceausescu's trusted adviser, Emil Bobu, and Maria Manescu, wife of another confidant, were the only leading figures who accompanied the Ceausescus on the flight, which was so cramped the co-pilot had to sit on the dictator's knees. The craft headed for Snagov, a village north of Bucharest where Ceausescu had a summer residence. Bobu and Mrs. Manescu left there. She kissed the president's hands. From Snagov, the helicopter flew to a military airport at Boteni, northwest of Bucharest. Ceausescu, apparently fearful of being shot out of the air or falling into rebel army hands at an airport, ordered Malutan to land away from any airfield. According to one account from Brucan, published in the Financial Times, Ceausescu was surrounded by peasants as soon as he landed and was handed over to the army. But in a later account, the deputy interior minister, Col. Gen. Jean Moldoveanu, said Ceausescu's bodyguards hijacked a private car for the couple, who sped off. Two traffic police recognized Ceausescu at a checkpoint. They caught up with the Ceausescus at a factory in Cimpulung, a town at the foot of the Carpathian Alps, some 100 miles northwest of Bucharest, Moldoveanu told the newspaper Adevarul. He said the couple was alone. The two policemen planned to surrender their prisoners to the army. But, as they drove south toward Tirgoviste, 40 miles northwest of Bucharest, citizens tried to stop the car, believing the policemen wanted to escape with the Ceausescus, Moldoveanu said. After a dramatic chase through Tirgoviste, the two policemen managed to outfox the pursuing citizens and drove to a wood, where they covered the car with tree branches and leaves and stayed until dark. Moldoveanu said they took the Ceausescus to a military base near Tirgoviste where they were put under heavy guard. ``Several hours after their capture, the base was attacked from land and air (by pro-Ceausescu security forces), but the military there knew how to defend themselves and their prisoners,'' Moldoveanu said. Soldiers put the Ceausescus in an armored car that was kept on the move for nearly three days to prevent the Securitate, or secret police, from discovering their whereabouts, Maj. Mihai Lupoi later told British television. Ceausescu suffered from diabetes but refused to take insulin during his detention, Lupoi said. Lupoi, who was appointed tourism minister for his role in the revolution, said the armored car was the one that delivered Ceausescu to the secret military tribunal that sentenced the dictator to death. On television, Romanians saw Ceausescu as he struggled in ungainly fashion out of the armored vehicle, losing his Astrakhan hat. They saw a doctor test the fallen leader's blood pressure, and then saw the dictator and his wife, in scarf and thick light brown coat, defiantly answering their unseen military accusers. The charge against Ceausescu and his wife, his second-in-command, was the genocide of 60,000 people during their years in power. ``I'm not guilty! I'm not guilty! I will answer only in front of the Grand National Assembly (parliament) and in front of the working class. These are lies!'' Ceausescu yelled near the end of the summary trial. ``I don't recognize this court!'' At the end, Ceausescu interrupted a prosecutor who addressed him simply as defendant. ``I am not a defendant, I am the president of Romania and the commander in chief of the armed forces, and I want to answer before the Grand National Assembly.'' The prosecutor replied, ``I have nothing to discuss with you.'' When Ceausescu again tried to interrupt, he was told sternly, ``The sentence cannot be appealed.'' Romanians did not see the Christmas Day execution. The videotape closed with a shot of the couple's bodies, crumpled close together beneath a bullet-shattered wall. Later accounts said so many soldiers wanted to be in the firing squad that a lottery was held among 300 volunteers. When the ruling couple walked toward their end, the soldiers barely waited for the order before opening fire. The accounts said the couple's last wish was to die together. And so they did, riddled with 90 bullets at a military base outside Tirgoviste. The people's last glimpse of the fallen Ceausescu was a close-up of his face, eyes open, the right side of his head stained with blood. The couple's burial place remains unknown. Most likely, the leaders that executed the couple buried them secretly near where they died, thus preventing either desecration of the grave by angry Romanians or an attempt by security men to recover the bodies.

DOC.HEAD: Klan Rally Ends Without Confrontation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, ``We'd rather...' to CORRECT to `they' sted `them.'
DOC.TEXT: More than 2,000 law-enforcement officers sealed off the area surrounding the state Capitol this morning and maintained order as about 50 white supremacists and 100 counterdemonstrators rallied. The Klan-led rally ended without any confrontations after about 75 minutes. However, a shouting match broke out as Klansmen returned to their cars. Counterdemonstrators a half-block away began jeering and the supremacists responded with shouts and Nazi-style salutes. As a Klan motorcade left the Capitol area, counterdemonstrators burned a figure made of sheets as a Ku Klux Klan effigy. Officials said 1,594 Georgia National Guardsmen, 300 Atlanta police officers, 184 state troopers and 145 agents from the Georgia Bureau of Investigation were present during the rally, separating the Klan contingent from about two dozen counterdemonstrators who marched two blocks away. About 30 of the white supremacists were dressed in white Klan robes, while others wore camouflage fatigues or pseudo-Nazi garb. Chants from the counterdemonstrators and the rumble of police and television helicopters drowned out the Klan. Randall W. Smith, grand dragon of the Southern White Knights of the KKK, said that considering the violence tht erupted during demonstrations the last two years, the Klan welcomed the security. ``We'd rather they keep them out. We really appreciate the security,'' Smith said. Civil rights leaders had urged blacks to stay away from the rally, which was organized by the Southern White Knights of the KKK. It was to be followed by an afternoon rally in Forsyth County, the virtually all-white county north of Atlanta where ``brotherhood marchers'' were pelted with rocks in 1987, prompting a second march by 20,000 civil rights supporters. The Ad Hoc Committee Against the Klan called this week for counterdemonstrators to gather nearby in opposition to the Klan. Several civil-rights leaders endorsed a less confrontational approach, an ``ecumenical prayer vigil for peace'' at the Martin Luther King Jr. International Chapter on the campus of Morehouse College, several miles from the Capitol. Among those supporting the vigil were Southern Christian Leadership Conference President Joseph E. Lowery and the southeastern regional director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Earl Shinhoster. ``The best reception for (racist) hate groups is empty streets and churches full of blacks and whites in prayer,'' Lowery said. Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., a longtime Atlanta civil rights leader, called on blacks to stay away from the Klan. ``The Klan represents the past, not the future,'' Lewis said. ``They represent the dark, not the light. Ignore this group, leave them to themselves and allow law enforcement officials to take care of the matter.'' Last January, a white supremacist rally and march in downtown Atlanta turned violent as thousands of counterdemonstrators gathered to oppose a handful of white protesters. Racial tensions have been heightened in the Southeast recently by the mail-bomb killings of Robert Vance, an Alabama judge on the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, based in Atlanta, and Robert Robinson, a Savannah attorney. A letter written after the bombings indicated they were racially motivated and said others would follow.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Dismisses Iraq Plan for Talks as Iraq Displays Military Might
DOC.TEXT: Iran dismissed an Iraqi proposal for reviving peace talks between the two countries as ``a new campaign of public deception,'' Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said Saturday. The dispatch, monitored in Cyprus, said Iraq's three-point plan offered Friday only reworded previous Iraqi demands. Talks on a permanent end to the eight-year conflict have been stalemated since a cease-fire in August 1988. The announcement came as Iraq displayed new weaponry, including Iraqi-built missiles, during its annual Army Day. Iran did not reject President Saddam Hussein's offer outright but described it as ``a new campaign of public deception to undermine (U.N. Security Council) Resolution 598,'' the cease-fire resolution. ``In fact, Saddam reiterated Iraq's previous proposals that were extraneous to the resolution, only giving them a new wrapping,'' it said. Resolution 598, adopted in July 1987, calls for a cease-fire, withdrawal of troops to pre-war borders, the repatriation of prisoners of war, and settlement of the conflict through negotiations. It noted that Saddam failed to address simultaneous withdrawals of troops and repatriation of POWs, key Iranian demands for progress in the talks. Iran claims Iraq holds 1,065 square miles of its territory. But United Nations experts say the Iraqis occupy only 260 square miles. Both sides blame each other for the deadlock in negotiations. The last session was held in April, and U.N. efforts to revive the negotiations have foundered. Saddam proposed a direct dialogue between the Iranian and Iraqi leaderships be held alternately in Baghdad and Tehran under U.N. supervision. He suggested exchanging all ailing and disabled POWs and prisoners who have been detained since the early days of the conflict, which broke out in September 1980. His proposal called for opening offices for the two countries' national airlines in the capitals and reviving air links, which were cut shortly before the war began. It said this would provide an atmopshere of peace that would help push efforts for a settlement. The parade marking Iraq's Army Day underlined Saddam's policy of building up Iraq's military capabilities until Tehran signs a peace treaty to formally end the war. With both sides devastated by the war, most analysts do not believe there is much likelihood the conflict will erupt again. The Red Cross has registered 50,182 prisoners held by Iran and 19,284 in Iraqi camps. But U.N. officials and diplomats say there are at least 100,000 POWs. The Red Cross mediated an agreement to repatriate the ailing and crippled POWs immediately after the cease-fire. But the accord broke down after the release of only 400 prisoners with both sides accusing each other of falsifying the number of captives who were seeking asylum. The Red Cross estimates 1,000 ailing or disabled POWs are still held by both sides. Iraq has demanded that a new border accord be worked out, giving it total control of the Shatt-al-Arab waterway. It also has insisted on an agreement for clearing the channel of debris. Under a 1975 accord, the border between the two countries ran down the middle of Shatt-al-Arab, which is Iraq's main outlet to the sea.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Political Parties Propose Sweeping Disarmament Plans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for East Berlin-dated story on news digest.
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Communist Party on Saturday proposed that both Germanys cut their armies in half this year, seek the withdrawal of all U.S. and Soviet troops by 1999 and discard their chemical weapons. In West Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's party called for a new European security force independent of Moscow and Washington, reflecting the growing sentiment among Germans for a united and neutral Europe. The moves position the dominant parties in both Germanys for election campaigns focusing on how to balance German unity with European fears of a new military threat rising on the continent. East Germany's Communist Party leader, Gregor Gysi, laid out a detailed plan for drastic troop and arms reductions at a special meeting of the party leadership, according to the official ADN news agency. Gysi said both the West German Bundeswehr and the East German Volksarmee should be cut in half by 1991, thereby lending credibility to promises that a united Germany would pose no threat to European neighbors. The Communists oppose formal reunification of Germany, but they have agreed to seek a ``treaty community'' that would give a more formal basis to relations with West Germany and possibly result in a German confederation. ``Both German states must begin the demilitarization of Central Europe and fix their treaty community with a cooperative security policy,'' Gysi said. East Germany's Defense Ministry on Thursday announced it was cutting the compulsory army service term from 18 months to 12 months, and Gysi urged Bonn to take similar action. He also proposed that both nations pull back any defense installations within 30 to 50 miles of the inter-German border. Arms production should be ``considerably reduced,'' and chemical weapons should be removed from both states by 1991, Gysi contended in his disarmament program titled ``Model for Security 2000.'' It also calls for all arms modernization to be halted and for both sides to refrain from selling weapons outside their military alliances. Under the proposal, all foreign troops would be removed from Germany by 1999. West Germany's army of 480,000 is backed by about 250,000 U.S. troops, while the East German force of 170,000 is reinforced by 400,000 Soviet soldiers. Leading defense officials of Kohl's Christian Democratic Union unveiled a new West German military strategy in interviews with the Hamburg-based Bild am Sonntag. The newspaper distributed its report to news agencies ahead of Sunday publication. Military policy expert Otto Hauser was quoted by the newspaper as saying that a united Europe requires ``new concepts'' in defense, and that reduction of the West German compulsory service term should not be ruled out. Kohl and Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg have made plans for reorganizing West Germany's military structure, which they expect to begin putting into force after a conventional arms agreement is reached between NATO and the Warsaw Pact at negotiations in Vienna, the newspaper said. Asked about the newspaper report, Defense Ministry spokesman Winfried Dunkel in Bonn refused to say what changes West Germany might consider in the wake of a Vienna agreement, expected this summer. The parliamentary defense policy expert from Kohl's party, Bernd Wilz, urged the ``European parts'' of NATO and the Warsaw Pact to realign themselves into a European security force independent of the superpowers. ``Our answer to Moscow's security considerations is a new European peace order whose freedom, peacefulness and stability would be guaranteed by a new European Security Union,'' Wilz told the newspaper. As the postwar divisions in Europe have been mending in the wake of Eastern Europe's turn toward democracy, defense experts have predicted that the two military blocs eventually will be dissolved. Germans in both states have expressed strong support for ending the East-West division of Europe that has separated them into rival political blocs for four decades. The defense proposals were announced by the two German states almost simultaneously, but there was no indication that either the Communists in East Germany or Kohl's party had consulted with the other state. East Germans vote May 6 in the first free, competitive and secret elections in the nation's 40-year history, and the issues of German unity and European security are high on the campaign agenda. Cutting defense spending would free up state funds that could be devoted to upgrading industry and improving the provision of basic goods and services to the nation of 16 million, which is mired in economic crisis. In West Germany, Kohl's party holds a slight lead over the opposition Social Democrats in polls conducted since the Berlin Wall opened Nov. 9 and relations between the Germanys began warming. West German elections are scheduled for December.

DOC.HEAD: Sudanese Rebels Claim Killing 250 Government Troops
DOC.TEXT: Sudanese rebels said Saturday they killed 250 government troops during six days of fighting. The rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army said in a radio broadcast that rebels chased fleeing government soldiers to the Ugandan border but stopped there ``out of respect for the international border.'' On Friday, the Sudanese rebels claimed they had dispersed an army brigade of more than 3,000 soldiers in the south region of Equatoria. There is no way to independently confirm rebel and army claims of victories in the nearly 7-year-old civil war in the south. The SPLA took up arms against the government in the spring of 1983. They want more autonomy and economic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Court squabbles between Washington Redskins owner Jack Kent Cooke and his ex-wife took a new twist when Suzanne Martin Cooke asked $140,000 a year support for their nearly 2-year-old daughter, Jacqueline. ``I find this proposal abhorrent!'' Cooke replied during a child-support hearing Friday in Fauquier County, Va., Circuit Court. Mrs. Cooke, 33, asked for $1,650 a month for vacations for the child, among other things. ``This is an average monthly expense?'' asked Cooke's attorney, Milton S. Gould. ``Twenty-thousand dollars a year? ... Is this a fair amount for a 2-year-old child?'' ``I think it's important that Jacqueline be brought up in an environment with other children of her own stature, yes,'' Suzanne Cook replied. Looking at her ex-husband, she added, ``She'll be 2 years old on January 25, in case you've forgotten her birthday.'' Other expenses included in the request were $600 a month for clothing, $1,390 monthly for baby sitting and a nanny, $375 for restaurants, and the purchase of a $650,000 farm. Her lawyer, Rodney Page, argued that Cooke be required to pay extra each month because at 77 he ``may not be around to pay this support.'' The Cookes separated a month after their July 1987 wedding when Mrs. Cooke refused to go through with an agreed-upon abortion. The Redskins owner's attorney argued that Suzanne Cooke intended all along to use the baby to obtain a fortune from Cooke, estimated by Forbes magazine to be worth $1.25 billion. A new court date was set Jan. 16.

NBC News correspondent Mary Alice Williams gave birth to a girl early Saturday, the network said. The 8 pound, 9 ounce baby was delivered at an undisclosed New York hospital, network spokeswoman Peggy Hubble said. Mother and daughter were doing fine, she said. It was the first child for Williams, formerly of Cable News Network, and her husband, CNN producer Mark Haefeli. The girl's name: Alice Ann Haefeli.

A plane piloted by actor James Brolin crashed and burned during takeoff, but Brolin escaped without injury. A strong gust of wind on Friday afternoon blew the plane off the runway and down an embankment, said Sgt. Ernie Roop of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department. Brolin, 49, escaped ``moments before the plane burst into flames,'' Roop said. He was alone in the four-seat Cessna 182 when the accident occurred at Agua Dulce Airport in Saugus, 33 miles northwest of Los Angeles. The plane was destroyed by fire. Brolin was known for his role as the apprentice to Robert Young in the prime-time television series, ``Marcus Welby M.D.'' He won an Emmy Award in 1970 for the role. He also starred in the television drama ``Hotel'' and has appeared in several films, including ``Pee Wee's Big Adventure'' and ``The Amityville Horror.''

Thomas F. Wilson had never been in a movie before ``Back to the Future,'' so auditioning for executive producer Steven Spielberg brought on ``utter mind-bending fear,'' he said. Wilson had been in television and commercials before he landed the role of Biff Tannen, who bullies Michael J. Fox's character, Marty McFly, in the original movie, its current sequel and next year's third episode. Wilson was ``ready to pass out'' at his final audition, he said in an interview published Friday in The New York Times. ``I thought I had destroyed the reading. It was the scene where I was bullying Crispin Glover,'' he said, referring to the actor who played McFly's father in the original. He was asked to ``show us some bully stuff.'' ``I just threw Crispin all around the room,'' Wilson said. ``But with all this physicality, I lost my way in the scene. I started improvising. I lost my place. ... ``I really thought I had blown it. It was a long night of me staying in a fetal position in a corner of my room.'' When his agent called the next day to say he got the part, he said he let out a ``blood-curdling scream.'' In next year's movie, he'll play Biff's great-great-grandfather, gunslinger Buford Tannen. ``If you thought Biff was bad, this guy's horrible. He woke up on the wrong side of the globe.''

The mother of the man profiled in the new movie ``Born on the Fourth of July'' says she's not the religious fanatic she is protrayed to be in the movie. However, her son's portrayal by Tom Cruise was right on target, she said. Pat Kovic, mother of Vietnam veteran Ron Kovic, an activist whose book is the basis for the Oliver Stone-directed movie, said her character, played by actress Carolyn Kova, is presented as the villain. ``I just don't like the words that were put in my mouth. He (Stone) made me out to be a religious fanatic,'' she said. ``I'm religious. God is very important to me, but I'm not a fanatic. I'm really a very nice person. Ask all my friends.'' Mrs. Kovic said she has accepted the film the way it is and just hopes it doesn't affect the opinions of her held by people she knows. ``It's a movie,'' said her husband, Tom Kovic. ``I don't think you get 100 percent accuracy.'' The Kovics raised their children in Massapequa, N.Y., and moved to Yuma five years ago.

DOC.HEAD: No One Knew the Dark Side of Charles Stuart
With AM-Stuart Shooting, Bjt
LaserPhoto BX5
DOC.TEXT: Residents of the close-knit, Catholic neighborhood where Charles Stuart grew up say they knew him well, the way everyone knows each other in a working class, church-going community. Now they're not so sure. ``It's like something out of a bad detective novel,'' said Steve Reardon, Stuart's cousin who runs a family-owned, downtown restaurant where Stuart and his three brothers worked when they were younger. Stuart, 29, killed himself Thursday by jumping off a Boston Harbor bridge after his youngest brother implicated him in his own shooting and the fatal shooting of his pregnant wife, Carol. Stuart had told police they were shot by an assailant after they left a childbirth class at a Boston hospital last Oct. 23. The baby was born prematurely and died 17 days later. Police now say Stuart's story isn't true. ``How could someone like Carol, with the character and reputation that she had, have gotten involved with Chuck if Chuck had been the madman it looks like he may have been,'' Reardon said. ``You just don't know what goes on behind closed doors. It all looked so good on the outside.'' But almost immediately after the shootings, the rumors began: that Stuart had drug problems; that he was hoping to cash in on life insurance policies on his wife; that he was not the father of the infant. Police are investigating the life insurance angle, but so far they know only that he collected $82,000 on a policy from his wife's job as a lawyer. Investigators also have ordered tests to check the baby's parentage. But checks so far show no criminal background, no confirmed link with drugs, and no evidence Stuart was anything but the way friends and police had come to see him: a nice guy. ``Never, ever did I get a tip to suspect Charles Stuart,'' said John Dawley, the Stuart family attorney who represented Charles until he became a suspect. ``The guy was a remarkable guy, and I don't say that lightly. I say it in light of everthing I know.'' There are still only hints of a darker side. ``Nothing was substantiated. I think there were a number of people who had a knowledge that something was amiss,'' said Acting Police Chief James Russo in Revere, north of Boston. ``As far as him being squeaky clean, I can't say that. But I don't want to add further to the burden of the family.'' Stuart was one of four vigorous, athletic brothers in an active family. His father, Charles Stuart Sr., was the one people called when they needed a toastmaster at the Knights of Columbus, a Catholic men's group. He and his wife, Dot, raised six children, two daughters from Stuart's first marriage, and their four sons, Charles Jr., Michael, Mark and Matthew. ``I heard the rumors, and I just said `that can't be,''' said Joanne Bogus, who lives two doors from the Stuart family's red shingle house. It is just around the corner from the construction site for a new Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church, attended by the Stuarts and most neighbors. ``I've been living here for 14 years. My son was a little younger than the four Stuart boys, but Chuckie and the others would always be out there playing with the kids, street hockey, basketball, baseball, you name it. This is just too hard to understand,'' she said. Maureen and John Vajdic, neighbors of the Stuarts in Reading, 13 miles northwest of Boston, said the couple seemed happy, and they saw nothing untoward when they were in the house after the shootings to care for the couple's two black retriever dogs. But Mrs. Vajdic said Mrs. Stuart had once asked if she heard a loud argument late one night after Stuart came home. Ted Kakas, one of the owners of the fur store that Stuart managed on the posh Newbury Street in Boston's Back Bay, said: ``There's nobody in this store of 50 employees who isn't blown away by this.'' One of the few glimpses of a possible other side of Chuck Stuart comes in reviewing his accounts of his college days. He told others he went to Brown University to play football and then to Salem State college. College officials at Brown say there is no trace of him; he only briefly attended Salem State. ``You see these stories on the television news, you analyze them and then forget about it. But then something like this happens, where you know the people, it just leaves you wondering,'' said Wayne Berry, a bartender at Reardon's.

DOC.HEAD: Taps Were Installed at Charles Keating Home, Ex-Bell Worker Says
DOC.TEXT: A former telephone technician testified that he put a wiretap on the home telephone of Charles H. Keating Jr., the central figure in a $2 billion savings and loan failure. Robert Draise, a former technician for Cincinnati Bell, said the company's former security chief gave him radio transmitters to attach to Keating's home phone in the 1970s. Keating was then a Cincinnati businessman and founder of the anti-pornography group Citizens for Decent Literature. Keating, now a Phoenix millionaire, is the former owner of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. The government seized Lincoln in April, and filed a $1.1 billion fraud and racketeering civil suit against Keating charging he operated Lincoln for his own and his family's benefit. Keating denies the charges and is challenging the seizure. Draise's testimony Friday came during the trial of a defamation suit filed by Cincinnati Bell in Hamilton County Common Pleas Court. Draise and another former Bell employee claim to have performed hundreds of illegal wiretaps between the early 1970s and 1984 ordered by police and Bell security officers. ``I know what I did. I did the wiretaps. I did them for Jerry Berry. I did them for Pete Gabor. I even did one for myself,'' Draise testified. Jerry Berry is a former sergeant in the Cincinnati Police intelligence squad. He and other former officers have admitted using Draise and Leonard Gates on some illegal wiretaps in the early 1970s. Peter Gabor is a Bell manager who headed the company's security section in the late 1970s and early 1980s. He and James West are the Bell security officers Gates and Draise claim ordered many of the alleged taps. The phone company, West and Gabor deny knowing about or participating in any illegal taps, and have sued Gates and Draise for defamation. Gates and Draise countersued, claiming they were injured by being called liars. The illegal wiretaps began in the early 1970s, Draise said. Draise said he agreed to Berry's request to perform taps against criminal suspects and alleged subversives. He said Berry told him the taps had been cleared with Bell security and continued installing them for several years. Draise said he was installing a phone at Keating's house when Gabor telephoned him. ``He said he understood I had done some very good work for Jerry Berry,'' Draise said. Gabor came to Keating's house and gave Draise two radio transmitters to attach to Keating's lines, Draise said. The reason for installing the transmitters or who was listening to them was not stated. Draise said he believed the Keating wiretap was done in 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan's Noriega Doesn't Mind Sharing
With AM-Noriega's Operation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for Detroit-datelined listing on News Digest
DOC.TEXT: Tony Noriega says he doesn't mind sharing his name with the deposed dictator of Panama. In fact, he enjoys the coincidence. He donned camouflage clothing last month and struck a clenched-fist pose that made him look just like Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega for a hometown newspaper, the Tri-City Times. To some co-workers at General Motors Corp., Noriega said he was the dictator's big brother. ``They didn't know how old he was. I said `He's 36 ... He's my younger brother,' and I walked away real fast,'' Noriega said Friday. Tony Noriega, 46, was born in Mexico and has lived in Imlay City for 25 years. He says to his knowledge, he is no relation to the alleged drug-runner who surrendered to U.S. troops outside the Vatican Embassy in Panama City Wednesday. A year of heavy Noriega-bashing by U.S. leaders hasn't bothered Michigan's Noriega. ``I'm having a lot of fun with it,'' he said. ``I have a very flexible personality.'' Noriega's humor befuddles a few. ``Some people don't know what to make of it,'' he said. ``They get very reserved, very far away.'' The parodies end as soon as Noriega, a staunch Republican, talks politics. This is one Noriega who supported the U.S. invasion of Panama. There have been no open hostilities, though, Noriega said. ``I don't let it get to that,'' he said. His kids seem to enjoy the attention and even attract it, Noriega said. When the family went out to dinner Thursday, the day of Gen. Noriega's arraignment on federal drug charges in Miami, one of the girls couldn't stop giggling at the Noriega discussions going on at the next table. Finally the family had to tell people why they were laughing. ``Now you can say you've served the Noriega family,'' he told the waitress. The notoriety has its benefits, said his wife, Becky Noriega. ``Before, I always had to spell my name,'' she said. ``Now I don't have to. Everyone knows.''

DOC.HEAD: Birthplace of National Anthem Rallies to Its Defense
DOC.TEXT: Oh say, can you sing the national anthem? Most people can't, says a congressman from Indiana who wants to scrap ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' as the nation's official song in favor of the less straining ``America the Beautiful.'' Rep. Andrew Jacobs also says the poem penned by Francis Scott Key after American troops repelled British forces at Baltimore's Fort McHenry in 1814 is unsuitable because it celebrates war and because the tune's origin is an old drinking song _ and an English one, to boot. Jacobs' introduction of a bill to make the change, though nothing new, has provoked a spirited defense. ``Who says you can't sing it?'' demanded Maryland Historical Society spokeswoman Darlene Frank. The society held a contest in September to commemorate the 175th anniversary of the writing of the anthem and found ``more than 300 patriotic Americans who loved the song enough to want to sing it in public ... and a capella, no less,'' Frank wrote in a letter dismissing Jacob's proposal. The Democrat has introduced the bill nine times in 12 years, without gaining any appreciable support. ``It's not a burning issue in my existence,'' Jacobs said. Still, he does not plan to forego the campaign. ``America the Beautiful'' is gradually eclipsing ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' as the song of choice at official functions, he said. In Maryland, Gov. William Donald Schaefer has asked the state's congressional delegation to oppose Jacobs' bill. The Frederick, Md., Keys, a minor league baseball team named for the composer, also opposes the change. Karen Stuart, head librarian at the Maryland Historical Society, said the latest attempt to replace the anthem has prompted more outcry that in the past. The public may be more sensitive because of the emphasis on the Pledge of Allegiance during the 1988 presidential campaign and the Supreme Court's ruling last summer that the burning of the flag is a protected form of free speech. Key wrote the anthem to commemorate the defense of Fort McHenry, where citizen soldiers withstood 25 hours of bombardment from British ships during the War of 1812. Key almost certainly took some poetic liberties in his most famous verse. Historians say it is unlikely he saw the flag ``gallantly streaming'' because it would have been soggy after a night of pounding rain. And Stuart said some scholars question whether the rockets' red glare was sufficient to illuminate the banner through the smoke and mist from as far away as the truce ship which Key was aboard. Flawed or not, ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' enjoyed immediate popularity in the young nation. The melody was ``To Anacreon in Heaven,'' the slightly bawdy theme song of a private men's club in London. The tune became well-known on both sides of the Atlantic but didn't get official recognition until 1931. Its rival _ the tribute to spacious skies and amber waves of grain _ was written in the late 19th century by a Wellesley College English literature professor, Katherine Lee Bates. Jacobs said he was impressed by the story of how Bates was inspired to write ``America the Beautiful,'' not by an armed conflict, but by the beauty she beheld from the peak of a Colorado mountain. But neither song is Jacobs' personal favorite among patriotic tunes. ``I like `This Land Is Your Land,''' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarians Defy Gov't, Maintain Ethnic Protests
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Bulgaria's Slavic majority defied their government and kept up protests in at least four cities Saturday to try to overturn new laws granting religious and cultural freedom for ethnic Turks. ``Turks to Turkey!'' and ``Listen to the voice of the people!'' shouted at least 2,000 people outside Parliament in Sofia, the capital. Demonstrations continued for a third day in the southern town of Kardzhali and in the northern cities of Shumen and Razgrad. The Turkish government and a spokesman for the ethnic Turks said the nationalistic protests, which have resulted in the country's biggest work stoppages in more than four decades, were instigated by Communist hard-liners opposed to the ouster of hard-line leaders and the implementation of democratic reforms. Protesters are demanding that the new Communist leaders reverse a decision Dec. 20 to allow ethnic Turks and Moslems to use their own names and languages and to allow the practice of Moslem religious rites without restrictions. Parliament President Stanko Todorov said late Friday that the government would not reverse itself. Turkey on Saturday denounced the demonstrations and said it supported the Bulgarian government. Turkish Foreign Minister Mesut Yilmaz said the protests were organized by people still loyal to ousted Communist leader Todor Zhivkov. Zhivkov, who was ousted Nov. 10, tried to forcibly assimilate the ethnic Turks by giving them Bulgarian names, prohibiting them from speaking Turkish in public and restricting their religious rights. Nationalists among the majority Slavs fear the 1.5 million ethnic Turkish minority is growing too fast in number and poses a threat to the country. The protests continued despite government appeals for calm. Todorov on Saturday went to Razgrad to meet with local officials in an attempt to defuse the crisis. On Friday, protest strikes paralyzed Kardzhali, where nearly half the 50,000 inhabitants are ethnic Turks. In nearby Haskovo, 25,000 people rallied Friday under such slogans as ``The Central Committee sold out Bulgaria.'' Protesters are demanding a nationwide referendum on the ethnic question. A major rally was expected Sunday outside Parliament. Bulgaria drew world criticism last May after Zhivkov granted passports to ethnic Turks and an estimated 320,000 emigrated to Turkey, saying they feared persecution if they stayed in Bulgaria. Turkey closed its borders. About 50,000 Bulgarian Turks later returned, complaining about lack of jobs and proper housing in Turkey. Slav nationalists have been suspicious of the loyalties of the Bulgarian Turks and ethnic Bulgarian Moslems, known as Pomaks, since Bulgaria won independence in 1877 from the Ottoman Empire after 500 years.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party to Find New Name and Revamp Itself at Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with plenum over, Central Committee recommending party disband, new quote; Picks up 7th graf, `The 230-member...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WAR50
DOC.TEXT: Communist leaders on Saturday voted to disband their crumbling party at a congress later this month and to form a leftist party with a new name and platform that rejects 40 years of Communist slogans. The Communists, who last year surrendered control of the government and lost their leading role in society, are hoping to regain some credibility and hold onto what power and members they still have by cutting ties to their past. ``The new party will be created with great effort,'' party leader Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski said in a speech concluding a party Central Committee plenum. ``It will have a new structure and program.'' The first day of the three-day congress scheduled for Jan. 27 will be devoted to abolishing the Communist Party and the following two days to forming a new party from its remnants, Politburo member Leszek Miller said. After Hungary, Poland would become the second East bloc nation to disband its Communist Party, which ruled for four decades until ceding control to Solidarity. It would be another in a series of historic changes that in the past year have changed everything from Poland's name to its state-run economy. Party members will be polled before the congress on choices for a new party name, Miller told the policy-making Central Committee before it voted to recommend the changes to the party congress _ likely the Communists' last. The 230-member Central Committee was presented with a proposal for the poll. It included six possible names and space for a write-in nomination for a name to replace the Polish United Workers Party, as the party is now called. The names being considered are the Socialist Party of Poland, Socialist Party of Working People, Social Democratic Party of Poland, Polish Party of Working People, Polish Party of the Socialist Left and Polish Labor Party. ``A new party is needed referring to the hopes which working people have in achieving leftist ideals,'' Miller said. An all-party poll conducted in September and presented to the Central Committee Saturday indicated that 72 percent of those queried favored transforming the party and adopting a new program and name. ``The idea of a new party is not the result of nostalgia of past importance. ... It is a consequence of the assessment that the (party) cannot effectively meet the challenge of the new times,'' Miller said. In a draft declaration for a new program to be voted on at the Congress, the party leaders rejected such Communist slogans as the ``dictatorship of the proletariat'' and ``collectivization'' and said Stalinism was imposed from abroad and had nothing to do with the roots of the Polish left. The declaration said the party believes the future of Poland lies not with capitalism but with ``democratic socialism,'' which it defined as ``freedom, democracy, social justice and solidarity.'' The draft said the new party hopes to work with trade unions and the left-wing of Solidarity and that it felt close to ecology and peace movements. Following a precedent set at the last plenum, reporters were allowed to attend the morning session. The sweeping victory of the Solidarity-led opposition in elections last June sent the Communist Party scrambling for a new identity. Blamed for Poland's crippled economy, the Communists' crisis deepened last summer with the election of Solidarity editor Tadeusz Mazowiecki, which ended more than 40 years of Communist control of the government. Constitutional amendments adopted last month stripped the party of its leading role in state affairs. At the beginning of 1980, the party claimed membership of 3 million. Now, membership has slipped to 2 million. Miller said 10 percent of the current members were not interested at all in preparations for the congress. Party unity has dissolved in recent months, with some Communist deputies in paRliament dropping out of the party caucus and with other Communists threatening to split from the party. But Miller said the possibility of a serious conflict going into the congress had subsided. ``We are going to the congress as a single party,'' he declared. He did not exclude the possibility of conflict at the congress, however. ``Unity of the post-congress party is the `to be or not to be' of the Polish left,'' he said. The congress is scheduled to last three days, with the first day devoted to passing resolutions to end the party's activity, and the following two days to the creation of a new party.

DOC.HEAD: Stricken Tanker Heads Across Open Sea After Denied Haven
DOC.TEXT: A crippled Iranian tanker that spilled 19 million gallons of oil off the Moroccan coast was towed past the Canary Islands Saturday in its search for calm seas to transfer its remaining cargo. Cape Verde, Morocco, Portugal and Spain turned away the Khark 5, which made an arc Saturday around the Canaries before heading south across open seas. The salvage company Smit Tak, which is commanding the three tugs towing the Khark 5, said it planned to take the 1,120-foot tanker toward ``sheltered waters'' with little wind and less than two-foot waves. The 53 million gallons of oil still estimated to be inside the Khark 5 will then be transferred to a second Iranian tanker, said Daan Kaakebeen, a spokesman for the Dutch salvage company. Smit Tak has been trying to find a haven for the Khark 5 since an explosion ripped through the ship's hull Dec. 19 when it was 400 miles north of Las Palmas in Spain's Canary Islands. Morocco, 400 miles west, refused to let the tanker dock there, and a 100-square-mile oil slick threatened Morocco's coastline. Pollution experts said Thursday nearly all the oil had dissipated and that there was no danger of an environmental disaster. Kaakebeen said Spain's decision to deny a request for the Khark 5 to perform the transfer of oil inside the 200-mile territorial zone around the Canaries would delay the transfer by seven or eight days. But he added that milder weather off Africa's Atlantic coast lessened the possibility of new spills. The tanker's condition was stable and it had not leaked crude since Wednesday, he said. ``As long as the ship is out in the open water with a cargo there is always a percentage of danger that a heavy storm will damage it,'' Kaakebeen said. ``But the weather is improving.'' The ship was heading west around the Canaries on Saturday morning, Kaakebeen said. The Spanish navy vessel Atrevida and the Punta Mayor, a Merchant Marine tug equipped with floating barriers and chemical dispersants were following the tanker, Merchant Marine officials said. In Cape Verde, a republic of 15 islands about 1,200 miles south of the Canaries, Merchant Marine head Humberto Morais issued a statement Thursday forbidding the Khark 5 from entering its waters. ``We won't accept this supertanker in Cape Verde for any money,'' the state news agency Capopress quoted Morais as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Suggests Free Movement Across Iran-Soviet Border
DOC.TEXT: A leading Tehran newspaper on Saturday suggested opening the border between Iran's Azerbaijan province and the Soviet Union to quell unrest in the region. The English-language Tehran Times said in an editorial: ``An agreement on free border crossing between the two governments ... will greatly help to alleviate the seething emotions of people who wish to see their ancestral land and visit long-lost relatives.'' Tehran radio said Iran's deputy foreign minister, Mahmoud Vaezi, left for Moscow on Saturday to discuss ``bilateral relations'' with Soviet officials. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, did not elaborate further on the purpose of the visit. Excerpts of the Tehran Times editorial were carried by the Islamic Republic News Agency, also monitored in Nicosia. Protesters demanding unification of Soviet Azerbaijan with the adjacent northern Iranian province also populated by ethnic Azerbaijanis have been trying to break open the border in demonstrations that flared last Sunday. Tehran television reported last week that four youths from Soviet Azerbaijan cut barbed wire border fences on the Aras river and swam safely to the Iranian side, while a fifth companion drowned. The Tehran Times said: ``The Kremlin should avoid suppressing the Azerbaijani people at all costs.'' ``Iranian authorities have already begun moves for preparing the grounds for Azerbaijani Moslems to visit Iran's holy shrines and religious institutions,'' it added. The Azerbaijanis are an ethnic group who, like most Iranians, are largely Shiite Moslems. Some 4 million Azerbaijanis live in northern Iran. Since the 1979 Islamic revolution in Iran, Soviet officials have expressed concern about Islamic fundamentalism creeping across the border. IRNA said that following meetings between Iranian and Soviet officials in Moscow on Friday, the two sides agreed to ease travel restrictions between the countries and issue visas within 15 days. It did not say who these officials were. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, said 7,500 protesters destroyed guard observation towers, electronic alarm equipment and communications lines along the border in the Azerbaijani unrest. It said one person was killed in a clash among the protesters but said border guards did not use their weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Ford Wants To Sell Its Aerospace Division
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. is trying to sell its aerospace division, a major supplier of missiles, flight training and satellite technology, a published report said Saturday. The Washington Post said the parent company wants to sell its Ford Aerospace Corp. because of uncertainties over government defense spending and a need to focus on automaking in the face of fierce global competition. Ford officials would not comment on the report, calling it ``speculative.'' Ford spokesman Bill Peacock in Dearborn, Mich., said he was unaware of any ``prospectus'' that the Post said was being circulated. ``I would not say there is nothing out there,'' Peacock said. ``I'm not sure what that document is. I can't say whether descriptive material might exist.'' Ford is holding a regularly scheduled board meeting Thursday, but Peacock said he was not privy to the agenda and did not know whether a sale would be discussed. Peacock said there had been some speculation in trade publications. Spokesman Thomas Foote said ``it's not a new rumor.'' The report occurs against a backdrop of concern among defense contractors that the thaw in East-West relations will mean reductions in government spending on weaponry. Chrysler Corp. announced last month it was pulling out of the defense business. General Motors has denied any interest in selling its Hughes Aircraft Co. subsidiary, which started laying off 6,000 of its 75,000 workers in the second half of 1989. The Ford aerospace and communications division received $2 billion in contract awards, both civilian and military, in its fiscal 1989. It employs 17,000 people, and division spokesman Norman Black said 70 percent of its business is with the military. Ford Aerospace produces the Chaparral and Sidewinder missiles and is one of the largest makers of satellites, supplying the Superbird to the Japanese. It is heavily involved in satellite tracking services and runs the military's jet pilot training ranges. The division also runs the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's mission control center in Houston and is building parts of the U.S. space station that is to orbit later this decade. Peacock said the division is in good financial shape and has extensive civilian contracts. ``It is solidly profitable and has a big communications activity with civilian customers, both in this country and Japan,'' Peacock said. When Chrysler Chairman Lee Iaccoca announced the sale of its Chrysler Technologies Corp., he cited the need to go back to basics and compete head-to-head with the Japanese automakers. When asked whether Ford was planning a consolidation like Chrysler's, Ford spokesman Foote said, ``If somebody comes along who wants to talk to us about anything, we'll talk to them.'' Ford's auto sales dropped 22 percent in late December compared with a year earlier, but it was the only domestic automaker last year to increase its market share, the Post said. Ford has about $2 billion in cash on hand. Ford acquired Britain's prestigious Jaguar auto company in November for $2.5 billion, and in August acquired Associates First Capitol Corp., the nation's third-largest independent finance company, for $3.4 billion. ``Ford would not do it for any immediate financial reason alone,'' said auto analyst Arvid Jouppi. He said he would not be surprised at such a move, ``Whenever one of the big three does something, the other ones do the same. ``The economies are essentially the same for all companies of the big three.'' Industry analyst Wolfgang Demisch of UBS Securities Inc. told the Post such a move would make sense. But he noted that Ford Aerospace within the last year acquired BDM International, a government services firm with extensive military contracts.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Meets with Loyalist Lithuanians In Search of Compromise
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts 2 grafs after 12th, `Protesters demanded...' to ADD Iranian call for border opening and SUBS 13th graf to conform. Pickup 14th pvs, `When negotiations...
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met Saturday with loyal Communists from Lithuania who oppose their party's bold break with Moscow, and thousands back home rallied to support them. Vitaras Rajavicus, a spokesman for Lithuania's political group Sajudis, said a delegation of the loyalists met behind closed doors with Gorbachev in Moscow. Gorbachev is undergoing what is widely viewed as a test of his personal powers of persuasion as he tries to bring renegade Lithuanians back into the fold. On Dec. 20, a majority of Lithuanian Communists voted to break ties with the national party, a possible precursor to secession by the Baltic republic. On Thursday, Gorbachev met the republic's party chief, Algirdas Brazauskas, and other leaders who support the break. He is scheduled to travel to Lithuania this week. The official news agency Tass, in the first official report on the talks Thursday and Saturday, said they featured ``exchange of opinions on a way out of the situation.'' It gave no details, except to say that aside from Gorbachev, the Soviet leadership was represented at the meetings by Politburo members Vadim A. Medvedev, Anatoly N. Yakovlev and Georgy P. Razumovsky. Participants in the meeting Thursday said Gorbachev understood that the majority of Lithuanian Communists want independence and vowed not to interfere. Two groups of predominantly non-ethnic Lithuanians sponsored a rally in the republic's capital Saturday to support continued alliance with Moscow. An estimated 2,000 to 3,000 people gathered outside the central sports palace and adopted an appeal to Gorbachev asking him to condemn ``nationalistic and chauvinistic overtones'' in their republic and restore the unity of the Communist Party, Rajavicus said. In another development, Radio Moscow said domestic problems had not forced Gorbachev to cancel all his January meetings with foreigners, as was reported Friday. The broadcast said Gorbachev still plans to meet with U.N. chief Javier Perez de Cuellar during the week of Jan. 15. In Tokyo, an official of the governing party said former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe has been invited to meet Gorbachev on Jan. 15. Tokyo and Hong Kong markets dropped and New York trading was upset Friday after a British Labor Party spokesman said Gorbachev canceled his meeting with opposition leader Neil Kinnock set for that week because of problems in the Soviet Union. In addition to the Baltics, Gorbachev is concerned with unrest in the south. KGB guards were rushed to the Soviet-Iranian frontier last week after protesters in the republic of Azerbaijan threatened guards and wrecked border fences. Protesters demanded the border be opened for trade, cultural exchanges and meetings of relatives. As in Iran, most of the people in Azerbaijan are Shiite Moslems. In Iran on Saturday, the English-language Tehran Times suggested opening the border between Iran's Azerbaijan province and Soviet Azerbaijan to quell the unrest. Tehran radio said Iran's deputy foreign minister, Mahmoud Vaezi, left for Moscow on Saturday to discuss ``bilateral relations'' with Soviet officials. It did not elaborate. By New Year's Eve, the border zone was occupied by protesters in tents, and authorities found 300 Molotov cocktails and hunting guns, the Soviet newspaper Arguments and Facts said Saturday. When negotiations collapsed New Year's Day, 9,000 people rioted along the 85-mile border on the Soviet side, and 800 people from the Iranian side joined them, the newspaper said. A new Communist Party chief was named in the area, the republic's official Azerinform news agency reported Saturday. Afedin Dzhalilov was named party first secretary of Nakhichevan, an Azerbaijan enclave and the site of the unrest. He replaced Gaidar Isayev, who cited health reasons for stepping down. Meanwhile, an explosion at a bus station in Agdam, in Azerbaijan and near the border of another troubled region, killed two people. The explosion occurred Saturday morning near the border of Nagorno-Karabakh, which both Azerbaijan and the neighboring republic of Armenia seek to control. Azerbaijani activists claimed Armenians were responsible for the explosion. Tass said it was caused by a gas leak. Nagorno-Karabakh has been torn by Armenian-Azerbaijani violence for two years. It is a part of Azerbaijan but populated mainly by Armenians.

DOC.HEAD: General Allegedly Used Power To ``Sell Panama To Traffickers''
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega used his power as head of Panama's intelligence unit, its military and then the entire country to give aid, comfort and shelter to Colombian cocaine traffickers in return for millions of dollars, the indictment against him charges. Noriega has been accused in testimony of detailing soldiers as bodyguards for Colombian drug traffickers, allowing military planes and airfields to be used for drug shipments, providing traffickers with intelligence information about U.S. anti-drug operations and sending armored cars to transport drug money. And when Colombian drug lords were angered over a raid on a cocaine lab in Panama, the indictment recounts, Cuban President Fidel Castro got them and Noriega together in Havana to mediate a settlement. ``By utilizing his official positions, Manuel Antonio Noriega and trusted associates were able to assure drug traffickers that Panamanian military, customs and law enforcement personnel would not interfere with their operations in Panama as long as substantial fees were paid to (Noriega),'' says the indictment handed up in Miami on Feb. 4, 1988. Since his arraignment in Miami on Thursday, Noriega's attorneys have been working on challenges to the indictment and the court's jurisdiction. They say the indictment was political and that Noriega claims innocence. He could face up to 145 years in prison and more than $1.1 million in fines on charges that include conspiracy and racketeering. The indictment names 15 other defendants ranging from Brian Alden Davidow, a jailed Miami college student charged with meeting with Noriega to arrange cocaine shipments, to Pablo Escobar Gaviria, the reputed Medellin cartel cocaine kingpin being pursued by Colombian authorities. While U.S. officials have accused leaders of other governments, particularly Cuba, of helping drug traffic to the United States for political reasons, Noriega's prime motivation seemed to be money, officials say. U.S. authorities say they have identified at least $10 million kept in European banks by Noriega, who rose from a poor family and reputedly supplemented his $60,000 annual salary with interests in casinos, liquor stores, news media outlets and banks. ``Money attracted him (to drug traffic). Noriega really loves money and luxury,'' said Ambler Moss, a former U.S. ambassador to Panama. The Miami indictment details at least $4.6 million in payments Noriega allegedly received for protecting cocaine and drug money shipments, selling seized ether and acetone used in making cocaine to Colombian drug traffickers, and for giving sanctuary to drug dealers in 1984 when the Colombian government went after them following the assassination of a justice minister. Noriega also is accused of allowing establishment of a cocaine laboratory in Panama's Darien province and helping the manufacture of cocaine in another laboratory in the nearby Colombian area dubbed ``Tranquilandia.'' A separate indictment in Tampa says Noriega agreed to protect two marijuana shipments totaling 1.4 million pounds for $4 million, of which he received $1 million. When he announced the 12-count Miami indictment, then-U.S. Attorney Leon Kellner noted that the case was unprecedented, but added that Noriega's influence in Panama was so pervasive that he was able to guarantee protection for trafficking. ``General Noriega controls Panama (and) he utilized his position to sell the country of Panama to traffickers,'' Kellner said at the time. Kellner, now in private practice in Washington, said last week he wouldn't comment on the Noriega case. Convicted drug smuggler Floyd Carlton Caceres told a U.S. Senate hearing in 1988 that he acted as a go-between in 1982, getting Noriega $200,000 a flight from the Medellin Cartel for protecting drug flights through Panama. Carlton, sentenced to nine years in prison in 1988 in Miami, has been called a key witness by prosecutors. Boris Olarte Morales, a convicted Colombian drug smuggler, may testify about a $4 million bribe the indictment says he paid Noriega. Other possible witnesses include convicted drug smugglers Ramon Milian Rodriguez, Cuban-born, and Stephen Kalish, a Houston native prominent in the Tampa case against Noriega. They have testified that the Noriega package of protection included armored car transport of their money, use of military airfields, immediate credit for deposits into Panamanian banks and intelligence information. Another crucial witness is expected to be Jose Blandon, a former Noriega confidant who broke with him in January 1988 and testified before the Senate and federal grand jury. Blandon said that in June 1984, Panamanian authorities raided the Darien processing plant and arrested 23 Colombians and Lt. Col. Julian Melo, secretary general of Noriega's staff. Blandon has said the Colombian traffickers, saying they had paid Melo $5 million to protect the operation, were outraged by the raid, which occurred while Noriega was in Paris. Castro was contacted by the Colombians, Blandon has said, and arranged a meeting at which Noriega was assured there would be no reprisals from the traffickers. Melo and the Colombians were soon freed, Blandon said, and equipment and $3 million were returned to the traffickers. Castro and Noriega have both denounced Blandon's charges as lies.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Executes Man as Spy for Iraq
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian was executed Saturday after being found guilty of spying for Iraq, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. IRNA, monitored in Nicosia, said Tofiq Daneshgar was also charged by the provincial Islamic Revolutionary court with smuggling counterfeit banknotes. The agency did not give Daneshgar's age but said he was arrested along with nine others in August on charges of spying and bringing counterfeit banknotes into the country. The others were fined and sentenced to various prison terms by the court, according to IRNA. The trial and execution took place in the town of Sanandaj, in the northwestern province of Kurdistan.

DOC.HEAD: Police Chief Commits Suicide Over Role in Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: A city police chief whose officers nearly clashed with demonstrators in November committed suicide and left a note saying he couldn't stand being blamed for the incident, a news report said Saturday. The demonstration occurred during the popular uprising that eventually swept the hard-line Communist leadership from power in Czechoslovakia. The police chief was the third official associated with the former power structure to commit suicide or attempt it last week. In other developments Saturday: _The Communists' Central Committee, meeting for the first time since its formation in December, elected a new 24-member executive body to replace the former ruling Politburo. _Former Communist Party leader Milos Jakes said the monopoly on power that the Communists enjoyed until recently left them without the political skills needed to meet the challenges of 1989. _An American congressional delegation said the United States may award Czechoslovakia most favored nation trading status soon, a development that could help the nation's economy. Josef Petracek, chief of police in the northern city of Teplice, 75 miles north of Prague, was found dead Friday morning after having shot himself with his own gun, the state news agency CTK reported. ``He left a goodbye note saying the reason for his suicide was pressure on him and the responsibility he felt for the police action on Nov. 11-13 in Teplice against demonstrators demanding a better environment,'' CTK reported. When several hundred people protested severe pollution in the region, riot police moved in to disperse them. But the officers were called off by a local Communist Party leader who agreed to talk with the demonstrators. The protest marked one of the first instances of officials agreeing to talk to the people as popular unrest spread in Czechoslovakia, eventually ending four decades of Communist Party supremacy. The news report did not say where Petracek was when he shot himself. On Wednesday, Jiri Becvar, a senior police official in Prague, also shot himself to death. He was charged with participating in a bloody police crackdown on students Nov. 17. Antonin Kapek, former Prague Communist Party boss, attempted suicide Thursday, citing what he called the unbearable pressure he was facing. He survived and was hospitalized in a psychiatric institution, media reported. Jakes, who was ousted as party leader on Nov. 24, discussed the Communist Party's problems in an interview broadcast Saturday on the Europe Express program on London's Channel Four in Britain. Excerpts of the interview were released by the program in advance of the broadcast. ``The party's problem was that because of centralized control, the party's power monopoly and the lack of an opposition, we couldn't fight political battles any more,'' he said. Jakes has been expelled from the Communist Party. He was widely held to be responsible for the purges of party members that followed the Warsaw Pact invasion in 1968 that crushed the reformist government of Alexander Dubcek. Jakes contended he was not responsible for the purges. ``That's a false version, that is years old,'' he said. ``The purge was ordered by the party Central Committee. I wasn't on the Central Committee. I headed the Control and Audit Commission, we just heard appeals against the decision of other party bodies.'' Though the Soviet Union and its allies have recently said the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion was a mistake, Jakes said it is too early to judge. ``It wasn't considered a mistake then, but a step to strengthen the socialist community. History will be the judge. It's only been 20 years, that's too little. While those who took part are alive, one can't be objective. ``From the point of view of today's events _ like perestroika, glasnost, democratization _ it seems a mistake. But history cannot be changed.'' Regarding the trade development, a group of U.S. congressmen, led by Rep. John J. La Falce, D-N.Y. said the most-favored-nation trading status could be granted as soon as Czechoslovakia implements planned economic reforms and further political changes, CTK reported. ``The United States will award Czechoslovakia the MFN clause as soon as some of the expected political and economic changes take place. It is a matter of several months, possibly weeks,'' CTK reported. In December 1989, the new non-Communist-dominated Czechoslovak government declared its intention to pass several new laws guaranteeing among other things freedoms of gathering, association and private enterprise. Some of these laws could be passed as early as February, sources say. The Communists' new executive body, which replaces the Politburo, includes the party's chairman Ladislav Adamec, first secretary Vasil Mohorita and three newly elected secretaries, CTK said. Adamec, speaking to the Central Committee, supported the idea of national understanding, but stressed that differences between Czechoslovakia's current political forces remain.

DOC.HEAD: Portland Grabs Cars To Slow Prostitution, Drunken Drivers
DOC.TEXT: Residents accused of using a car to solicit a prostitute or driving with a suspended license can have the vehicles confiscated under a new law that city officials think is the first of its kind. Since the forfeiture law went into effect Dec. 15, about 15 vehicles have been seized from people accused of driving with licenses suspended under a prior drunken driving charge, police spokesman Dave Simpson said Friday. Thirteen vehicles were taken from prostitution suspects, including an 11-ton delivery truck. The city has been seizing vehicles of all those arrested who fit the provisions of the law, a police spokesman said Saturday, but it probably won't keep many of the cars and trucks it seizes, although the ordinance allows it. The forfeiture part of the law has raised the ire of the American Civil Liberties Union, which has threatened to challenge the ordinance. The ordinance is aimed at discouraging drunken driving and prostitution, not at raising money for city coffers, officials say. ``The average `john' is a married man with a job,'' said City Commissioner Bob Koch, whose staff drafted the ordinance. ``It's going to be awfully hard for a guy to go home and explain to his wife where the car is.'' Administrative costs probably will exceed the value of the vehicles seized, said Deputy City Attorney Paul Elsener. ``I don't even think it (the forfeitures) will cover the cost of this program. I think it's a money loser,'' he said. Elsener said that while a $20,000 Chevy Blazer was seized from a man accused of soliciting a policewoman posing as a prostitute, most of the vehicles taken from those with suspended licenses were valued at less than $1,000. The city attorney's office is drafting criteria to use in deciding which vehicles to keep, Elsener said. ``They may include value, the history of the person, and other types of extenuating or mitigating circumstances,'' he said. Meanwhile, the ACLU's lawyers' committee plans to meet Wednesday to discuss whether to challenge the ordinance in court because a vehicle can be forfeited before its owner is convicted. ``I understand the enormous frustration caused by lack of space to incarcerate people, but now they're trying to violate people's rights,'' said Stevie Remington, executive director of the state chapter. ``We don't think there's anything wrong with impounding a car if someone is drunk and keeping it for a short period of time, but certainly not until after a conviction should there be a forfeiture.'' ``The mere fact that someone is acquitted does not imply that he'll get his vehicle back,'' Elsener said. A person can file a claim to the city to get his car back, and take the matter to court if the claim is denied, Elsener said. Those whose cars are seized but not forfeited still must pay towing and storage costs, he said. The provisions intended to deter drunken driving are unique in the nation, Elsener said. He believes the same is true for the prostitution provisions. Koch said the new ordinance should make a dent in the city's prostitution problem. ``Our real goal here is to convince the marketplace that the cost of street prostitution is too high and the johns will stay away from the city,'' Koch said. ``We're going to see a decrease in prostitution.''

DOC.HEAD: Teen Operator of Bomb-Builders' Network Sentenced
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who helped run a computer bulletin board service showing how to make explosive devices was sentenced to three years in prison for his part in a bombing intended to scare a 17-year-old girl. David Overeem, 18, Gaithersburg, Md., received the sentence Friday from Montgomery County Circuit Judge John J. Mitchell. The computer service, ``Pyromaniac Production Systems,'' reportedly gave formulas for homemade bombs to users as far away as California, prosecutors said. Authorities said Overeem was one of the leaders of a group of acquaintances who called themselves ``Damage Incorporated.'' Assistant State's Attorney Constance Junghans said in court that the group loaded the bulletin board with recipes for an array of explosive devices, including rockets, car bombs, pipe bombs, bottle bombs and land mines. Overeem was a junior at Gaithersburg High School at the time of his arrest in April and was described by prosecutors as an ``emotionally troubled'' young man of superior intelligence. Overeem pleaded guilty to making a pipe bomb that allegedly was detonated by a friend of his on March 26 outside the girl's home in Germantown, which like Gaithersburg is a distant suburb of Washington, D.C. The bombing was intended only to frighten the girl, who a former girlfriend of Overeem's friend, prosecutors said. No one was injured, but a piece of shrapnel tore through a wall and into a room where three children were asleep, authorities said. ``I don't know when some cowardly, yellow-bellied so-and-so ... is going to place one of these devices, just for fun, in someone's home, or car or office,'' Mitchell told Overeem. He imposed the maximum 20-year sentence for the offense of manufacturing a destructive explosive device, but suspended all but three years of the term. After Overeem's arrest, investigators said extensive computer records found in his bedroom showed that hundreds of people had access to the bulletin board, including some of the four teenagers killed Dec. 31, 1988, in the accidental explosion of a pipe bomb they were building in a Bethesda, Md., garage.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Threatens To Delay Shuttle Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `If not...', with 5 grafs to specify date of satellite demise and add background. `Picks up 12th graf pvs, `Columbia is...'.
DOC.TEXT: Forecasters said Saturday there is only a 40 percent chance that weather at the Kennedy Space Center will be satisfactory on Monday to launch space shuttle Columbia on a 10-day mission. ``It does not look all that good right now,'' said Terri Brasher, a spokeswoman for Air Force weather forecasters. She ticked off potential problems: poor visibility, a thick layer of clouds hanging low over the launch area and rain, but said ``we remain optimistic.''
